[{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"deprecation_process.md","document_title":"Step 4: Trigger a release","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/deprecation_process.md","content":"# Step 4: Trigger a release ## Release the Package # deprecation_process.md # Step 4: Trigger a release ## Release the Package A release here is the same as usual, triggering the release pipeline of your SDK. Note that local smoke testing and mypy/pylint/sphinx/etc. checks are not needed. More instructions on release can be found at: https://aka.ms/azsdk/release-checklist **Note: This release DOES NOT need to be done during during release week and can be done any time.** ### Checks Failing on Other Packages You may see tests/mypy/pylint or other checks failing on other packages in the CI when releasing. To unblock the release of the deprecated package, you may add one or more `Skip.*` variables when you 'Run pipeline' to skip these checks. The `Skip.*` variables for all checks are listed [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/dc283ae7e8f7fe3bb1db8f27315d589e88bdf453/doc/eng_sys_checks.md?plain=1#L76)."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#mgmt#generation.md","document_title":"Generation of SDK","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/generation.md","content":"# Generation of SDK ## Building the code ### Automation bot # dev#mgmt#generation.md # Generation of SDK ## Building the code ### Automation bot If the automation is doing its job correctly, you should not have to build the SDK, but look for an integration PR for the service in question. This link will give you for instance [the list of all integration PRs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/labels/ServicePR)."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#README.md","document_title":"Developer Documentation","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/README.md","content":"# Developer Documentation # dev#README.md # Developer Documentation This folder contains documentation for developers of SDKs: internal teams at Microsoft, or advanced contributors. Overview of the documents: - [Developer Set-Up](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/dev_setup.md) : How to create a development environment for this repo - [Release](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/release.md) : How to release a package when ready - [Packaging](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/packaging.md) : How to organize packaging information for packages under `azure` - [Testing](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/tests.md): How to write unit and functional tests for a library - [Docstrings](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/docstring.md): How to document an SDK (API View) and our documentation at [MS Docs][ms_docs] and the [azure.github.io][azure_github_io] site. - [Type Hints and Type Checking](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/static_type_checking.md) / [Cheatsheet](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/static_type_checking_cheat_sheet.md): How to add type hints to your library code and run type checking. The [mgmt](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt) folder contains information specific to management packages (i.e. packages prefixed by `azure-mgmt`) [ms_docs]: https://docs.microsoft.com/python/api/overview/azure/appconfiguration-readme?view=azure-python [azure_github_io]: https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk-for-python/"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-pipeline.md","document_title":"Run release SDK pipeline","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-pipeline","content":"# Run release SDK pipeline ## SDK release pipeline # docs#develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-pipeline.md # Run release SDK pipeline ## SDK release pipeline At a high level the process is: - Locate the appropriate pipeline for your set of packages. - Manually queue a build targeting the commit sha you want to release. - Wait for the build, signing and validation steps to complete. - Approve release via the pipeline. When you use our release pipelines, the SDK is released in the following package managers: | **Language** | **Package Manager** | | ----------- | --------------- | | **.NET** | [NuGet](https://nuget.org) | | **C** | GitHub source release (single source unit to GitHub and publishes doxygen documentation to github.io) | | **C++** | [vcpkg](https://github.com/microsoft/vcpkg) | | **Go** | [Go](https://pkg.go.dev/) | | **Java** | [Maven](https://search.maven.org/) (via oss.sonatype.org) | | **JavaScript** | [NPM](https://www.npmjs.com/) | | **Python** | [PyPI](https://pypi.org/) | ### Select a release pipeline 1. Go to our [pipelines hub](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?view=pipelines&option=recent) contained within the _internal_ team project. 1. Select **All** to see all the pipelines aggregated by language folders. 1. Per language, you will need to locate and select the pipeline that is used to build your package. Pipelines are named after the language and service area that they are responsible for building and releasing. For example the _core_ libraries are named **java - core**, and the app configuration libraries are named **java - appconfiguration**. 1. If you don't find a release pipeline, you will need to create one. > [!NOTE] > In some cases where there was a pre-existing track 1 library and new track 2 libraries were introduced, > we have split the pipelines - so you may see some pipelines in the form **java - [service] - data**. > This means that the pipeline is the track 1 version of the unified pipeline. This distinction is made to optimize the > build and release process for teams doing active development on the track 2 versions of the library. #### Create a release pipeline To generate pipelines for a new service that does not yet exist on _main_, ensure that your PR contains the `ci.yml` and `tests.yml` files ([modified from the template](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki/117/Setting-up-a-new-Unified-Pipeline)) and then issue the following comment on your github pull request: \`\`\` /azp run prepare-pipelines \`\`\` This will trigger a pipeline which analyzes the state of the repo-based on your commit and generates pipelines necessary to run PR validation. ### Run a release pipeline 1. Click on **Run pipeline**. 1. If the slide out panel displays checkbox on packages, select the package you would like to release, and deselect other packages. 1. If you want to release whatever commit is the HEAD of _main_, click **Run** on the slide out panel that is displayed. Our recommendation is to release against main. However, if you want to build a specific commit or branch, add the commit hash or branch name in the **Commit** field. > [!IMPORTANT] > Before running the build pipeline, make sure that your Core dependency (and any other inter-library dependency) > is correct for the current release. ### Wait for signing Once the pipeline started it will display a progress screen. Because releasing a package is a multi-stage process, we first build the package from scratch again, then sign the package. Wait until this step is completed. ### Inspect the package 1. Click on the **Artifacts** generated by the pipeline. 1. Select **packages-signed**. 1. Select each package you want to release and download it. 1. Spot check version and package name and inspect and/or test the package. Make sure you are satisfied with the quality. ### Approve the release > [!IMPORTANT] > Once a package is published to a package manger, the action is final and cannot be reversed. > While it is possible to remove or conceal problematic packages, reusing the same version number is not an option. > All future package releases require a version change at minimum. Each package generated by the pipeline has an individual approval checkpoint before it is finalized for publishing. This allows you to selectively approve a specific package for release while declining the rest. 1. Read our [Azure SDK approval release guidelines](xref:sdk-approval-release-guidelines). 1. Click on the **Review** button in the pipeline run to start the approval process. 1. Select which of the packages you want to approve for release. 1. Select **Reject** for the packages you do not want to release. >[!IMPORTANT] > Make sure to approve only your package's release stage as the pipeline is shared among multiple packages. ![Approve release example](../../img/approve_release.png) Once you click approve the pipeline will proceed to tag the sources that were just built with the package name and version and then publish the package to the appropriate package manager."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#retirement#sdk-deprecation.md","document_title":"Deprecating Azure SDKs","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/retirement/sdk-deprecation","content":"# Deprecating Azure SDKs ## Update package managers # docs#retirement#sdk-deprecation.md # Deprecating Azure SDKs ## Update package managers The Azure SDKs are hosted on public package managers: | **Language** | **Package Manager** | | --- | --- | | **.NET** | [NuGet](https://nuget.org) | | **Python** | [PyPI](https://pypi.org/) | | **JavaScript** | [NPM](https://www.npmjs.com/) | | **Java** | [Maven](https://search.maven.org/) | | **Go** | [pkg.go.dev](https://pkg.go.dev/) | The download page for each deprecated package on each package manager needs to be updated with a deprecation message. ### Deprecation message | **Package Status** | **Message** | | --- | --- | | Deprecated with differently named replacement | This package has been deprecated and will no longer be maintained after ``. Upgrade to the replacement package, ``, to continue receiving updates. Refer to the migration guide (``) for guidance on upgrading. Refer to our deprecation policy (link) for more details. | | Deprecated with same name | This package has been deprecated and will no longer be maintained after ``. Upgrade to the latest version to continue receiving updates. Refer to the migration guide (``) for guidance on upgrading. Refer to our [deprecation policy](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support-policies) for more details. | ### Package specific requirements from another deprecated package. **PyPI** | Follow the process outlined in the [package deprecation wiki](https://aka.ms/azsdk/python/deprecation-process) located in the Azure SDK for Python GitHub repo. | **NPM** |File a deprecation issue on the Azure SDK for JS GitHub [repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-js/issues/new?assignees=xirzec&labels=bug%2Cneeds-triage&projects=&template=deprecation_request.yaml&title=%5BDeprecate%5D%3A).| **Maven** |Follow the process outlined in the package deprecation wiki located in the Azure SDK for Java GitHub [repo](https://aka.ms/azsdk/java/deprecation-process). | **pkg.go.dev** |Follow the process outlined in the package deprecation wiki located in the Azure SDK for Go GitHub [repo](https://aka.ms/azsdk/go/deprecation-process). | | **Package Manager** | **Deprecation Process** | | --- | --- | | **NuGet** | If you are deprecating .NET packages, there is automation in the Azure SDK GitHub repo that will update NuGet after your dotnet CSV commit is merged. You will need to have the NuGet search popularity for the deprecated package forwarded to the new replacement package to ensure it shows up in search results. This is a manual step and requires sending an email to account@nuget.org with the names of deprecated packages whose popularity should be transferred, and the list of stable packages that should receive the popularity transfer for each deprecated package. If deprecating more than ten packages, list them in tabular form using two columns: new ID, old ID. After the application is submitted, the NuGet team will notify you of the application's acceptance or rejection status (with the criteria that caused rejection).

Popularity transfer requirements:
- The legacy packages and new packages must share all owners.
- The new packages must be clearly related to the legacy packages in naming and function (i.e., an evolution or next generation).
- All versions of the legacy packages must be deprecated and point to the new packages receiving the transfer.
- The popularity transfer must not cause confusion for NuGet users or worsen the NuGet search experience.
- The new packages must have a stable version.
- The legacy package must not receive popularity transfers from another deprecated package. **PyPI** | Follow the process outlined in the [package deprecation wiki](https://aka.ms/azsdk/python/deprecation-process) located in the Azure SDK for Python GitHub repo. | **NPM** |File a deprecation issue on the Azure SDK for JS GitHub [repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-js/issues/new?assignees=xirzec&labels=bug%2Cneeds-triage&projects=&template=deprecation_request.yaml&title=%5BDeprecate%5D%3A).|"},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#mgmt#mgmt_release.md","document_title":"Management Package Release","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/mgmt_release.md","content":"# Management Package Release ## General Release Process Overview # dev#mgmt#mgmt_release.md # Management Package Release ## General Release Process Overview Once Swagger PR is merged and a release plan/request is submitted, here are steps that you need to do in order to release a new package: - create SDK pull request with code generation - identify and resolve breaking changes - verify that generated code was generated correctly, make sure right version was generated with right configuration - verify the release notes match actual changes (CHANGELOG.md) - verify the version accordingly to changes that were made (_version.py) - generate samples and develop tests - make sure the CI passes - merge the PR if everything looks good - run release pipeline Once you have a PR that contains accurate with correct tests (or no tests at all, but CI is green), this page explains how to prepare for a release. IMPORTANT NOTE: All the commands in this page assumes you have loaded the [dev_setup](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/dev_setup.md) in your currently loaded virtual environment."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#release.md","document_title":"Release process","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/release.md","content":"# Release process ## Python Package Index ### Production - Deploy with Azure Dev Ops # dev#release.md # Release process ## Python Package Index ### Production - Deploy with Azure Dev Ops To avoid "accidental" pushes to our target repositories, [approval](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/pipelines/release/approvals/approvals?view=azure-devops) will be requested directly prior to the final PyPI publish. Reference this [wiki page](https://aka.ms/python-approval-groups) and click on `Release to PyPI Approvers` to add yourself to the group for PyPI publishing. Instead of a single central pipeline, the python SDK has moved to `service directory` associated build pipelines. These are driven by yml templates at the root of each service folder. [Example for storage service folder.](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/sdk/storage/ci.yml#L44) As an aside, please note that the preview feature `multi-stage pipelines` must be enabled to properly interact with unified pipelines. If you aren't aware, find out how to enable by visiting [this link.](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/project/navigation/preview-features?view=azure-devops) #### Releasing Through Unified Pipelines 1. Begin by locating your pipeline on the `internal` project under the `python` folder. Naming convention is `python - `. 1. To release any package under the folder `sdk/core`, you would queue a build against [python - core](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=983&_a=summary) pipeline. 2. After queuing the build, a last test pass will execute prior to splitting into a release job per defined artifact. 3. Click `approve` only on packages that you wish to release to pypi. Reject all others. 1. [A partially approved build will look like this](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build/results?buildId=176564&view=results) Validate artifacts prior to clicking `approve` on the release stage for the package you wish to release. [Additional Internal Wiki Walkthrough](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki/69/Package-release-via-Unified-Pipelines)"},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_wiki","document_filename":"Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start.md","document_title":"Support","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/wiki/Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start","content":"# Support # Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start.md # Support For more questions and general overview of the process, please refer to https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen"},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_wiki","document_filename":"Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start.md","document_title":"Prerequisites","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/wiki/Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start","content":"# Prerequisites ## Project folder structure # Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start.md # Prerequisites ## Project folder structure Before we start, we probably should get to know the project folder for [SDK repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python). Normally, the folder structure would be something like: - `sdk/{service_name}/{package_name}`: **the PROJECT_ROOT folder** - `/azure/{service_name}/{module_name}` : folder where generated code is. - `/tests`: folder of test files - `/samples`: folder of sample files - `azure-{service_name}-{module_name}`: package name. Usually, package name is same with part of **${PROJECT_ROOT} folder**. After release, you can find it in pypi. For example: you can find [azure-messaging-webpubsubservice](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/tree/main/sdk/webpubsub/azure-messaging-webpubsubservice) in [pypi](https://pypi.org/project/azure-messaging-webpubsubservice/). - there are also some other files (like setup.py, README.md, etc.) which are necessary for a complete package. More details on the structure of Azure SDK repos is available in the [Azure SDK common repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/docs/policies/repostructure.md#sdk-directory-layout)."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#release.md","document_title":"NOTE REGARDING ARTIFACTS","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/release.md","content":"# NOTE REGARDING ARTIFACTS # dev#release.md # NOTE REGARDING ARTIFACTS Note that the unified pipeline will maintain a separate release step for each defined artifact in the `Artifacts` parameter in the relevant `ci.yml` file. [Example](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/cffaa424f4198bae99033c8ab2474fe87fb2451a/sdk/storage/ci.yml#L44) The `name` parameter is **required** to be the exact package name with `_` in place of `-`. `safeName` must be unique. Example Artifact List in `ci.yml`: \`\`\` Artifacts: - name: azure_core safeName: azurecore - name: azure_core_tracing_opencensus safeName: azurecorecoretracingopencensus \`\`\` Resulting Release Stages: ![Example Release Stages](./release_stage.png "Example Release Stages") This means that new `mgmt` packages **_must_** be added to this list of artifacts manually."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"esrp_release.md","document_title":"ESRP Release Process","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/esrp_release.md","content":"# ESRP Release Process # esrp_release.md # ESRP Release Process Up until [this PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/pull/29004) the azure-sdk-for-python team released packages to `PyPI` using our own PyPI account. After that PR, our releases will be handled by the central ESRP team. This process change should not affect the release process whatsoever. There will be no change in release experience. Owners will still queue an `internal` build for their service, then approve each individual package for release as necessary. The primary visible effect of these release changes is that these packages will be published by the `Microsoft` pypi account, _not_ `azure-sdk` account that has been used until now. Further details on ESRP release methods is available at [docs.opensource.microsoft.com](https://docs.opensource.microsoft.com/releasing/publish-binaries/python/). ## Break Glass - Yanking/Deleting For low priority yank requests, directly contact the `python` team via email @ `python@microsoft.com`. Ensure that the `package name`, the `version`, and the `yank reason` are readily available in the yank request email. If there is no response on the email, and the request is urgent. escalate to filing a sev 2 ICM. The process is documented [here](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki/1035/ESRP-Release-Task?anchor=escalating-to-esrp)."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#mgmt#README.md","document_title":"Management and ARM SDK documentation for developers","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/README.md","content":"# Management and ARM SDK documentation for developers # dev#mgmt#README.md # Management and ARM SDK documentation for developers The documentation in that folder is intended for developers at Microsoft, or for advanced contributors, in the ARM (Azure Resource Management) world. In order of workflow: - [swagger_conf.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/swagger_conf.md) : Describe how to configure the different Readme on https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs for Python - [tests.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/tests.md) : How to test management SDK (recordings, etc.) - [mgmt_release.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/mgmt_release.md) : How to finish preapring the package, changelog, version, etc. More implementations / advanced documents: - [changelog_impl.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/changelog_impl.md) : Technical details about the change log tool implementation"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#sdk-review.md","document_title":"Request an SDK Architecture Review","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-review","content":"# Request an SDK Architecture Review ## Stable (GA) Review ### How to request a Stable review # docs#develop#sdk-review.md # Request an SDK Architecture Review ## Stable (GA) Review ### How to request a Stable review 1. **Prepare your materials**: Ensure all required materials listed above are ready 2. **Send an email** to [azsdkarch-help@microsoft.com][azsdkarch-help] 3. **Use the following email template**: \`\`\` Subject: [Service Name] [Stable/GA] Azure SDK Review Service Name: [Your service name] API Spec Directory: [Link to spec directory including client.tsp] APIView links for all Tier 1 languages: .NET: [Link] Java: [Link] JavaScript/TypeScript: [Link] Python: [Link] Originating PR(s) for each APIView: .NET: [Link] Java: [Link] JavaScript/TypeScript: [Link] Python: [Link] CI Validation Status: [Confirm passing for all Tier 1 languages] README Links: .NET: [Link] Java: [Link] JavaScript/TypeScript: [Link] Python: [Link] Additional context/questions: [Optional] \`\`\`"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#sdk-docs.md","document_title":"Publish SDK reference docs","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-docs","content":"# Publish SDK reference docs ## Onboard a released package ### Packages released outside the Azure SDK engineering system # docs#develop#sdk-docs.md # Publish SDK reference docs ## Onboard a released package ### Packages released outside the Azure SDK engineering system update the data and [run the automation again](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284). For information about the CSV fields see the [CSV field README](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields). ##### CSV fields Relevant fields in the CSV for docs generation are: - **Package** -- Name of the package (e.g. `Azure.Storage.Blobs`) - **VersionGA** -- The latest GA version of the package (e.g. `12.8.0`) - **VersionPreview** -- The latest preview version of the package (e.g. `12.9.0-beta.1`) - **DisplayName** -- Display name of the package in the table of contents (e.g. `Storage - Blobs`) - **ServiceName** -- Name of the service (e.g. `Storage`) - **MSDocService** -- Used to ensure correct metadata for the docs site. Use an appropriate value for the service as defined in the [taxonomy service (filtered by **ms.service**)](https://taxonomy.learn.microsoft.com/TaxonomyServiceAdminPage/#/taxonomy/detail/2023-01-27T09:00:06.1263332Z!5a3ccca6-19ce-4f32-b516-88038fa259ae/ms.service) (Related: [taxonomy documentation](https://review.learn.microsoft.com/en-us/help/platform/metadata-taxonomies?branch=main#msservice)). - **Type** -- Use values `client` or `mgmt` to place the package in the appropriate location in the table of contents. For more information on CSV fields, see: [metadata CSV readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields) #### Service-level overviews Service-level overviews provide a list of relevant packages. Service-level overview pages are generated automatically for each service and contain a list of packages. Service teams can create their own service-level overview pages which contain more information. Service teams that create their own service-level overview pages are responsible for updating those pages. | ##### Monikers The **\** should be one of "preview" for pre-release versions, "latest" for GA versions, and "legacy" for legacy versions. #### Metadata JSON files Create a metadata JSON file specifying information about your package to ensure that it is properly onboarded into the docs build system. The metadata JSON file should be named in the following format: \`\`\`json { "Name": "Azure.Storage.Blobs", "Version": "12.17.0", "DirectoryPath": "sdk/storage/Azure.Storage.Blobs", "ServiceDirectory": "storage", "ReadMePath": "sdk/storage/Azure.Storage.Blobs/README.md", "ChangeLogPath": "sdk/storage/Azure.Storage.Blobs/CHANGELOG.md", "Group": null, "SdkType": "client", "IsNewSdk": true, "ArtifactName": "Azure.Storage.Blobs", "ReleaseStatus": "2023-07-11", "Namespaces": [ "Azure.Storage.Blobs", "Azure.Storage.Blobs.Models", "Azure.Storage.Blobs.Specialized", "Azure.Storage.Sas", "Microsoft.Extensions.Azure" ], "DocsCiConfigProperties": { "tfm": "netstandard2.0" }, "MSDocService": "placeholder" } \`\`\` Required fields are: - **Name** -- Name of the package (e.g. `Azure.Storage.Blobs`). - **Version** -- The latest GA version of the package (e.g. `12.17.0`). - **ServiceDirectory** -- Name of the service (e.g. `storage`). - **DirectoryPath** -- Path from the root of the `azure-sdk-for-*` repo to the package. If unknown or the package is not released from an `azure-sdk-for-*` repo, use the value `""` - **SdkType** -- Use values `client` or `mgmt` to place the package in the appropriate location in the table of contents. - **IsNewSdk** -- Use `true` if the package is a track 2 SDK, otherwise use `false`. - **Group** -- Required *only for Java* Place the metadata JSON file in the `metadata/` folder with the name of the package. For example, the metadata 1. Release package to a public package repository (e.g. NuGet, Maven, NPM, PyPI). 2. Ensure CSV metadata is correct in the [azure-sdk GitHub Repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/tree/main/_data/releases/latest). 3. Ensure your package has expected service-level overview pages. 4. Ensure your package has expected package-level overviews. 5. Ensure your package appears as expected in the TOC 6. Update metadata JSON files in the docs repo for onboarding. #### Ensure CSV metadata is correct Ensure that your packages are in the metadata CSV files. In most cases you will need to manually add an entry for your package. | | .NET | Java | JavaScript | Python | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | CSV | [Link](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/_data/releases/latest/dotnet-packages.csv) | [Link](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/_data/releases/latest/java-packages.csv) | [Link](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/_data/releases/latest/js-packages.csv) | [Link](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/_data/releases/latest/python-packages.csv) | If the **Notes** field of the CSV for your package has a value of `Needs Review` then [automation](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284) might overwrite your changes. To ensure this doesn't happen, update the **Notes** field to a value other than `Needs Review`... Or find the related [release work items](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/Release/_queries/query/7d106acd-a1c2-47b9-9676-996422328397/), update the data and [run the automation again](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284). For information about the CSV fields see the [CSV field README](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields). ##### CSV fields Relevant fields in the CSV for docs generation are: - **Package** -- Name of the package (e.g. `Azure.Storage.Blobs`) - **VersionGA** -- The latest GA version of the package (e.g. `12.8.0`) #### Service-level overviews Service-level overviews provide a list of relevant packages. Service-level overview pages are generated automatically for each service and contain a list of packages. Service teams can create their own service-level overview pages which contain more information. Service teams that create their own service-level overview pages are responsible for updating those pages. To create a service-level overview page, look for the relevant markdown for your service. Service-level markdown files are named in the format `service-name.md` where spaces are replaced with dashes (`-`). For example the service-level overview for the `Key Vault` service would be named `key-vault.md`. An `[!INCLUDE]` directive can be used to include a list of packages which will be automatically updated as metadata about new packages is available. \`\`\`md [!INCLUDE [packages](advisor-index.md)] \`\`\` The list of packages is in a file whose name is of the form `-index.md`. Service-level overview examples: - Custom service-level overview requiring manual edits: [Python Storage](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-python/blob/main/docs-ref-services/latest/storage.md) - Service-level overview generated automatically: [Python Advisor](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-python/blob/main/docs-ref-services/latest/advisor.md) #### Package-level overviews Package level overviews are generated from the README.md file in the package source as part of the release process. For example: [JavaScript storage blob package README.md in SDK repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-js/blob/main/sdk/storage/storage-blob/README.md). For packages released through the Azure SDK engineering system there is no action. repo to the package. If unknown or the package is not released from an `azure-sdk-for-*` repo, use the value `""` - **SdkType** -- Use values `client` or `mgmt` to place the package in the appropriate location in the table of contents. - **IsNewSdk** -- Use `true` if the package is a track 2 SDK, otherwise use `false`. - **Group** -- Required *only for Java* Place the metadata JSON file in the `metadata/` folder with the name of the package. For example, the metadata JSON file for the `Azure.Storage.Blobs` package would be named [`Azure.Storage.Blobs.json`](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-dotnet/blob/main/metadata/latest/Azure.Storage.Blobs.json). For Java packages, name the file for the artifact and omit the group ID (e.g. [`azure-storage-blob.json`](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-java/blob/main/metadata/latest/azure-storage-blob.json)). | | .NET | Java | JS | Python | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Metadata Location | [Link](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-dotnet/tree/main/metadata) | [Link](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-java/tree/main/metadata) | [Link](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-node/tree/main/metadata) | [Link](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-python/tree/main/metadata) | #### Package-level overviews Package level overviews are generated from the README.md file in the package source as part of the release process. For example: [JavaScript storage blob package README.md in SDK repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-js/blob/main/sdk/storage/storage-blob/README.md). For packages released through the Azure SDK engineering system there is no action. For packages released outside of the Azure SDK engineering system, a package-level overview will need to be checked into the docs repo. The package-level overview should be named in the following for each language: | Language | Package name | Package-level overview name | Location | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | .NET | `Azure.AI.FormRecognizer"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#sdk-docs.md","document_title":"Publish SDK reference docs","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-docs","content":"# Publish SDK reference docs ## FAQ ### How do I preview docs? # docs#develop#sdk-docs.md # Publish SDK reference docs ## FAQ ### How do I preview docs? Docs can be previewed on the review site. To preview docs that are built and about to publish visit: - [.NET](https://review.learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/overview/azure/?view=azure-dotnet&branch=main) - [Java](https://review.learn.microsoft.com/en-us/java/api/overview/azure/?branch=main&view=azure-java-stable) - [JavaScript](https://review.learn.microsoft.com/en-us/javascript/api/overview/azure/?view=azure-node-latest&branch=main)- [JS](https://review.learn.microsoft.com/en-us/javascript/api/overview/azure/?view=azure-node-latest&branch=main) - [Python](https://review.learn.microsoft.com/en-us/python/api/overview/azure/?view=azure-python&branch=main) For packages released from the Azure SDK engineering system, daily docs are available for review. To view daily docs, visit the preview site for the documentation and from the branch selection dropdown in the top right of the page select a branch with the name format following `daily/YYYY-MM-DD-ignore-build-ci-succeeded` if the branch name for the date you wish to preview ends in `-ignore-build-ci-failed` then reach out to the team for assistance. > [!NOTE] > The "ignore-build" is in the branch name to prevent the docs build system from automatically kicking off runs with each commit to the `daily/YYYY-MM-DD` branch. Instead, our docIndex runs kick off the daily docs build at the end if there are no errors."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"SDK-Validation.md","document_title":"Table of Contents","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/SDK-Validation","content":"# Table of Contents ## How to Download the Generated Artifacts ### Steps to Download Artifacts # SDK-Validation.md # Table of Contents ## How to Download the Generated Artifacts ### Steps to Download Artifacts Let's take Python as an example. 1. Locate Generated Artifacts: The generated artifacts for Python are located under the **Packages** folder. ![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a6f1d800-4b3a-42ff-863a-45b50c201047)"},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#release.md","document_title":"Release process","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/release.md","content":"# Release process ## Prerequisites # dev#release.md # Release process ## Prerequisites First, ensure your code on `main` is ready to publish. For management (control plane) packages, start with this page: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/mgmt_release.md For client (data plane) packages, ensure that: - The version at `sdk/path-to-your-package/_version.py` has been updated following [these guidelines](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/package_version/package_version_rule.md). - The changelog has been updated following [these guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releases.html#change-logs). - Package README has been updated following [these guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/python_documentation.html). - Samples have been updated following [these guidelines](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/sample_guide.md)."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Specification-Folder-Structure-Guide.md","document_title":"Azure REST API Specification Directory Structure","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Specification-Folder-Structure-Guide","content":"# Azure REST API Specification Directory Structure ## Contact Us # Specification-Folder-Structure-Guide.md # Azure REST API Specification Directory Structure ## Contact Us If you have any questions regarding folder structure and Azure Service Versioning Guideline, you can reach out by: - [TypeSpec Discussion] Channel. - Email to azversioning@service.microsoft.com > [!WARNING] > **All violations described above are considered legacy and deprecated.** They are strongly discouraged for any new development and will be addressed through the ongoing migration efforts. info about python SDK","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/wiki/Generate-Python-Mgmt-SDK-from-Typespec","content":"# Necessary info about python SDK ## Project service name and namespace # Generate-Python-Mgmt-SDK-from-Typespec.md # Necessary info about python SDK ## Project service name and namespace Two key pieces of information for your project are the service_name and namespace. The `service_name` is the short name for the Azure service. The `service_name` should match across all the SDK language repos and should be name of the directory in the specification folder of the Rest repo that contains the REST API definition file. An example is Service Bus, whose API definitions are in the `specification/servicebus` folder of the Rest repo, and uses the service_name "servicebus". Not every service follows this convention, but it should be the standard unless there are strong reasons to deviate. In Python, a project's `package name` is the name used to publish the package in [PyPI](https://pypi.org/). By default, the package name is derived from the `namespace`, just swapping the `.`s for `-`s. You can override the default `package-name` by passing in a different value in your `tspconfig.yaml`. For management plane libraries, the package_name could be just azure-mgmt-{service_name}. An example is "azure-mgmt-servicebus"."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_wiki","document_filename":"Generate-Python-Mgmt-SDK-from-Typespec.md","document_title":"What to do after generating the SDK code","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/wiki/Generate-Python-Mgmt-SDK-from-Typespec","content":"# What to do after generating the SDK code ## Create/Update the `ci.yml` # Generate-Python-Mgmt-SDK-from-Typespec.md # What to do after generating the SDK code ## Create/Update the `ci.yml` Now, if everything looks good to you, you can submit a PR in [azure-sdk-for-python](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python) repo with all the changes you made above. Before you do that, you need to add/update the `ci.yml` file. Depends on whether there's already one in `sdk/{servicename}` folder. If there's no such file then you can add the following template. \`\`\`yaml // DO NOT EDIT THIS FILE // This file is generated automatically and any changes will be lost. trigger: branches: include: - main - hotfix/* - release/* - restapi* paths: include: - sdk/{service_name}/ pr: branches: include: - main - feature/* - hotfix/* - release/* - restapi* paths: include: - sdk/{service_name}/ extends: template: ../../eng/pipelines/templates/stages/archetype-sdk-client.yml parameters: ServiceDirectory: {service_name} Artifacts: - name: { package_name } safeName: { safeName } \`\`\` Please change the `{service_name}`, `{package_name}` and `{safeName}` into yours. If there's already a `ci.yml` file in your project path. then the only thing you need to do is to add the `package_name` and `safeName` of yours into that `ci.yml`. Usually, `safeName` is derived from `package name` by removing all `-`. For example: [webpubwub](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/sdk/webpubsub/ci.yml)."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"deprecation_process.md","document_title":"Step 4: Trigger a release","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/deprecation_process.md","content":"# Step 4: Trigger a release ## Release the Package # deprecation_process.md # Step 4: Trigger a release ## Release the Package A release here is the same as usual, triggering the release pipeline of your SDK. Note that local smoke testing and mypy/pylint/sphinx/etc. checks are not needed. More instructions on release can be found at: https://aka.ms/azsdk/release-checklist **Note: This release DOES NOT need to be done during during release week and can be done any time.** ### Checks Failing on Other Packages You may see tests/mypy/pylint or other checks failing on other packages in the CI when releasing. To unblock the release of the deprecated package, you may add one or more `Skip.*` variables when you 'Run pipeline' to skip these checks. The `Skip.*` variables for all checks are listed [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/dc283ae7e8f7fe3bb1db8f27315d589e88bdf453/doc/eng_sys_checks.md?plain=1#L76)."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"deprecation_process.md","document_title":"Microsoft Azure SDK for Python","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/deprecation_process.md","content":"# Microsoft Azure SDK for Python # deprecation_process.md # Microsoft Azure SDK for Python This package has been deprecated and will no longer be maintained after . This package will only receive security fixes until . Package source code and samples have been removed from the `main` branch and can be found under the release tag for the latest version. See [azure-mypackage_](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/tree/azure-mypackage_/sdk/mypackage/azure-mypackage). The latest release can be found on [PyPI](https://pypi.org/project/azure-mypackage/). If you have any questions, please open a [GitHub Issue](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/issues) or email `azpysdkhelp@microsoft.com`. \`\`\` - Delete all files in the package directory `sdk/mypackage/azure-mypackage` EXCEPT for the README.md at the package directory root. - You will see an `Artifacts` parameter in `mypackage/ci.yml`. \`\`\`yml extends: parameters: ... Artifacts: - name: azure-mypackage safeName: azuremypackage \`\`\` - If there are multiple packages listed, remove the `name` and corresponding `safeName` lines for only `azure-mypackage`. \`\`\`yml extends: parameters: ... Artifacts: ... \`\`\` - If the only package listed is `azure-mypackage`, delete `ci.yml` and all other files -- _not package subdirectories_-- in the `mypackage` service directory (i.e. `tests.yml`, `test-resources.bicep`, etc.). - Create a new PR targeting the `main` branch of the repository. - Post the PR in the [review channel for Python](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3a4175567f1e154a80ab5b88cbd22ea92f%40thread.skype/Language%2520-%2520Python%2520-%2520Reviews?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47). - Once the PR has been approved by codeowner, merge. - You're responsible for fixing any CI issues related to this PR."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#tests.md","document_title":"Python SDK testing guide","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/tests.md","content":"# Python SDK testing guide ## Write or run tests ### Set up test resources # dev#tests.md # Python SDK testing guide ## Write or run tests ### Set up test resources Live Azure resources will be necessary in order to run live tests and produce recordings. There are PowerShell test resource management commands, documented in [/eng/common/TestResources][test_resources], that streamline this process. Both pure ARM templates (`test-resources.json`) and BICEP files (`test-resources.bicep`) are supported. User-based authentication is preferred when using test resources. The `New-TestResources` script defaults to user-based authentication. To use it: - Choose a development tool to authenticate with by setting an `AZURE_TEST_USE_*_AUTH` environment variable to "true" (tests will authenticate as the tool's logged-in user). The following tools are supported, listed in the order that authentication will be attempted in if requested: 1. Azure PowerShell: set `AZURE_TEST_USE_PWSH_AUTH`. 2. Azure CLI (`az`): set `AZURE_TEST_USE_CLI_AUTH`. 4. Azure Developer CLI (`azd`): set `AZURE_TEST_USE_AZD_AUTH`. - Ensure you're logged into the tool you choose -- if you used `New-TestResources` to deploy resources, you'll already have logged in with Azure PowerShell. **Important:** these environment variables will only be successfully used if test credentials are fetched with the [`AzureRecordedTestCase.get_credential`][get_credential] method. See [Write your tests](#write-your-tests) for details. If you haven't yet set up a `test-resources` file for test resource deployment and/or want to use test resources of your own, you can just configure credentials to target these resources instead. To create a `test-resources` file: 1. Create an Azure Resource Management Template for your specific service and the configuration you need. This can be done in the [Portal][azure_portal] by creating a resource, and at the very last step (Review + Create), clicking "Download a template for automation". 2. Save this template to a `test-resources.json` file under the directory that contains your package your own, you can just configure credentials to target these resources instead. To create a `test-resources` file: 1. Create an Azure Resource Management Template for your specific service and the configuration you need. This can be done in the [Portal][azure_portal] by creating a resource, and at the very last step (Review + Create), clicking "Download a template for automation". 2. Save this template to a `test-resources.json` file under the directory that contains your package (`sdk//test-resources.json`) or create a `test-resources.bicep` file. You can refer to [Key Vault's][kv_test_resources] as an example. 3. Add templates for any additional resources in a grouped `"resources"` section of `test-resources` ([example][kv_test_resources_resources]). 4. Add an `"outputs"` section to `test-resources` that describes any environment variables necessary for accessing these resources ([example][kv_test_resources_outputs])."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-pipeline.md","document_title":"Run release SDK pipeline","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-pipeline","content":"# Run release SDK pipeline ## SDK release pipeline # docs#develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-pipeline.md # Run release SDK pipeline ## SDK release pipeline At a high level the process is: - Locate the appropriate pipeline for your set of packages. - Manually queue a build targeting the commit sha you want to release. - Wait for the build, signing and validation steps to complete. - Approve release via the pipeline. When you use our release pipelines, the SDK is released in the following package managers: | **Language** | **Package Manager** | | ----------- | --------------- | | **.NET** | [NuGet](https://nuget.org) | | **C** | GitHub source release (single source unit to GitHub and publishes doxygen documentation to github.io) | | **C++** | [vcpkg](https://github.com/microsoft/vcpkg) | | **Go** | [Go](https://pkg.go.dev/) | | **Java** | [Maven](https://search.maven.org/) (via oss.sonatype.org) | | **JavaScript** | [NPM](https://www.npmjs.com/) | | **Python** | [PyPI](https://pypi.org/) | ### Select a release pipeline 1. Go to our [pipelines hub](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?view=pipelines&option=recent) contained within the _internal_ team project. 1. Select **All** to see all the pipelines aggregated by language folders. 1. Per language, you will need to locate and select the pipeline that is used to build your package. Pipelines are named after the language and service area that they are responsible for building and releasing. For example the _core_ libraries are named **java - core**, and the app configuration libraries are named **java - appconfiguration**. 1. If you don't find a release pipeline, you will need to create one. > [!NOTE] > In some cases where there was a pre-existing track 1 library and new track 2 libraries were introduced, > we have split the pipelines - so you may see some pipelines in the form **java - [service] - data**. > This means that the pipeline is the track 1 version of the unified pipeline. This distinction is made to optimize the > build and release process for teams doing active development on the track 2 versions of the library. #### Create a release pipeline To generate pipelines for a new service that does not yet exist on _main_, ensure that your PR contains the `ci.yml` and `tests.yml` files ([modified from the template](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki/117/Setting-up-a-new-Unified-Pipeline)) and then issue the following comment on your github pull request: \`\`\` /azp run prepare-pipelines \`\`\` This will trigger a pipeline which analyzes the state of the repo-based on your commit and generates pipelines necessary to run PR validation. ### Run a release pipeline 1. Click on **Run pipeline**. 1. If the slide out panel displays checkbox on packages, select the package you would like to release, and deselect other packages. 1. If you want to release whatever commit is the HEAD of _main_, click **Run** on the slide out panel that is displayed. Our recommendation is to release against main. However, if you want to build a specific commit or branch, add the commit hash or branch name in the **Commit** field. > [!IMPORTANT] > Before running the build pipeline, make sure that your Core dependency (and any other inter-library dependency) > is correct for the current release. ### Wait for signing Once the pipeline started it will display a progress screen. Because releasing a package is a multi-stage process, we first build the package from scratch again, then sign the package. Wait until this step is completed. ### Inspect the package 1. Click on the **Artifacts** generated by the pipeline. 1. Select **packages-signed**. 1. Select each package you want to release and download it. 1. Spot check version and package name and inspect and/or test the package. Make sure you are satisfied with the quality. ### Approve the release > [!IMPORTANT] > Once a package is published to a package manger, the action is final and cannot be reversed. > While it is possible to remove or conceal problematic packages, reusing the same version number is not an option. > All future package releases require a version change at minimum. Each package generated by the pipeline has an individual approval checkpoint before it is finalized for publishing. This allows you to selectively approve a specific package for release while declining the rest. 1. Read our [Azure SDK approval release guidelines](xref:sdk-approval-release-guidelines). 1. Click on the **Review** button in the pipeline run to start the approval process. 1. Select which of the packages you want to approve for release. 1. Select **Reject** for the packages you do not want to release. >[!IMPORTANT] > Make sure to approve only your package's release stage as the pipeline is shared among multiple packages. ![Approve release example](../../img/approve_release.png) Once you click approve the pipeline will proceed to tag the sources that were just built with the package name and version and then publish the package to the appropriate package manager."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#release.md","document_title":"NOTE REGARDING ARTIFACTS","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/release.md","content":"# NOTE REGARDING ARTIFACTS # dev#release.md # NOTE REGARDING ARTIFACTS Note that the unified pipeline will maintain a separate release step for each defined artifact in the `Artifacts` parameter in the relevant `ci.yml` file. [Example](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/cffaa424f4198bae99033c8ab2474fe87fb2451a/sdk/storage/ci.yml#L44) The `name` parameter is **required** to be the exact package name with `_` in place of `-`. `safeName` must be unique. Example Artifact List in `ci.yml`: \`\`\` Artifacts: - name: azure_core safeName: azurecore - name: azure_core_tracing_opencensus safeName: azurecorecoretracingopencensus \`\`\` Resulting Release Stages: ![Example Release Stages](./release_stage.png "Example Release Stages") This means that new `mgmt` packages **_must_** be added to this list of artifacts manually."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-internal-wiki","document_filename":"Engineering-System#Pipelines#Azure-DevOps-Pipeline-Guidance.md","document_title":"Pipelines","document_link":"https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki?wikiVersion=GBwikiMaster&pagePath=/Engineering-System/Pipelines/Azure-DevOps-Pipeline-Guidance","content":"## Pipelines ### Most common pipeline configurations for our main language repos # Engineering-System#Pipelines#Azure-DevOps-Pipeline-Guidance.md ## Pipelines ### Most common pipeline configurations for our main language repos - ` - - ci` - Pipeline hooked up to the service ci.yml file and runs in our public team and is used for automatic PR validation for the service. This pipeline has no access to secrets and thus can only do builds and run unit/recorded tests. - ` - ` - Pipeline hooked up to the service ci.yml file and runs in our internal team and is used for daily scheduled builds and releases. Thee daily scheduled builds are primarily for ensuring the pipeline remains functional and for publishing daily dev packages to our dev feeds. We also queue manual builds from here to [release packages](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki/8/Releasing-Packages?anchor=publishing-packages). - ` - - tests` - Pipeline hooked up to the service tests.yml file and runs in our internal team and is used for daily test runs. These runs are usually for live test validation but will usually run all tests but in live test mode. These pipelines can also be used to trigger a live test run on a PR via a comment trigger `/azp run - - tests`."}]

rows.inputs.ground_truth:
According to error log, it seems that your typespec refer to folder outside project folder but you don't declare it in `tspconfig.yaml`. You could add the missing dir like below then try again:
```
"@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-cli":
additionalDirectories:
- "specification/keyvault/Security.KeyVault.Common/"
```
rows.inputs.response:
Your Python SDK generation is failing due to unresolved relative imports in your TypeSpec files (errors like 'Couldn't resolve import "../Discovery.Shared/namespace.tsp"'). This typically happens when the TypeSpec compiler cannot locate the referenced files because they are outside the main service directory.

To resolve this, you need to specify the additional directories containing the shared TypeSpec files in your configuration. For Azure SDK pipelines and local generation, this is done by adding an `additionalDirectories` array to your TypeSpec location configuration (often in a file like `tsp-location.yaml`).

Here's how to fix it:

1. Locate or create the `tsp-location.yaml` file in your service's TypeSpec directory.
2. Add the `additionalDirectories` property, listing the relative paths to all folders containing the shared TypeSpec files you import. For example:

```yaml
directory: specification/discoverydev/Discovery.Workspace
repo: Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr
commit: <your-commit-sha>
additionalDirectories:
  - specification/discoverydev/Discovery.Shared
```

3. Make sure the paths are relative to the repo root and point to the folders containing the referenced `.tsp` files.
4. Commit this change and re-run the pipeline or local generation.

This will ensure the TypeSpec compiler can resolve all relative imports and your Python SDK generation should succeed.

If you are using a different config file or tool, look for an equivalent `additionalDirectories` or import path setting.

# docs#design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md

# SDK generation configuration

To generate SDK code based on REST API specifications, you need to configure the corresponding files.
- For TypeSpec, the configuration file is `tspconfig.yaml`.
- For OpenAPI, the configuration file is `readme.md`.

## Enable SDK generation

>[!IMPORTANT]
> You cannot enable SDK generation for both TypeSpec and OpenAPI simultaneously. Disable one before enabling the other.

### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)

Add the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs:
1. Add `@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`.
2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter:
    - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).
    - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).
\`\`\``
"@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt":
    namespace: "Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso"
    emitter-output-dir: "{output-dir}/{service-dir}/{namespace}"
\`\`\``

### [OpenAPI](#tab/openapi)

Configure the `swagger-to-sdk` section in `readme.md`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code for your OpenAPIs:
1. Add `azure-sdk-for-net` to the list.
2. Add detailed settings to a separate file `readme.csharp.md` and place it in the same folder as `readme.md`.
\`\`\``

## Swagger to SDK

This section describes what SDK should be generated by the automatic system.
This is not used by Autorest itself.
\`\`\`yaml
$(swagger-to-sdk)
\`\`\`
swagger-to-sdk:
  - repo: azure-sdk-for-net
\`\`\`

## CSharp

See configuration in [readme.csharp.md](./readme.csharp.md)
\`\`\``
For more samples on configuring specific `readme.{language}.md`, refer to:
- [Sample Readmes for Management Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles)
- [Sample Readmes for Data Plane Specifications](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/samplefiles-dp)
- [Config SDK Guidelines](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/documentation/code-gen)"},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx","document_title":"Configuration","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/configuration/configuration","content":"# Configuration
## Configuration file
### Discovery
# handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx

# Configuration

## Configuration file

### Discovery

The TypeSpec compiler will look for the closest `tspconfig.yaml` file located in the same directory or closest parent directory from the TypeSpec entrypoint.
For example if running `tsp compile /dev/foo/bar/main.tsp`, the compiler will lookup the file at the folllowing paths (in order):
- `/dev/foo/bar/tspconfig.yaml`
- `/dev/foo/tspconfig.yaml`
- `/dev/tspconfig.yaml`
- `/tspconfig.yaml`"},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_wiki","document_filename":"Generate-Python-Mgmt-SDK-from-Typespec.md","document_title":"What to do after generating the SDK code","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/wiki/Generate-Python-Mgmt-SDK-from-Typespec","content":"# What to do after generating the SDK code

# dev#ai#typespec_generation.md

# TypeSpec SDK Generation - Getting Started

Generate Azure SDK for Python from TypeSpec definitions using GitHub Copilot.

## Prerequisites

1. **GitHub CLI authentication**: Run `gh auth login`
2. **Feature branch**: Create a new branch with `git checkout -b <branch-name>`
3. **Python environment**: Ensure `uv` package manager is installed

## Quick Start

### 1. Initiate Generation

In Copilot **Agent** mode, use one of these prompts:
- `"Generate a Python SDK using TypeSpec"`
- `"Start TypeSpec SDK generation for Python"`
- `"Generate SDK from tspconfig.yaml at <path>"`

### 2. Follow Copilot's Workflow

Copilot will automatically:
1. **Verify environment** - Check dependencies and virtual environment
2. **Generate SDK** - Run TypeSpec generation (~5-6 minutes)
3. **Validate code** - Run Pylint, MyPy, Pyright, Verifytypes, Sphinx, Mindependency, Bandit, Black, Samples, Breaking changes (~3-5 minutes each)
4. **Update docs** - Create/update CHANGELOG.md and version files
5. **Commit changes** - Add, commit, and push to your branch
6. **Create PR** - Generate pull request in draft mode
7. **Handoff** - Provide PR link for azure-rest-api-specs agent

### 3. Your Actions

- Provide file paths when requested
- Review and approve code changes
- Confirm commit messages
- Review PR title and description

## Expected Timeline

- **Total time**: 10-15 minutes
- **SDK Generation**: 5-6 minutes
- **Validation**: 3-5 minutes per step
- **Documentation**: 2-4 minutes

## Library Health Check

Check a library's release readiness:
\`\`\`
What is the health status of azure-ai-projects?
\`\`\`
This reports the library's status from [aka.ms/azsdk/python/health](https://www.aka.ms/azsdk/python/health) and identifies any release blockers.

## Next Steps

After PR creation, use the **azure-rest-api-specs agent** with your PR link to complete the release process.

## Useful Prompts

### Starting SDK Generation

**Basic generation:**
\`\`\`
"Generate a Python SDK using TypeSpec"
"Start TypeSpec SDK generation workflow"
\`\`\`
**With local TypeSpec project:**
\`\`\`
"Generate SDK from my local TypeSpec project at sdk/cognitiveservices/azure-ai-projects"
"I have a tspconfig.yaml at [path], generate the Python SDK"
\`\`\`
**With remote TypeSpec:**
\`\`\`
"Generate SDK from TypeSpec at https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/ai/Azure.AI.Projects/tspconfig.yaml"
\`\`\`

### Validation and Fixes

**Fix validation issues:**
\`\`\`
"Fix the pylint warnings in my generated SDK"
"Help me resolve mypy errors"
"Run all validation steps and fix any issues"
\`\`\`
**Check specific validations:**
\`\`\`
"Run only pylint validation"
"Check if my SDK passes pyright validation"
\`\`\`

### Documentation and Release

**Update documentation:**
\`\`\`
"Update the CHANGELOG.md for my new SDK"
"Set the correct version in _version.py"
\`\`\`
**Commit and PR:**
\`\`\`
"Commit my changes and create a pull request"
"Push my SDK changes to a new branch"
\`\`\`

### Health and Status

**Check library health:**
\`\`\`
"What is the health status of azure-ai-projects?"
"Check if azure-cognitiveservices-textanalytics is ready for release"
"Show me the CI status for my library"
\`\`\`"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_migration_docs","document_filename":"typespec-migration-docs-2025-09-12.md","document_title":"missing externalDocs","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange","content":"# missing externalDocs

# missing externalDocs

## question

how to resolve missing externalDocs?

## answer

*.tsp files:
Added @externalDocs decorators to multiple interfaces and operations such as
```diff
+   @externalDocs("https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/consumption/")
    get is Extension.Read<Extension.ScopeParameter, Budget>;
```
generated openapi.json file:
```diff
          "description": "Gets the budget for the scope by budget name.",
+         "externalDocs": {
+           "url": "https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/consumption/"
+         },
```"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"howtos#generate-client-libraries#00howtogen.mdx","document_title":"add "@azure-tools/typespec-python" to your package.json to generate Python code","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/00howtogen","content":"# add "@azure-tools/typespec-python" to your package.json to generate Python code

# rename duplicated model `Resource`

## question

how to rename duplicated model `Resource` for python?

## answer

Add in specification/keyvault/Keyvault.Management/back-compatible.tsp:
```diff
+ import "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-resource-manager";

+ @@clientName(Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Resource, "ArmResource", "python");

## Configuration file
# handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx

# Configuration

## Configuration file

TypeSpec configuration can be provided via the `tspconfig.yaml` configuration file.

### Discovery

The TypeSpec compiler will look for the closest `tspconfig.yaml` file located in the same directory or closest parent directory from the TypeSpec entrypoint.
For example if running `tsp compile /dev/foo/bar/main.tsp`, the compiler will lookup the file at the folllowing paths (in order):
- `/dev/foo/bar/tspconfig.yaml`
- `/dev/foo/tspconfig.yaml`
- `/dev/tspconfig.yaml`
- `/tspconfig.yaml`

### Schema

The file is a `yaml` document with the following structure. See the [next section](#typespec-configuration-options) for details on each option.
\`\`\`typespec
model TypeSpecProjectSchema {
  extends?: string;
  parameters?: Record<{default: string}>
  `environment-variables`?: Record<{default: string}>
  `warn-as-error`?: boolean;
  `output-dir`?: string;
  `trace`?: string | string[];
  imports?: string[];
  emit?: string[];
  `dry-run`?: boolean;
  options?: Record<unknown>;
  linter?: LinterConfig;
}
model LinterConfig {
  extends?: RuleRef[];
  enable?: Record<RuleRef, boolean>;
  disable?: Record<RuleRef, string>;
}
\`\`\`

### Extending Project Files

There may be instances where you want to build different folders with varying options (such as different emitters), but still want to share some common configurations.
In such cases, you can use the `extends` property in the configuration file.
For instance, in `<my-pkg>/tspconfig.yaml`:
\`\`\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml
options:
  emitter1:
    some-option: my-name
  emitter2:
    some-other-option: This is a title
\`\`\`
in `<my-pkg>/proj2/tspconfig.yaml`, enable `emitter1` using the options specified in the parent `tspconfig.yaml`
\`\`\`yaml title=proj2/tspconfig.yaml
extends: ../tspconfig.yaml
emit:
  - emitter1
\`\`\`
#### What gets extended
The extending logic follows these rules:
- **Root-level properties**: Shallow merge for all properties except `options`
- **Options property**: Deep merge at one level (per emitter)
- **Override behavior**: Properties specified in the extending file will completely override those from the extended file
**Root-level merge behavior:**
When extending a configuration, most properties (like `emit`, `imports`, `trace`, etc.) are merged at the root level. If the same property exists in both files, the extending file's value completely replaces the extended file's value.
**Options merge behavior:**
The `options` property receives special treatment with a one-level deep merge:
- Different emitters from both files are combined
- If the same emitter is configured in both files, the extending file's emitter configuration completely overrides the extended file's configuration for that emitter
- Individual emitter options are not merged - it's all or nothing per emitter
**Example:**
\`\`\`yaml
// Base config (parent/tspconfig.yaml)
emit:
  - emitter1
options:
  emitter1:
    option-a: value-a
    option-b: value-b
  emitter2:
    option-x: value-x
// Extending config (child/tspconfig.yaml)
extends: ../tspconfig.yaml
emit:
  - emitter3  # Completely replaces the emit array
options:
  emitter1:

completely overrides the extended file's configuration for that emitter
- Individual emitter options are not merged - it's all or nothing per emitter
**Example:**
\`\`\`yaml
// Base config (parent/tspconfig.yaml)
emit:
  - emitter1
options:
  emitter1:
    option-a: value-a
    option-b: value-b
  emitter2:
    option-x: value-x
// Extending config (child/tspconfig.yaml)
extends: ../tspconfig.yaml
emit:
  - emitter3  # Completely replaces the emit array
options:
  emitter1:   # Completely replaces emitter1 options
    option-c: value-c
  emitter3:   # Added alongside emitter2 from parent
    option-y: value-y
// Resulting merged config:
// emit: [emitter3]  # Only emitter3, emitter1 is gone
// options:
//   emitter1: { option-c: value-c }  # Only option-c, option-a and option-b are gone
//   emitter2: { option-x: value-x }  # Inherited from parent
//   emitter3: { option-y: value-y }  # From extending config
\`\`\`

### Variable interpolation

The TypeSpec project file provides variable interpolation using:
- built-in variables
- environment variables
- config file parameters
- emitter options can reference each other
Variable interpolation is done using an variable expression surrounded by `{` and `}`. (`{<expression>}`)
Examples:
- `{output-dir}/my-path`
- `{env.SHARED_PATH}/my-path`

### Interpolation of Emitter Path Config

emitter                                                                  |
| `service-name`             | service name             | Name of the service                                                                  |
| `service-name-if-multiple` | service name if multiple | Name of the service if multiple, undefined if one                                    |
#### Project Parameters
A TypeSpec project file can define certain parameters that can subsequently be specified through the CLI.
Parameters can be organized in a nested structure, to access different levels of the structure, use dots (`.`) in the variable expression.
Therefore, parameter names should not contain `.` in their name.
The `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be utilized in the default value of these parameters.
These parameters can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression.
All parameters must have a default value.
**Example:**
\`\`\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml
parameters:
  base-dir:
    default: "{cwd}"
output-dir: {base-dir}/output
\`\`\`
The parameter can then be specified via `--arg` in this format `--arg "<parameter-name>=<value>"` and for nested structures `--arg "<parameter-name>.<nested-parameter-name>=<value>"`
\`\`\`bash
tsp compile . --arg "base-dir=/path/to/base"
\`\`\`
#### Environment variables
A TypeSpec project file can specify which environment variables it can interpolate.
The `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be used in the default value of these environment variables.
These environment variables can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression, using the `env.` prefix.
All environment variables must have a default value.
**Example:**
\`\`\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml
environment-variables:
  BASE_DIR:
    default: "{cwd}"
output-dir: {env.BASE_DIR}/output
\`\`\`
#### Emitter Options

Certain emitter configurations can be interpolated using a specific rule designed to collapse a path.
If a variable is succeeded by a `/` or `.` and the emitter responsible for interpolating the config doesn't supply that variable, the path segment will be omitted.
For instance, consider the following config value: `{service-name}/output.{version}.json`
Here's what would be produced:
| Service name value | Version value | Result                    |
| ------------------ | ------------- | ------------------------- |
| `"PetStore"`       | `"v1"`        | `PetStore/output.v1.json` |
| `"PetStore"`       | `undefined`   | `PetStore/output.json`    |
#### Built-in variables
| Variable name              | Scope                    | Description                                                                          |
| -------------------------- | ------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |
| `cwd`                      | \*                       | Points to the current working directory                                              |
| `project-root`             | \*                       | Points to the the tspconfig.yaml file containing folder.                             |
| `output-dir`               | emitter options          | Common `output-dir` See [output-dir](#output-dir---configure-the-default-output-dir) |
| `emitter-name`             | emitter options          | Name of the emitter                                                                  |
| `service-name`             | service name             | Name of the service                                                                  |
| `service-name-if-multiple` | service name if multiple | Name of the service if multiple, undefined if one                                    |
#### Project Parameters
A TypeSpec project file can define certain parameters that can subsequently be specified through the CLI.

variables it can interpolate.
The `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be used in the default value of these environment variables.
These environment variables can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression, using the `env.` prefix.
All environment variables must have a default value.
**Example:**
\`\`\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml
environment-variables:
  BASE_DIR:
    default: "{cwd}"
output-dir: {env.BASE_DIR}/output
\`\`\`
#### Emitter Options
Emitter options can refer to each other by using the other option's name as the variable expression.
Interpolation is only possible among emitter options from the same emitter.
\`\`\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml
options:
  @typespec/openapi3:
    emitter-output-dir: {output-dir}/{emitter-sub-folder}
    emitter-sub-folder: bar
\`\`\`
Emitter options support a nested structure, enabling complex configurations.
\`\`\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml
options:
  emitter-sub-folder:
    sub-folder: bar
\`\`\`
To set these values via the CLI, use dots to navigate deeper levels in the definition. `--option "<option-name>.<nested-option-name>=<value>"`
Due to this capability, emitter option names should not contain a `.` in their name."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md","document_title":"What is TypeSpec?","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec","content":"# What is TypeSpec?
## Get help
# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md

# What is TypeSpec?

## Get help

If you need help or have questions, join the [TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel](https://aka.ms/typespec/discussions).  
This is a community of TypeSpec users and experts who are ready to assist you.

### Azure SDK Q&A Bot

The TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel includes an Azure SDK Q&A Bot that is designed to help you with questions  
related to TypeSpec, Azure TypeSpec, and the related emitters. Simply mention `@Azure SDK Q&A Bot` directly in your  
message with a clear description of the problem you're facing.
**Example usage:**
\`\`\`
@Azure SDK Q&A Bot: How can I describe HTTP status codes for responses in TypeSpec?
\`\`\`
**Best practices for using the bot:**
- Start a conversation by mentioning `@Azure SDK Q&A Bot` in the TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel - note that  
  modifying existing posts won't trigger a response
- The bot only has context from messages that directly mention it and cannot access or see messages outside of that  
  context
- It supports images and GitHub pull request links for better context
- All replies are generated by AI, so please double-check to ensure the information is correct"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors.md","document_title":"After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors","content":"# After migration - in data-plane/DynamicSessions/tspconfig.yaml
