## Common Error Fix Guidance
### Import Resolution Errors
# SDK-Validation.md

# Table of Contents

## Common Error Fix Guidance

### Import Resolution Errors

#### Error Pattern: `import-not-found`
**Error Message Pattern**: `error import-not-found: Couldn't resolve import '[.*].tsp'`
**Root Cause**: The folder containing the imported TypeSpec files is not specified in the `tspconfig.yaml` file's `additionalDirectories` setting.
**Solution Steps**:
1. Locate the `tspconfig.yaml` file in your TypeSpec project root
2. Find the `additionalDirectories` array in the configuration
3. Add the path to the folder containing the imported `.tsp` files
4. Ensure the path is relative to the `tspconfig.yaml` file location
**Reference**: [Sample tspconfig.yaml](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager/tspconfig.yaml#L52)"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"howtos#generate-with-tsp-client#intro_tsp_client.md","document_title":"Usage","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-with-tsp-client/intro_tsp_client","content":"# Usage
## Important concepts
### Per project setup
# howtos#generate-with-tsp-client#intro_tsp_client.md

# Usage

## Important concepts

### Per project setup

| true                  |
| <a id="additionalDirectories-anchor"></a> additionalDirectories | Sometimes a typespec file will use a relative import that might not be under the main directory. In this case a single `directory` will not be enough to pull down all necessary files. To support this you can specify additional directories as a list to sync so that all needed files are synced. | false: default = null |
| <a id="commit-anchor"></a> commit                               | The commit sha for the version of the typespec files you want to generate off of. This allows us to have idempotence on generation until we opt into pointing at a later version.                                                                                                                     | true                  |
| <a id="repo-anchor"></a> repo                                   | The repo this spec lives in. This should be either `Azure/azure-rest-api-specs` or `Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr`. Note that pr will work locally but not in CI until we add another change to handle token based auth.                                                                              | true                  |
| <a id="entrypointFile-anchor"></a> entrypointFile               | A specific entrypoint file used to compile the TypeSpec project. NOTE: This option should only be used with a non-standard entrypoint file name. DO NOT use this option with standard entrypoints: `client.tsp` or `main.tsp`.                                                                        | false                 |
Example:
\`\`\`yml title=tsp-location.yaml
directory: specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager
commit: 431eb865a581da2cd7b9e953ae52cb146f31c2a6
repo: Azure/azure-rest-api-specs
additionalDirectories:
  - specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager.Shared/
\`\`\`

Each project will need to have a configuration file called tsp-location.yaml that will tell the tool where to find the TypeSpec project.
#### tsp-location.yaml
This file is created through the `tsp-client init` command or you can manually create it under the project directory to run other commands supported by this tool.
:::info
This file should live under the project directory for each service.
:::
The file has the following properties:
| Property                                                        | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           | IsRequired            |
| --------------------------------------------------------------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | --------------------- |
| <a id="directory-anchor"></a> directory                         | The top level directory where the main.tsp for the service lives. This should be relative to the spec repo root such as `specification/cognitiveservices/OpenAI.Inference`                                                                                                                            | true                  |
| <a id="additionalDirectories-anchor"></a> additionalDirectories | Sometimes a typespec file will use a relative import that might not be under the main directory. In this case a single `directory` will not be enough to pull down all necessary files. To support this you can specify additional directories as a list to sync so that all needed files are synced. |"},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"emitters#clients#http-client-python#reference#emitter.md","document_title":"Emitter usage","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/clients/http-client-python/reference/emitter","content":"# Emitter usage
## Emitter usage
# emitters#clients#http-client-python#reference#emitter.md

# Emitter usage

## Emitter usage

1. Via the command line
\`\`\`bash
tsp compile . --emit=@typespec/http-client-python
\`\`\`
2. Via the config
\`\`\`yaml
emit:
  - "@typespec/http-client-python"
\`\`\`
The config can be extended with options as follows:
\`\`\`yaml
emit:
  - "@typespec/http-client-python"
options:
  "@typespec/http-client-python":
    option: value
\`\`\`"},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"emitters#clients#http-client-python#reference#package-structure.mdx","document_title":"Namespaces","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/clients/http-client-python/reference/package-structure","content":"# Namespaces
## Controlling the Generation Directory
# emitters#clients#http-client-python#reference#package-structure.mdx

# Namespaces

## Controlling the Generation Directory

When migrating existing SDKs or working with brownfield services, you might need to place generated code in a specific subdirectory, like `_generated`. For these scenarios, you can use the [`namespace` configuration option](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/typespec-client-generator-core/reference/emitter/#namespace) in your `tspconfig.yaml` file.
If you want the published SDK to follow closely with the package structure and namespaces in your TypeSpec file, you should also pass in the `package-name` flag with the desired value.

### Using the `namespace` Flag

The `namespace` option allows you to specify where the generated code should be placed within your package structure. This is particularly useful for cases where you want to:
1. Keep generated code isolated in a dedicated subdirectory
2. Maintain backward compatibility with existing SDK structures
3. Separate generated code from hand-written code
#### Example Configuration
In this example, we will take you through emitting generated code into a specific subdirectory (like `_generated`), with the idea that you will be fully-wrapping the generated code. Add the following to your `tspconfig.yaml`:
<Tabs>
<TabItem label="tspconfig.yaml" default>
\`\`\`yaml
emitters:
  "@typespec/http-client-python":
    namespace: "azure.keyvault.certificates._generated"
    package-name: "azure-keyvault-certificates"
\`\`\`
</TabItem>
<TabItem label="TypeSpec File">
\`\`\`typespec
namespace Azure.KeyVault.Certificates;
@service({
  title: "Azure Key Vault Certificate Client",
})
namespace Azure.Keyvault.Certificates {
  model Certificate {
    id: string;
    name: string;
    properties: CertificateProperties;
  }
  model CertificateProperties {
    created: utcDateTime;
    updated: utcDateTime;
    enabled: boolean;
  }
  @route("/certificates")
  interface CertificateOperations {
    @get list(): Certificate[];
    @get get(@path id: string): Certificate;
  }
}
\`\`\`
</TabItem>
<TabItem label="Generated Python SDK">
\`\`\`
azure-keyvault-certificates/
â”œâ”€â”€ azure/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ keyvault/
â”‚       â””â”€â”€ certificates/
â”‚           â”œâ”€â”€ __init__.py
â”‚           â””â”€â”€ _generated/
â”‚               â”œâ”€â”€ __init__.py
â”‚               â”œâ”€â”€ _models.py
â”‚               â”œâ”€â”€ _client.py
â”‚               â””â”€â”€ ...
â”œâ”€â”€ setup.py
â””â”€â”€ ...
\`\`\`
</TabItem>
</Tabs>"},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"emitters#clients#introduction.mdx","document_title":"Client Emitters","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/clients/introduction","content":"# Client Emitters
## Running Language-Specific Emitters in CLI
# emitters#clients#introduction.mdx

# Client Emitters

## Running Language-Specific Emitters in CLI

<Steps>
1. Ensure that your package.json file is correctly configured to include the necessary dependencies for running the emitters
2. Update the tspconfig.yaml file for properly configured for the language-specific emitter.
   \`\`\`yaml
   emit:
     - "@typespec/http-client-csharp"
     - "@typespec/http-client-java"
     - "@typespec/http-client-python"
     - "@typespec/http-client-js"
   options:
     "@typespec/http-client-csharp":
       emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/dotnet"
     "@typespec/http-client-java":
       emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/java"
     "@typespec/http-client-python":
       emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/python"
     "@typespec/http-client-js":
       emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/javascript"
   \`\`\`
3. Once the package.json and tspconfig.yaml files are updated, you need to install all required dependencies by running the following command in the project root:
   \`\`\`bash
   tsp install
   \`\`\`
4. Run the emitter to compile your TypeScript code into the desired language. Use the following command to trigger the emitter and compile your project:
   \`\`\`bash
   tsp compile {path to main.tsp}/main.tsp
   \`\`\`
</Steps>"},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_wiki","document_filename":"Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start.md","document_title":"Prerequisites","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/wiki/Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start","content":"# Prerequisites
## How to generate SDK code with Dataplane Codegen
### 1. Configure python emitter in tspconfig.yaml
# Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start.md

# Prerequisites

## How to generate SDK code with Dataplane Codegen

### 1. Configure python emitter in tspconfig.yaml

In `rest repo`, there shall be `tspconfig.yaml` where `main.tsp` of your service is. Make sure there are configuration for Python SDK like:
\`\`\`yaml
parameters:
  "service-dir":
    default: "YOUR-SERVICE-DIRECTORY"
emit: [
  "@azure-tools/typespec-autorest", // this value does not affect python code generation
]
options:
  "@azure-tools/typespec-python":
    emitter-output-dir: "{output-dir}/{service-dir}/YOUR-PACKAGE-DIR"
    namespace: "YOUR.NAMESPACE.NAME"
    flavor: "azure"
\`\`\`
`YOUR.NAMESPACE.NAME` is your namespace name; `YOUR-PACKAGE-DIR` is your package directory; `YOUR-SERVICE-DIRECTORY` is SDK directory name. For example, assume that namespace is "azure.ai.anomalydetector" and you want to put it in folder "azure-sdk-for-python/sdk/anomalydetector", then "YOUR.NAMESPACE.NAME" is "azure.ai.anomalydetector", "YOUR_PACKAGE_DIR" is "azure-ai-anomalydetector" and "YOUR-SERVICE-DIRECTORY" is "sdk/anomalydetector""},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#mgmt#sdk-breaking-changes-guide.md","document_title":"Azure Python SDK Breaking Changes Review and Resolution Guide for TypeSpec Migration","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/sdk-breaking-changes-guide.md","content":"# Azure Python SDK Breaking Changes Review and Resolution Guide for TypeSpec Migration
# dev#mgmt#sdk-breaking-changes-guide.md

# Azure Python SDK Breaking Changes Review and Resolution Guide for TypeSpec Migration

The Azure Python SDK generally prohibits breaking changes unless they result from service behavior modifications. This guide helps you identify, review, and resolve breaking changes that may occur in new SDK versions due to migration of service specifications from Swagger to TypeSpec.
Breaking changes can be resolved by:
1. Client Customizations
Client customizations should be implemented in a file named `client.tsp` located in the service's specification directory alongside the main entry point `main.tsp`. This `client.tsp` becomes the new specification entry point, so import `main.tsp` in the `client.tsp` file. **Do not** import `client.tsp` in the `main.tsp` file.
\`\`\`tsp
import "./main.tsp";
import "@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core";
using Azure.ClientGenerator.Core;
// Add your customizations here
\`\`\`
2. TypeSpec Configuration Changes
TypeSpec configuration changes should be made in the `tspconfig.yaml` file located in the service's specification directory. This file is used to configure the TypeSpec compiler and client generator options. For example:
\`\`\`yaml
options:
  "@azure-tools/typespec-python":
\`\`\`

## 1. Naming Changes with Numbers

**Changelog Pattern**:
Paired removal and addition entries showing naming changes from words to numbers:
\`\`\`md
- Enum `Minute` deleted or renamed its member `ZERO`
- Enum `Minute` deleted or renamed its member `THIRTY`
- Enum `Minute` added member `ENUM_0`
- Enum `Minute` added member `ENUM_30`
\`\`\`
**Reason**: Swagger automatically converts numeric names to words during code generation, while TypeSpec preserves the original naming. This affects all type names, including enums, models, and operations.
**Spec Pattern**:
Find the type definition by examining the names from the addition entries in the changelog (pattern: `Enum '<type name>' added member xxx`):
\`\`\`tsp
union Minute {
  int32,
  `0`: 0,
  `30`: 30,
}
\`\`\`
**Resolution**:
Use client customization to restore the original names from the removal entries:
\`\`\`tsp
@@clientName(Minute.`0`, "ZERO", "python");
@@clientName(Minute.`30`, "THIRTY", "python");
\`\`\`

## 2. Operation Naming Changes

**Changelog Pattern**:
Removal of an operation and addition of a similarly named operation for the same operation group:
\`\`\`md
- Added operation StorageTaskAssignmentOperations.storage_task_assignment_list
- Removed operation StorageTaskAssignmentOperations.list
\`\`\`
**Reason**: TypeSpec may generate different operation names than Swagger to avoid naming collisions.
**Spec Pattern**:
Locate the interface and operation using the name from the addition entries.
\`\`\`tsp
interface StorageTaskAssignment {
  op storageTaskAssignmentList(xxx): xxx;
}
\`\`\`
**Resolution**:
Use client naming to restore the original operation name from the removal entries:
\`\`\`tsp
@@clientName(StorageTaskAssignment.storageTaskAssignmentList, "list", "python");
\`\`\`

## 3. Naming Changes from Directive

**Changelog Pattern**:
Paired removal and addition entries showing naming changes for structs:
\`\`\`md
- Added model `RedisResource`
- Deleted or renamed model `ResourceInfo`
\`\`\`
Also, in the legacy config for swagger under the spec folder: `specification/<service>/resource-manager/readme.python.md`, the renaming directives could be found:
\`\`\`md
directive:
- rename-model:
  from: 'RedisResource'
  to: 'ResourceInfo'
\`\`\`
**Reason**: Swagger has directive ways to change the naming.
**Spec Pattern**:
Find the type definition by examining the names from the addition entries in the changelog (pattern: `Added model '<type name>'`):
\`\`\`tsp
model RedisResource {
  ...
}
\`\`\`
**Resolution**:
Use client customization to do the same renaming as the directives in the legacy config:
\`\`\`tsp
@@clientName(RedisResource, "ResourceInfo", "python");
\`\`\`

## 4. Client Naming Changes

**Changelog Pattern**:
Removal entry showing naming change of the client:
\`\`\`md
- Deleted or renamed client `IotDpsClient`
\`\`\`
**Reason**: TypeSpec generates client names based on the `namespace` name rather than the title annotation in the `@service` decorator.
**Spec Pattern**:
Find the name from namespace:
\`\`\`tsp
@service(#{ title: "iotDpsClient" })
namespace Microsoft.Devices;
\`\`\`
**Resolution**:
Update it to the correct client name using `@@clientName`:
\`\`\`tsp
@@clientName(Microsoft.Devices, "IotDpsClient", "python");
\`\`\`

## 5. Reorder of Parameters

Entry showing the parameters get re-ordered for an operation:
\`\`\`md
- Method `IotDpsResourceOperations.get` re-ordered its parameters from `['self', 'provisioning_service_name', 'resource_group_name', 'kwargs']` to `['self', 'resource_group_name', 'provisioning_service_name', 'kwargs']`
\`\`\`
**Reason**: TypeSpec generally uses generic to generate operations. An unified parameters' order will be widely shared in one operation group, and may make difference comparing to what defined in swagger.
**Spec Pattern**:
Operation extends parameters from type `ProvisioningServiceDescription`:
\`\`\`tsp
@armResourceOperations
interface ProvisioningServiceDescriptions {
  get is ArmResourceRead<ProvisioningServiceDescription, Error = ErrorDetails>;
}
\`\`\`
**Resolution**:
Override the operation by a customized one with a manually designed order of parameters:
\`\`\`tsp
op IotDpsResourceGetCustomized(
  @path
  provider: "Microsoft.ThisWillBeReplaced",
  @path
  provisioningServiceName: string,
  ...Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.ResourceGroupNameParameter,
): ProvisioningServiceDescription;
@@override(ProvisioningServiceDescriptions.get,
  IotDpsResourceGetCustomized,
  "python"
);
\`\`\`

## 6. Common Types Upgrade

**Changelog Pattern**:
Multiple changes related to common infrastructure types such as `SystemData` and `IdentityType`:
\`\`\`md
- Deleted or renamed model `IdentityType`
\`\`\`
**Reason**: Common types are upgraded to their latest versions during TypeSpec migration.
**Impact**: Low impact since these are common infrastructure types rarely used directly by users.
**Resolution**: Accept these breaking changes.

## 7. Removal of Unreferenced Models

**Changelog Pattern**:
Multiple removals of unreferenced models that are typically not used in the SDK:
\`\`\`md
- Deleted or renamed model `ProxyResourceWithoutSystemData`
- Deleted or renamed model `Resource`
\`\`\`
**Reason**: Unreferenced models are removed during TypeSpec migration.
**Impact**: Low impact since these models are typically not used directly by users.
**Resolution**: Accept these breaking changes.

## 8. Removal of Pageable Models

**Changelog Pattern**:
Multiple removals of models following the pattern `xxxList`:
\`\`\`md
- Deleted or renamed model `ElasticSanList`
- Deleted or renamed model `SkuInformationList`
- Deleted or renamed model `SnapshotList`
- Deleted or renamed model `VolumeGroupList`
- Deleted or renamed model `VolumeList`
\`\`\`
**Reason**: Python will not expose pageable models for list APIs.
**Impact**: Low impact since these models are typically not used directly by users.
**Resolution**: Accept these breaking changes.

## 9. Parameters Changed to Keyword-only

**Changelog Pattern**:
Entries showing the usage of passing parameters positionally is disabled:
\`\`\`md
- Method `DpsCertificateOperations.delete` changed its parameter `certificate_name1` from `positional_or_keyword` to `keyword_only`
\`\`\`
**Reason**: Query and header parameters in operation methods have been changed from positional to keyword-only by the new operation design.
**Impact**: Users should convert all positional parameters to keyword arguments
**Resolution**: Accept these breaking changes.

## 10. Removal of Parameter `if_match`

**Changelog Pattern**:
Removal of parameter `if_match` and addition of `etag/match_condition` for the same operation:
\`\`\`md
- Model `DpsCertificateOperations` added parameter `etag` in method `create_or_update`
- Model `DpsCertificateOperations` added parameter `match_condition` in method `create_or_update`
- Method `DpsCertificateOperations.create_or_update` deleted or renamed its parameter `if_match` of kind `positional_or_keyword`
\`\`\`
**Reason**: Header signatures `if_match/if_none_match` is replaced by `etag/match_condition` by the new operation design.
**Impact**: Replace `if_match="<specific etag>"` with `etag="<specific etag>", match_condition=MatchConditions.IfNotModified`.
**Resolution**: Accept these breaking changes.

## 11. Removal of multi-level flattened properties

**Changelog Pattern**:
Removal of multiple parameters and addition of parameters `properties` entries for the same model:
\`\`\`md
- Model `VaultExtendedInfoResource` added property `properties`
- Model `VaultExtendedInfoResource` deleted or renamed its instance variable `integrity_key`
- Model `VaultExtendedInfoResource` deleted or renamed its instance variable `encryption_key`
- Model `VaultExtendedInfoResource` deleted or renamed its instance variable `encryption_key_thumbprint`
- Model `VaultExtendedInfoResource` deleted or renamed its instance variable `algorithm`
\`\`\`
**Reason**: Typespec no longer supports multi-level flattening and will always preserve the actual REST API hierarchy. For more detailed information about model hierarchy, please refer to https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/hybrid_model_migration.md#model-hierarchy-reflects-rest-api-structure
**Impact**: Users can only get the property following the actual model structure which matches the REST API documentation.
**Resolution**: Accept these breaking changes."},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"howtos#generate-client-libraries#08types.mdx","document_title":"Generated Types","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/08types","content":"# Generated Types
## Using `@alternateType` to Reference External Types
### Example: Referencing an External Type
# howtos#generate-client-libraries#08types.mdx

# Generated Types

## Using `@alternateType` to Reference External Types

### Example: Referencing an External Type

Suppose you want your generated client library to use a type from an external package instead of the default emitted type.
\`\`\`typespec
@alternateType(
  {
    fullyQualifiedName: "externallib.ExternalModel",
    package: "externallib",
  },
  "python"
)
model MyModel {
  prop: string;
}
\`\`\`
In this example, instead of generating `MyModel` in the Python sdk, the emitter will reference `ExternalModel` from `externallib` instead."},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"emitters#clients#introduction.mdx","document_title":"Client Emitters","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/clients/introduction","content":"# Client Emitters
## Python Client Emitter Example
### Step 2: Update Configuration
# emitters#clients#introduction.mdx

# Client Emitters

## Python Client Emitter Example

### Step 2: Update Configuration

Update your `tspconfig.yaml` file with the following configuration:
\`\`\`yaml
emit:
  - "@typespec/http-client-python"
options:
  "@typespec/http-client-python":
    emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/python"
\`\`\`"}]

This typically happens when the TypeSpec compiler cannot locate the referenced files because they are outside the main service directory.\\n\\nTo resolve this, you need to specify the additional directories containing the shared TypeSpec files in your configuration. For Azure SDK pipelines and local generation, this is done by adding an `additionalDirectories` array to your TypeSpec location configuration (often in a file like `tsp-location.yaml`).\\n\\nHere's how to fix it:\\n\\n1. Commit this change and re-run the pipeline or local generation.\\n\\nThis will ensure the TypeSpec compiler can resolve all relative imports and your Python SDK generation should succeed.\\n\\nIf you are using a different config file or tool, look for an equivalent `additionalDirectories` or import path setting.\", \"ground_truth\": \"According to error log, it seems that your typespec refer to folder outside project folder but you don't declare it in `tspconfig.yaml`. Disable one before enabling the other.\\\\n\\\\n### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)\\\\n\\\\nAdd the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`.\\\\r\\\\n2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter:\\\\r\\\\n    - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).\\\\r\\\\n    - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"@azure-typespec/http-client-csharp-mgmt\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    namespace: \\\\\\\"Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{output-dir}/{service-dir}/{namespace}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n### [OpenAPI](#tab/openapi)\\\\n\\\\nConfigure the `swagger-to-sdk` section in `readme.md`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code for your OpenAPIs:\\\\r\\\\n1. Add `azure-sdk-for-net` to the list.\\\\r\\\\n2. Add detailed settings to a separate file `readme.csharp.md` and place it in the same folder as `readme.md`.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\n\\\\n## Swagger to SDK\\\\n\\\\nThis section describes what SDK should be generated by the automatic system.\\\\r\\\\nThis is not used by Autorest itself.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n$(swagger-to-sdk)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nswagger-to-sdk:\\\\r\\\\n  - repo: azure-sdk-for-net\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## CSharp\\\\n\\\\nSee configuration in [readme.csharp.md](./readme.csharp.md)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\\r\\\\nFor more Started\\\\n# dev#ai#typespec_generation.md\\\\n\\\\n# TypeSpec SDK Generation - Getting Started\\\\n\\\\nGenerate Azure SDK for Python from TypeSpec definitions using GitHub Copilot.\\\\n\\\\n## Prerequisites\\\\n\\\\n1. **GitHub CLI authentication**: Run `gh auth login`\\\\r\\\\n2. **Feature branch**: Create a new branch with `git checkout -b \\\\u003cbranch-name\\\\u003e`\\\\r\\\\n3. **Python environment**: Ensure `uv` package manager is installed\\\\n\\\\n## Quick Start\\\\n\\\\n### 1. Initiate Generation\\\\n\\\\nIn Copilot **Agent** mode, use one of these prompts:\\\\r\\\\n- `\\\\\\\"Generate a Python SDK using TypeSpec\\\\\\\"`\\\\r\\\\n- `\\\\\\\"Start TypeSpec SDK generation for Python\\\\\\\"`\\\\r\\\\n- `\\\\\\\"Generate SDK from tspconfig.yaml at \\\\u003cpath\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"`\\\\n\\\\n### 2. Follow Copilot's Workflow\\\\n\\\\nCopilot will automatically:\\\\r\\\\n1. **Verify environment** - Check dependencies and virtual environment\\\\r\\\\n2. **Generate SDK** - Run TypeSpec generation (~5-6 minutes)\\\\r\\\\n3. **Validate code** - Run Pylint, MyPy, Pyright, Verifytypes, Sphinx, Mindependency, Bandit, Black, Samples, Breaking changes (~3-5 minutes each)\\\\r\\\\n4. **Update docs** - Create/update CHANGELOG.md and version files\\\\r\\\\n5. **Commit changes** - Add, commit, and push to your branch\\\\r\\\\n6. **Create PR** - Generate pull request in draft mode\\\\r\\\\n7. **Handoff** - Provide PR link for azure-rest-api-specs agent\\\\n\\\\n### 3. Your Actions\\\\n\\\\n- Provide file paths when requested\\\\r\\\\n- Review and approve code changes\\\\r\\\\n- Confirm commit messages\\\\r\\\\n- Review PR title and description\\\\n\\\\n## Expected Timeline\\\\n\\\\n- **Total time**: 10-15 minutes\\\\r\\\\n- **SDK Generation**: 5-6 minutes\\\\r\\\\n- **Validation**: 3-5 minutes per step\\\\r\\\\n- **Documentation**: 2-4 minutes\\\\n\\\\n## Library Health Check\\\\n\\\\nCheck a library's release readiness:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nWhat is the health status of azure-ai-projects?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis reports the library's status from [aka.ms/azsdk/python/health](https://www.aka.ms/azsdk/python/health) and identifies any release blockers.\\\\n\\\\n## Next Steps\\\\n\\\\nAfter PR creation, use the **azure-rest-api-specs agent** with your PR link to complete the release process.\\\\n\\\\n## Useful Prompts\\\\n\\\\n### Starting SDK Generation\\\\n\\\\n**Basic generation:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"Generate a Python SDK using TypeSpec\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"Start TypeSpec SDK generation workflow\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**With local TypeSpec project:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"Generate SDK from my local TypeSpec project at sdk/cognitiveservices/azure-ai-projects\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"I have a tspconfig.yaml at [path], generate the Python SDK\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**With remote TypeSpec:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"Generate SDK from TypeSpec at https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/ai/Azure.AI.Projects/tspconfig.yaml\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Validation and Fixes\\\\n\\\\n**Fix all validation steps and fix any issues\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Check specific validations:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"Run only pylint validation\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"Check if my SDK passes pyright validation\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Documentation and Release\\\\n\\\\n**Update documentation:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"Update the CHANGELOG.md for my new SDK\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"Set the correct version in _version.py\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Commit and PR:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"Commit my changes and create a pull documentation](./emitter.md)\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Configuration\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/configuration/configuration\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Configuration\\\\n## Configuration file\\\\n# handbook#configuration#configuration.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Configuration\\\\n\\\\n## Configuration file\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec configuration can be provided via the `tspconfig.yaml` configuration file.\\\\n\\\\n### Discovery\\\\n\\\\nThe TypeSpec compiler will look for the closest `tspconfig.yaml` file located in the same directory or closest parent directory from the TypeSpec entrypoint.\\\\r\\\\nFor example if running `tsp compile /dev/foo/bar/main.tsp`, the compiler will lookup the file at the folllowing paths (in order):\\\\r\\\\n- `/dev/foo/bar/tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `/dev/foo/tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `/dev/tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n- `/tspconfig.yaml`\\\\n\\\\n### Schema\\\\n\\\\nThe file is a `yaml` document with the following structure. See the [next section](#typespec-configuration-options) for details on each option.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\nmodel TypeSpecProjectSchema {\\\\r\\\\n  extends?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  parameters?: Record\\\\u003c{default: string}\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  `environment-variables`?: Record\\\\u003c{default: string}\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n  `warn-as-error`?: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n  `output-dir`?: string;\\\\r\\\\n  `trace`?: string | string[];\\\\r\\\\n  imports?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  emit?: string[];\\\\r\\\\n  `dry-run`?: boolean;\\\\r\\\\n  options?: Record\\\\u003cunknown\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  linter?: LinterConfig;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\nmodel LinterConfig {\\\\r\\\\n  extends?: RuleRef[];\\\\r\\\\n  enable?: Record\\\\u003cRuleRef, boolean\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n  disable?: Record\\\\u003cRuleRef, string\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Extending Project Files\\\\n\\\\nThere may be instances where you want to build different folders with varying options (such as different emitters), but still want to share some common configurations.\\\\r\\\\nIn such cases, you can use the `extends` property in the configuration file.\\\\r\\\\nFor instance, in `\\\\u003cmy-pkg\\\\u003e/tspconfig.yaml`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\r\\\\n    some-option: my-name\\\\r\\\\n  emitter2:\\\\r\\\\n    some-other-option: This is a title\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nin `\\\\u003cmy-pkg\\\\u003e/proj2/tspconfig.yaml`, enable `emitter1` using the options specified in the parent `tspconfig.yaml`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=proj2/tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nextends: ../tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter1\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### What gets extended\\\\r\\\\nThe extending logic follows these rules:\\\\r\\\\n- **Root-level properties**: Shallow merge for all properties except `options`\\\\r\\\\n- **Options property**: Deep merge at one level (per emitter)\\\\r\\\\n- **Override behavior**: Properties specified in the extending file will completely override those from the extended file\\\\r\\\\n**Root-level merge behavior:**\\\\r\\\\nWhen extending a configuration, most properties (like `emit`, `imports`, `trace`, etc.) are merged at the root level. If the same property exists in both files, the extending file's value completely replaces the extended file's value.\\\\r\\\\n**Options merge behavior:**\\\\r\\\\nThe `options` property receives special treatment with a one-level deep merge:\\\\r\\\\n- Different emitters from both files are combined\\\\r\\\\n- If the same emitter is configured in both files, the extending file's emitter configuration completely overrides the extended file's configuration for that emitter\\\\r\\\\n- Individual emitter options are not merged - it's all or nothing per emitter\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n// Base config (parent/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter1\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\r\\\\n    option-a: value-a\\\\r\\\\n    option-b: value-b\\\\r\\\\n  emitter2:\\\\r\\\\n    option-x: value-x\\\\r\\\\n// Extending config (child/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nextends: ../tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter3  # Completely replaces the emit array\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\n\\\\ncompletely overrides the extended file's configuration for that emitter\\\\r\\\\n- Individual emitter options are not merged - it's all or nothing per emitter\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n// Base config (parent/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter1\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:\\\\r\\\\n    option-a: value-a\\\\r\\\\n    option-b: value-b\\\\r\\\\n  emitter2:\\\\r\\\\n    option-x: value-x\\\\r\\\\n// Extending config (child/tspconfig.yaml)\\\\r\\\\nextends: ../tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - emitter3  # Completely replaces the emit array\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter1:   # Completely replaces emitter1 options\\\\r\\\\n    option-c: value-c\\\\r\\\\n  emitter3:   # Added alongside emitter2 from parent\\\\r\\\\n    option-y: value-y\\\\r\\\\n// Resulting merged config:\\\\r\\\\n// emit: [emitter3]  # Only emitter3, emitter1 is gone\\\\r\\\\n// options:\\\\r\\\\n//   emitter1: { option-c: value-c }  # Only option-c, option-a and option-b are gone\\\\r\\\\n//   emitter2: { option-x: value-x }  # Inherited from parent\\\\r\\\\n//   emitter3: { option-y: value-y }  # From extending config\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n### Variable interpolation\\\\n\\\\nThe TypeSpec project file provides variable interpolation using:\\\\r\\\\n- built-in variables\\\\r\\\\n- environment variables\\\\r\\\\n- config file parameters\\\\r\\\\n- emitter options can reference each other\\\\r\\\\nVariable interpolation is done using an variable expression surrounded by `{` and `}`. (`{\\\\u003cexpression\\\\u003e}`)\\\\r\\\\nExamples:\\\\r\\\\n- `{output-dir}/my-path`\\\\r\\\\n- `{env.SHARED_PATH}/my-path`\\\\n\\\\n### Interpolation of Emitter Path Config\\\\n\\\\nemitter                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name`             | service name             | Name of the service                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name-if-multiple` | service name if multiple | Name of the service if multiple, undefined if one                                    |\\\\r\\\\n#### Project Parameters\\\\r\\\\nA TypeSpec project file can define certain parameters that can subsequently be specified through the CLI.\\\\r\\\\nParameters can be organized in a nested structure, to access different levels of the structure, use dots (`.`) in the variable expression.\\\\r\\\\nTherefore, parameter names should not contain `.` in their name.\\\\r\\\\nThe `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be utilized in the default value of these parameters.\\\\r\\\\nThese parameters can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression.\\\\r\\\\nAll parameters must have a default value.\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nparameters:\\\\r\\\\n  base-dir:\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"{cwd}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {base-dir}/output\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe parameter can then be specified via `--arg` in this format `--arg \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cparameter-name\\\\u003e=\\\\u003cvalue\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"` and for nested structures `--arg \\\\\\\"\\\\u003cparameter-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003cnested-parameter-name\\\\u003e=\\\\u003cvalue\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\ntsp compile . --arg \\\\\\\"base-dir=/path/to/base\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Environment variables\\\\r\\\\nA TypeSpec project file can specify which environment variables it can interpolate.\\\\r\\\\nThe `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be used in the default value of these environment variables.\\\\r\\\\nThese environment variables can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression, using the `env.` prefix.\\\\r\\\\nAll environment variables must have a default value.\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nenvironment-variables:\\\\r\\\\n  BASE_DIR:\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"{cwd}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {env.BASE_DIR}/output\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Emitter Options\\\\n\\\\nCertain emitter configurations can be interpolated using a specific rule designed to collapse a path.\\\\r\\\\nIf a variable is succeeded by a `/` or `.` and the emitter responsible for interpolating the config doesn't supply that variable, the path segment will be omitted.\\\\r\\\\nFor instance, consider the following config value: `{service-name}/output.{version}.json`\\\\r\\\\nHere's what would be produced:\\\\r\\\\n| Service name value | Version value | Result                    |\\\\r\\\\n| ------------------ | ------------- | ------------------------- |\\\\r\\\\n| `\\\\\\\"PetStore\\\\\\\"`       | `\\\\\\\"v1\\\\\\\"`        | `PetStore/output.v1.json` |\\\\r\\\\n| `\\\\\\\"PetStore\\\\\\\"`       | `undefined`   | `PetStore/output.json`    |\\\\r\\\\n#### Built-in variables\\\\r\\\\n| Variable name              | Scope                    | Description                                                                          |\\\\r\\\\n| -------------------------- | ------------------------ | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ |\\\\r\\\\n| `cwd`                      | \\\\\\\\*                       | Points to the current working directory                                              |\\\\r\\\\n| `project-root`             | \\\\\\\\*                       | Points to the the tspconfig.yaml file containing folder.                             |\\\\r\\\\n| `output-dir`               | emitter options          | Common `output-dir` See [output-dir](#output-dir---configure-the-default-output-dir) |\\\\r\\\\n| `emitter-name`             | emitter options          | Name of the emitter                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name`             | service name             | Name of the service                                                                  |\\\\r\\\\n| `service-name-if-multiple` | service name if multiple | Name of the service if multiple, undefined if one                                    |\\\\r\\\\n#### Project Parameters\\\\r\\\\nA TypeSpec project file can define certain parameters that can subsequently be specified through the CLI.\\\\n\\\\nvariables it can interpolate.\\\\r\\\\nThe `{cwd}` and `{project-root}` variables can be used in the default value of these environment variables.\\\\r\\\\nThese environment variables can then be referred to by their name in a variable interpolation expression, using the `env.` prefix.\\\\r\\\\nAll environment variables must have a default value.\\\\r\\\\n**Example:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\nenvironment-variables:\\\\r\\\\n  BASE_DIR:\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"{cwd}\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noutput-dir: {env.BASE_DIR}/output\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Emitter Options\\\\r\\\\nEmitter options can refer to each other by using the other option's name as the variable expression.\\\\r\\\\nInterpolation is only possible among emitter options from the same emitter.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  @typespec/openapi3:\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: {output-dir}/{emitter-sub-folder}\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-sub-folder: bar\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nEmitter options support a nested structure, enabling complex configurations.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml title=tspconfig.yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  emitter-sub-folder:\\\\r\\\\n    sub-folder: bar\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nTo set these values via the CLI, use dots to navigate deeper levels in the definition. `--option \\\\\\\"\\\\u003coption-name\\\\u003e.\\\\u003cnested-option-name\\\\u003e=\\\\u003cvalue\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"`\\\\r\\\\nDue to this capability, emitter option names should not contain a `.` in their name.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What is Ensure that your package.json file is correctly configured to include the necessary dependencies for running the emitters\\\\r\\\\n2. Update the tspconfig.yaml file for properly configured for the language-specific emitter.\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\n   emit:\\\\r\\\\n     - \\\\\\\"@typespec/http-client-csharp\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n     - \\\\\\\"@typespec/http-client-java\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n     - \\\\\\\"@typespec/http-client-python\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n     - \\\\\\\"@typespec/http-client-js\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n   options:\\\\r\\\\n     \\\\\\\"@typespec/http-client-csharp\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n       emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{project-root}/clients/dotnet\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n     \\\\\\\"@typespec/http-client-java\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n       emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{project-root}/clients/java\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n     \\\\\\\"@typespec/http-client-python\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n       emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{project-root}/clients/python\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n     \\\\\\\"@typespec/http-client-js\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n       emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{project-root}/clients/javascript\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n3. Once the package.json and tspconfig.yaml files are updated, you need to install all required dependencies by running the following command in the project root:\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\n   tsp install\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n4. Run the emitter to compile your TypeScript code into the desired language. Use the following command to trigger the emitter and compile your project:\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\n   tsp compile {path to main.tsp}/main.tsp\\\\r\\\\n   \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/Steps\\\\u003e\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_sdk_for_python_wiki\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Prerequisites\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/wiki/Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Prerequisites\\\\n## How to generate SDK code with Dataplane Codegen\\\\n### 1. Configure python emitter in tspconfig.yaml\\\\n# Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start.md\\\\n\\\\n# Prerequisites\\\\n\\\\n## How to generate SDK code with Dataplane Codegen\\\\n\\\\n### 1. Configure python emitter in tspconfig.yaml\\\\n\\\\nIn `rest repo`, there shall be `tspconfig.yaml` where `main.tsp` of your service is. Make sure there are configuration for Python SDK like:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nparameters:\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"service-dir\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    default: \\\\\\\"YOUR-SERVICE-DIRECTORY\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\nemit: [\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-autorest\\\\\\\", // this value does not affect python code generation\\\\r\\\\n]\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-python\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    emitter-output-dir: \\\\\\\"{output-dir}/{service-dir}/YOUR-PACKAGE-DIR\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    namespace: \\\\\\\"YOUR.NAMESPACE.NAME\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    flavor: \\\\\\\"azure\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n`YOUR.NAMESPACE.NAME` is your namespace name; `YOUR-PACKAGE-DIR` is your package directory; `YOUR-SERVICE-DIRECTORY` is SDK directory name. For example, assume that namespace is \\\\\\\"azure.ai.anomalydetector\\\\\\\" and you want to put it in folder \\\\\\\"azure-sdk-for-python/sdk/anomalydetector\\\\\\\", then \\\\\\\"YOUR.NAMESPACE.NAME\\\\\\\" is \\\\\\\"azure.ai.anomalydetector\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"YOUR_PACKAGE_DIR\\\\\\\" is \\\\\\\"azure-ai-anomalydetector\\\\\\\" and \\\\\\\"YOUR-SERVICE-DIRECTORY\\\\\\\" is \\\\\\\"sdk/anomalydetector\\\\\\\"\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_sdk_for_python_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"dev#mgmt#sdk-breaking-changes-guide.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Python SDK Breaking Changes Review and Resolution Guide for TypeSpec Migration\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/sdk-breaking-changes-guide.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure Python SDK Breaking Changes Review and Resolution Guide for TypeSpec Migration\\\\n# dev#mgmt#sdk-breaking-changes-guide.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure Python SDK Breaking Changes Review and Resolution Guide for TypeSpec Migration\\\\n\\\\nThe Azure Python SDK generally prohibits breaking changes unless they result from service behavior modifications. This guide helps you identify, review, and resolve breaking changes that may occur in new SDK versions due to migration of service specifications from Swagger to TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\nBreaking changes can be resolved by:\\\\r\\\\n1. Client Customizations\\\\r\\\\nClient customizations should be implemented in a file named `client.tsp` located in the service's specification directory alongside the main entry point `main.tsp`. This `client.tsp` becomes the new specification entry point, so import `main.tsp` in the `client.tsp` file. **Do not** import `client.tsp` in the `main.tsp` file.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"./main.tsp\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nimport \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-core\\\\\\\";\\\\r\\\\nusing Azure.ClientGenerator.Core;\\\\r\\\\n// Add your customizations here\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n2. TypeSpec Configuration Changes\\\\r\\\\nTypeSpec configuration changes should be made in the `tspconfig.yaml` file located in the service's specification directory. This file is used to configure the TypeSpec compiler and client generator options. For example:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-python\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## 1. Naming Changes with Numbers\\\\n\\\\n**Changelog Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nPaired removal and addition entries showing naming changes from words to numbers:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`md\\\\r\\\\n- Enum `Minute` deleted or renamed its member `ZERO`\\\\r\\\\n- Enum `Minute` deleted or renamed its member `THIRTY`\\\\r\\\\n- Enum `Minute` added member `ENUM_0`\\\\r\\\\n- Enum `Minute` added member `ENUM_30`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Reason**: Swagger automatically converts numeric names to words during code generation, while TypeSpec preserves the original naming. This affects all type names, including enums, models, and operations.\\\\r\\\\n**Spec Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nFind the type definition by examining the names from the addition entries in the changelog (pattern: `Enum '\\\\u003ctype name\\\\u003e' added member xxx`):\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nunion Minute {\\\\r\\\\n  int32,\\\\r\\\\n  `0`: 0,\\\\r\\\\n  `30`: 30,\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Resolution**:\\\\r\\\\nUse client customization to restore the original names from the removal entries:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(Minute.`0`, \\\\\\\"ZERO\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(Minute.`30`, \\\\\\\"THIRTY\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## 2. Operation Naming Changes\\\\n\\\\n**Changelog Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nRemoval of an operation and addition of a similarly named operation for the same operation group:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`md\\\\r\\\\n- Added operation StorageTaskAssignmentOperations.storage_task_assignment_list\\\\r\\\\n- Removed operation StorageTaskAssignmentOperations.list\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Reason**: TypeSpec may generate different operation names than Swagger to avoid naming collisions.\\\\r\\\\n**Spec Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nLocate the interface and operation using the name from the addition entries.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\ninterface StorageTaskAssignment {\\\\r\\\\n  op storageTaskAssignmentList(xxx): xxx;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Resolution**:\\\\r\\\\nUse client naming to restore the original operation name from the removal entries:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(StorageTaskAssignment.storageTaskAssignmentList, \\\\\\\"list\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## 3. Naming Changes from Directive\\\\n\\\\n**Changelog Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nPaired removal and addition entries showing naming changes for structs:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`md\\\\r\\\\n- Added model `RedisResource`\\\\r\\\\n- Deleted or renamed model `ResourceInfo`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAlso, in the legacy config for swagger under the spec folder: `specification/\\\\u003cservice\\\\u003e/resource-manager/readme.python.md`, the renaming directives could be found:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`md\\\\r\\\\ndirective:\\\\r\\\\n- rename-model:\\\\r\\\\n  from: 'RedisResource'\\\\r\\\\n  to: 'ResourceInfo'\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Reason**: Swagger has directive ways to change the naming.\\\\r\\\\n**Spec Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nFind the type definition by examining the names from the addition entries in the changelog (pattern: `Added model '\\\\u003ctype name\\\\u003e'`):\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nmodel RedisResource {\\\\r\\\\n  ...\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Resolution**:\\\\r\\\\nUse client customization to do the same renaming as the directives in the legacy config:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(RedisResource, \\\\\\\"ResourceInfo\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## 4. Client Naming Changes\\\\n\\\\n**Changelog Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nRemoval entry showing naming change of the client:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`md\\\\r\\\\n- Deleted or renamed client `IotDpsClient`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Reason**: TypeSpec generates client names based on the `namespace` name rather than the title annotation in the `@service` decorator.\\\\r\\\\n**Spec Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nFind the name from namespace:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@service(#{ title: \\\\\\\"iotDpsClient\\\\\\\" })\\\\r\\\\nnamespace Microsoft.Devices;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Resolution**:\\\\r\\\\nUpdate it to the correct client name using `@@clientName`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@@clientName(Microsoft.Devices, \\\\\\\"IotDpsClient\\\\\\\", \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\");\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## 5. Reorder of Parameters\\\\n\\\\nEntry showing the parameters get re-ordered for an operation:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`md\\\\r\\\\n- Method `IotDpsResourceOperations.get` re-ordered its parameters from `['self', 'provisioning_service_name', 'resource_group_name', 'kwargs']` to `['self', 'resource_group_name', 'provisioning_service_name', 'kwargs']`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Reason**: TypeSpec generally uses generic to generate operations. An unified parameters' order will be widely shared in one operation group, and may make difference comparing to what defined in swagger.\\\\r\\\\n**Spec Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nOperation extends parameters from type `ProvisioningServiceDescription`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\n@armResourceOperations\\\\r\\\\ninterface ProvisioningServiceDescriptions {\\\\r\\\\n  get is ArmResourceRead\\\\u003cProvisioningServiceDescription, Error = ErrorDetails\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Resolution**:\\\\r\\\\nOverride the operation by a customized one with a manually designed order of parameters:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`tsp\\\\r\\\\nop IotDpsResourceGetCustomized(\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  provider: \\\\\\\"Microsoft.ThisWillBeReplaced\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n  @path\\\\r\\\\n  provisioningServiceName: string,\\\\r\\\\n  ...Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.ResourceGroupNameParameter,\\\\r\\\\n): ProvisioningServiceDescription;\\\\r\\\\n@@override(ProvisioningServiceDescriptions.get,\\\\r\\\\n  IotDpsResourceGetCustomized,\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"python\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n);\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\n## 6. Common Types Upgrade\\\\n\\\\n**Changelog Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nMultiple changes related to common infrastructure types such as `SystemData` and `IdentityType`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`md\\\\r\\\\n- Deleted or renamed model `IdentityType`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Reason**: Common types are upgraded to their latest versions during TypeSpec migration.\\\\r\\\\n**Impact**: Low impact since these are common infrastructure types rarely used directly by users.\\\\r\\\\n**Resolution**: Accept these breaking changes.\\\\n\\\\n## 7. Removal of Unreferenced Models\\\\n\\\\n**Changelog Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nMultiple removals of unreferenced models that are typically not used in the SDK:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`md\\\\r\\\\n- Deleted or renamed model `ProxyResourceWithoutSystemData`\\\\r\\\\n- Deleted or renamed model `Resource`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Reason**: Unreferenced models are removed during TypeSpec migration.\\\\r\\\\n**Impact**: Low impact since these models are typically not used directly by users.\\\\r\\\\n**Resolution**: Accept these breaking changes.\\\\n\\\\n## 8. Removal of Pageable Models\\\\n\\\\n**Changelog Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nMultiple removals of models following the pattern `xxxList`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`md\\\\r\\\\n- Deleted or renamed model `ElasticSanList`\\\\r\\\\n- Deleted or renamed model `SkuInformationList`\\\\r\\\\n- Deleted or renamed model `SnapshotList`\\\\r\\\\n- Deleted or renamed model `VolumeGroupList`\\\\r\\\\n- Deleted or renamed model `VolumeList`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Reason**: Python will not expose pageable models for list APIs.\\\\r\\\\n**Impact**: Low impact since these models are typically not used directly by users.\\\\r\\\\n**Resolution**: Accept these breaking changes.\\\\n\\\\n## 9. Parameters Changed to Keyword-only\\\\n\\\\n**Changelog Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nEntries showing the usage of passing parameters positionally is disabled:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`md\\\\r\\\\n- Method `DpsCertificateOperations.delete` changed its parameter `certificate_name1` from `positional_or_keyword` to `keyword_only`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Reason**: Query and header parameters in operation methods have been changed from positional to keyword-only by the new operation design.\\\\r\\\\n**Impact**: Users should convert all positional parameters to keyword arguments\\\\r\\\\n**Resolution**: Accept these breaking changes.\\\\n\\\\n## 10. Removal of Parameter `if_match`\\\\n\\\\n**Changelog Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nRemoval of parameter `if_match` and addition of `etag/match_condition` for the same operation:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`md\\\\r\\\\n- Model `DpsCertificateOperations` added parameter `etag` in method `create_or_update`\\\\r\\\\n- Model `DpsCertificateOperations` added parameter `match_condition` in method `create_or_update`\\\\r\\\\n- Method `DpsCertificateOperations.create_or_update` deleted or renamed its parameter `if_match` of kind `positional_or_keyword`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Reason**: Header signatures `if_match/if_none_match` is replaced by `etag/match_condition` by the new operation design.\\\\r\\\\n**Impact**: Replace `if_match=\\\\\\\"\\\\u003cspecific etag\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"` with `etag=\\\\\\\"\\\\u003cspecific etag\\\\u003e\\\\\\\", match_condition=MatchConditions.IfNotModified`.\\\\r\\\\n**Resolution**: Accept these breaking changes.\\\\n\\\\n## 11. Removal of multi-level flattened properties\\\\n\\\\n**Changelog Pattern**:\\\\r\\\\nRemoval of multiple parameters and addition of parameters `properties` entries for the same model:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`md\\\\r\\\\n- Model `VaultExtendedInfoResource` added property `properties`\\\\r\\\\n- Model `VaultExtendedInfoResource` deleted or renamed its instance variable `integrity_key`\\\\r\\\\n- Model `VaultExtendedInfoResource` deleted or renamed its instance variable `encryption_key`\\\\r\\\\n- Model `VaultExtendedInfoResource` deleted or renamed its instance variable `encryption_key_thumbprint`\\\\r\\\\n- Model `VaultExtendedInfoResource` deleted or renamed its instance variable `algorithm`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Reason**: Typespec no longer supports multi-level flattening and will always preserve the actual REST API hierarchy. For more detailed information about model hierarchy, please refer to https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/hybrid_model_migration.md#model-hierarchy-reflects-rest-api-structure\\\\r\\\\n**Impact**: Users can only get the property following the actual model structure which matches the REST API documentation.\\\\r\\\\n**Resolution**: Accept these breaking rows.inputs.query:
title: MS Learning Documentation Categorization as "Unknown"

question: I've released the preview version of azure-ai-transcription (v1.0.0b1), but the documentation is appearing under the "unknown" folder on Microsoft Learn instead of the cognitive-services category.
During the documentation build, the warning shows:
```
The service of package: cognitiveservices
```
Can someone help take a look of this issue? Does it require register this package in the metadata CSV with MSDocService: cognitive-services so the documentation appears in the correct location on Microsoft Learn?
Here is the release [pipeline link: Pipelines - Run 20251203.2](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build/results?buildId=5633753&view=results)
Here is MS learning link: [Azure AI Speech Transcription client library for Python | Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/python/api/overview/azure/ai-transcription-readme?view=azure-python-preview)
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
Yes, to ensure the documentation for azure-ai-transcription appears under the "cognitive-services" category on Microsoft Learn, you need to add or update the metadata for this package in the metadata CSV file located at https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/_data/releases/latest/python-packages.csv.
Specifically, you should:
1. Find (or add) the row for azure-ai-transcription in python-packages.csv.
2. Set the MSDocService field to "cognitive-services". This value is used to correctly categorize the package in the Learn docs hierarchy.
3. Ensure other relevant fields (ServiceName, DisplayName, Type, etc.) are filled in appropriately.
After updating the CSV, commit and create a PR in the azure-sdk repo. Once merged, the next docs build will pick up the new metadata and your package will be categorized correctly.
If the Notes field for your package is set to "Needs Review", update it to another value to avoid automation overwriting your changes.
References and field details can be found here:
- [CSV field README](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields)
- [Relevant CSV file for Python packages](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/_data/releases/latest/python-packages.csv)
In summary: Yes, registering your package in the metadata CSV with MSDocService: cognitive-services is required. This action will resolve the warning and correct the Learn categorization.
**References**
[Publish SDK reference docs / Onboard a released package | Azure-sdk-docs-eng](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-docs)
[Metadata CSV update process for Python | Azure Sdk For Python Docs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/deprecation_process.md)
rows.inputs.response:
Yes, to ensure your package documentation appears under the correct 'cognitive-services' category on Microsoft Learn, you must register the package in the metadata CSV with the correct MSDocService value. Specifically, in the metadata CSV (located at _data/releases/latest/python-packages.csv), set the MSDocService field to 'cognitive-services' for your package. This field is used to ensure the correct metadata for the docs site and controls the categorization in the documentation table of contents. If MSDocService is missing or incorrect, your package will appear under 'unknown'.

After updating the CSV, run the documentation automation again to propagate the changes. If the Notes field for your package says 'Needs Review', update it to something else to prevent automation from overwriting your changes. Once the metadata is correct and the automation job completes, your documentation should appear under the correct category.

In summary: Yes, you need to update the metadata CSV for your package and set MSDocService: cognitive-services.

A few notes: - First release should always use 1.0.0b1, unless asked explicitly by service team - If a version is 2.1.0: - Next preview breaking is 2.2.0b1 - Next stable breaking is 3.0.0 - Next preview feature is 2.2.0b1 - Next stable feature is 2.2.0 - Next patch is 2.1.1"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_migration_docs","document_filename":"typespec-migration-docs-2025-09-12.md","document_title":"missing externalDocs","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange","content":"# missing externalDocs ## answer # typespec-migration-docs-2025-09-12.md # missing externalDocs ## question how to resolve missing externalDocs? ## answer *.tsp files: Added @externalDocs decorators to multiple interfaces and operations such as ```diff + @externalDocs("https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/consumption/") get is Extension.Read; ``` generated openapi.json file: ```diff "description": "Gets the budget for the scope by budget name.", + "externalDocs": { + "url": "https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/consumption/" + }, ```"},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"standard-library#built-in-decorators.md","document_title":"Built-in Decorators","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-decorators","content":"# Built-in Decorators ## TypeSpec ### `@doc` {#@doc} # standard-library#built-in-decorators.md # Built-in Decorators ## TypeSpec ### `@doc` {#@doc} Attach a documentation string. Content support CommonMark markdown formatting. \`\`\`typespec @doc(doc: valueof string, formatArgs?: {}) \`\`\` #### Target `unknown` #### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | |------|------|-------------| | doc | [valueof `string`](#string) | Documentation string | | formatArgs | `{}` | Record with key value pair that can be interpolated in the doc. | #### Examples \`\`\`typespec @doc("Represent a Pet available in the PetStore") model Pet {} \`\`\`"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"libraries#azure-core#rules#no-openapi.md","document_title":"no-openapi","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/azure-core/rules/no-openapi","content":"# no-openapi # libraries#azure-core#rules#no-openapi.md # no-openapi \`\`\`text title="Full name" @azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi \`\`\` Azure services should not be using decorators from the OpenAPIs libraries(`@azure-tools/openapi`, `@azure-tools/typespec-autorest` or `@azure-tools/openapi3`) in their spec. Using those decorators is usually a sign that the spec is either not following the correct Azure or trying to match exactly a particular OpenAPI spec which should be a non-goal. Those decorators are only meant to be read by the openapi emitters which means this might achieve the correct OpenAPI output but other emitters(client SDK, service, etc.) will not be able to understand them and will see a broken representation of the spec. ## Decorators and their alternatives | OpenAPI Decorator | Alternative | | ------------------------------------ | --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | | `@example` | [See examples doc](../../../migrate-swagger/faq/x-ms-examples.mdx) | | `@extension("x-ms-examples", ` | [See examples doc](../../../migrate-swagger/faq/x-ms-examples.mdx) | | `@extension("x-ms-client-flatten", ` | Use [`@flattenProperty`](../../typespec-client-generator-core/reference/decorators.md#@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.flattenProperty) | | `@extension("x-ms-mutability", ` | Use [`@visibility` decorator](https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-decorators#@visibility) | | `@extension("x-ms-enum", ` | [Enum extensibility doc](../../../troubleshoot/enum-not-extensible.md) | | `@extension("x-ms-identifiers", ` | Use [`@identifiers`](../../azure-resource-manager/reference/decorators.md#@Azure.ResourceManager.identifiers) | | `@operationId` | Name your interface and operation accordingly | | `@useRef` | This should not be used, define the types correctly in TypeSpec. For ARM common types read the [Arm docs](../../.. | | `@operationId` | Name your interface and operation accordingly | | `@useRef` | This should not be used, define the types correctly in TypeSpec. For ARM common types read the [Arm docs](../../../getstarted/azure-resource-manager/step00.md) | | `@info` | Use versioning library for `version` and `@service` for title | ## Examples ### `@extension("x-ms-enum"` #### âŒ Incorrect \`\`\`tsp @extension( "x-ms-enum", { name: "PetKind", modelAsString: true, } ) enum PetKind { Cat, Dog, } \`\`\` #### âœ… Correct \`\`\`tsp union PetKind { Cat: "Cat", Dog: "Dog", string, } \`\`\` ### `@extension("x-ms-mutability"` #### âŒ Incorrect \`\`\`tsp model Pet { @extension("x-ms-mutability", #["read", "create"]) name: string; } \`\`\` ### `@extension("x-ms-identifiers"` #### âŒ Incorrect \`\`\`tsp model Pet { @extension("x-ms-identifiers", #["customId"]) names: Name[]; } model Name { customId: string; } \`\`\` #### âœ… Correct \`\`\`tsp model Pet { @identifiers(#["customId"]) names: Name[]; } model Name { customId: string; } \`\`\` ### `@operationId` #### âŒ Incorrect \`\`\`tsp @operationId("Pet_Get") op getPet(): Pet; \`\`\` #### âœ… Correct \`\`\`tsp interface Pet { get(): Pet; } \`\`\`"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Folder-Structure.md","document_title":"Overview","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Folder-Structure","content":"# Overview # Folder-Structure.md # Overview Specifications in this repository must organize their files and folders according to strict guidelines. In June 2025, the guidelines were updated to version 2. New specs are encouraged to start with v2, and existing specs are encouraged to convert to v2 when convenient. The [widget](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification/widget) sample uses v2. Prior to June 2025, all specs were using v1. The [contosowidgetmanager](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager) sample uses v1."},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_10_17.md","document_title":"Unknown decorator @flattenProperty","document_link":"","content":"# Unknown decorator @flattenProperty ## answer # typespec_2025_10_17.md # Unknown decorator @flattenProperty ## question I'm getting the below errors and something like this, which I had never run into before. error invalid-ref: Unknown decorator @flattenProperty ``` https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37909 ## answer your release branch has fallen far behind main. it will need to be updated or recreated. you can try this, but if your release branch is too old, it will likely need to be recreated https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish#update-your-branch-with-changes-from-main"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-internal-wiki","document_filename":"Engineering-System#Testing-Guidelines.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki?wikiVersion=GBwikiMaster&pagePath=/Engineering-System/Testing-Guidelines","content":"[[_TOC_]]"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-internal-wiki","document_filename":"Engineering-System#Pipelines#Azure-DevOps-Pipeline-Guidance.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki?wikiVersion=GBwikiMaster&pagePath=/Engineering-System/Pipelines/Azure-DevOps-Pipeline-Guidance","content":"[[_TOC_]]"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"howtos#versioning#preview-version.md","document_title":"How to define a preview version","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/versioning/preview-version","content":"# How to define a preview version # howtos#versioning#preview-version.md # How to define a preview version See [`@typespec/versioning` documentation](https://typespec.io/docs/libraries/versioning/guide) for the general versioning concept. This guide expands on how Azure Services should define Preview versions. ## Preview Versioning Rules - Always make the last enum the preview and apply `@previewVersion` to it. - Apply `@added(Versions.PreviewVersion)` to all preview items - these items will not show up in any GA Version - For a new GA, add a new version enum **BEFORE** the preview enum value. Manually change all **preview** items that are GA'ing so that the `@added` version value matches the new GA enum value - For any items remaining in **preview**, rename the **old preview** enum value to the **new preview** enum value. ## Usage Examples ### New preview Version In the following example we introduce a new preview version called `v3Preview` which includes everything from `v2` plus adds a new property to the `Widget` resource. \`\`\`diff lang=tsp import "@typespec/http"; import "@typespec/rest"; import "@typespec/versioning"; import "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core"; using Http; using Rest; using Versioning; using Azure.Core; @versioned(Versions) @service(#{ title: "Widget Service" }) namespace DemoService; enum Versions { v1, v2, + @previewVersion + v3Preview } /** * Model defining the Widget resource */ model Widget { /** * Identifier of the Widget Resource */ @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) @key id: string; /** * Weight of the widget */ weight: int32; /** * Color of the widget; */ color: "red" | "blue"; /** * Nickname of the Widget resource */ + @added(Versions.v3Preview) nickname: string; } \`\`\` ### Adding a new stable (GA) version This example builds on the previous one, where `v3` is introduced which GA's the `nickname` property introduced in `v3Preview` \`\`\`diff lang=tsp import "@typespec/http"; import "@typespec/rest"; import "@typespec/versioning"; import "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core"; using Http; using Rest; using Versioning; using Azure.Core; @versioned(Versions) @service(#{ title: "Widget Service" }) namespace DemoService; enum Versions { v1, v2, - @previewVersion - v3Preview + v3 } /** * Model defining the Widget resource */ model Widget { /** * Identifier of the Widget Resource */ @visibility(Lifecycle.Read) @key id: string; /** * Weight of the widget */ weight: int32; /** * Color of the widget; */ color: "red" | "blue"; /** * Nickname of the Widget resource */ - @added(Versions.v3Preview) nickname: string; + @added(Versions.v3) nickname: string; } \`\`\`"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_migration_docs","document_filename":"typespec-migration-docs-2025-09-12.md","document_title":"add missing location path parameter","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange","content":"# add missing location path parameter ## answer # typespec-migration-docs-2025-09-12.md # add missing location path parameter ## question here is my typespec definition: specification/appconfiguration/AppConfiguration.Management/DeletedConfigurationStore.tsp ``` /** * Deleted configuration store information with extended details. */ @subscriptionResource model DeletedConfigurationStore is Azure.ResourceManager.ProxyResource { ...ResourceNameParameter< ``` how to add missing location path parameter? ## answer "$ref": "../../../../../common-types/resource-management/v5/types.json#/parameters/LocationParameter" + }, ``` ... ```diff -
