Unfortunately there is no way to make a Pull Request to the wiki repo. 1. `git clone https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs.wiki.git` 2. Make changes 3. `git push` your changes to `master` * Branch must be named `master`, not `main`. The GitHub Wiki code appears to hardcode `origin/master` instead of using `origin/HEAD`."},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"standard-library#built-in-decorators.md","document_title":"Built-in Decorators","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-decorators","content":"# Built-in Decorators ## TypeSpec ### `@returnsDoc` {#@returnsDoc} # standard-library#built-in-decorators.md # Built-in Decorators ## TypeSpec ### `@returnsDoc` {#@returnsDoc} Attach a documentation string to describe the successful return types of an operation. If an operation returns a union of success and errors it only describes the success. See `@errorsDoc` for error documentation. \`\`\`typespec @returnsDoc(doc: valueof string) \`\`\` #### Target `Operation` #### Parameters | Name | Type | Description | |------|------|-------------| | doc | [valueof `string`](#string) | Documentation string | #### Examples \`\`\`typespec @returnsDoc("Returns doc") op get(): Pet | NotFound; \`\`\`"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#supporting-sdk-customers#codeowners.md","document_title":"PRLabel: %Your Service Label","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/supporting-sdk-customers/codeowners","content":"# PRLabel: %Your Service Label # docs#develop#supporting-sdk-customers#codeowners.md # PRLabel: %Your Service Label /sdk// @myalias @Azure/myTeam1"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-pipeline.md","document_title":"Run release SDK pipeline","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-pipeline","content":"# Run release SDK pipeline ## SDK release pipeline ### Select a release pipeline # docs#develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-pipeline.md # Run release SDK pipeline ## SDK release pipeline ### Select a release pipeline 1. Go to our [pipelines hub](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?view=pipelines&option=recent) contained within the _internal_ team project. 1. Select **All** to see all the pipelines aggregated by language folders. 1. Per language, you will need to locate and select the pipeline that is used to build your package. Pipelines are named after the language and service area that they are responsible for building and releasing. For example the _core_ libraries are named **java - core**, and the app configuration libraries are named **java - appconfiguration**. 1. If you don't find a release pipeline, you will need to create one. > [!NOTE] > In some cases where there was a pre-existing track 1 library and new track 2 libraries were introduced, > we have split the pipelines - so you may see some pipelines in the form **java - [service] - data**. > This means that the pipeline is the track 1 version of the unified pipeline. This distinction is made to optimize the > build and release process for teams doing active development on the track 2 versions of the library. #### Create a release pipeline To generate pipelines for a new service that does not yet exist on _main_, ensure that your PR contains the `ci.yml` and `tests.yml` files ([modified from the template](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki/117/Setting-up-a-new-Unified-Pipeline)) and then issue the following comment on your github pull request: \`\`\` /azp run prepare-pipelines \`\`\` This will trigger a pipeline which analyzes the state of the repo-based on your commit and generates pipelines necessary to run PR validation."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#develop#sdk-docs.md","document_title":"Publish SDK reference docs","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-docs","content":"# Publish SDK reference docs ## Onboard a released package ### Packages released through the Azure SDK engineering system # docs#develop#sdk-docs.md # Publish SDK reference docs ## Onboard a released package ### Packages released through the Azure SDK engineering system If your package is released through the Azure SDK engineering system, almost everything is automated. You'll need to take action if this is your first time releasing a package. When releasing a package for the first time: 1. Ensure that your package is tracked in the [release work items](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/Release/_queries/query/7d106acd-a1c2-47b9-9676-996422328397/). This can be done by running the [**Prepare-Release.ps1** script](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mark-release-status). In each item for your release, you should have a value for **Service Name** and **Package Display Name**. The docs table of contents is generated from this data. > [!NOTE] > Do not skip this step. If you skip the service name, your item will appear in the TOC in the **Other** > **Uncategorized** section. 1. Ensure that your package-level overview file (the README.md file for your package in the SDK source repo) is up to date *before* releasing. In general, the automated system will ensure that updated docs are onboarded within a day or two of your release. To customize information about your package outside of the engineering system consult documentation for [CSV fields](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields) and [Service Level Overview](#service-level-overview) and [Package Level Overview](#package-level-overview). #### Troubleshooting automated documentation updates An automation job runs every 2 hours during business hours on weekdays. If your data is not updated and you don't want to wait, [run the job manually](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284). This will update the metadata PR. If you find anything unexpected in the table of contents or service README, check the [metadata CSV file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/tree/main/_data/releases/latest) to ensure that the metadata is correct. If the metadata is not correct, open a PR with corrections. during business hours on weekdays. If your data is not updated and you don't want to wait, [run the job manually](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284). This will update the metadata PR. If you find anything unexpected in the table of contents or service README, check the [metadata CSV file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/tree/main/_data/releases/latest) to ensure that the metadata is correct. If the metadata is not correct, open a PR with corrections. Once merged your changes will be released on the next available documentation release. ##### Update a published Package-level Overview > [!NOTE] > For packages released using the Azure SDK EngSys, changes need to be synchronized between the source SDK repo and the docs > repo. Changes to the docs repo that are not mirrored to the source SDK repo will be overwritten by content from the source > SDK repo on the next package release. 1. Find the Package-level overview using the table from [Package-level overviews](#package-level-overviews). 2. Find the corresponding README.md file for the library in the SDK repo (e.g. [azure-sdk-for-net](https://github.com/azure/azure-sdk-for-net)). 3. Update the "front matter" date field at the beginning of the file to today's date. To update other front matter metadata, see [Ensure CSV metadata is correct](#ensure-csv-metadata-is-correct). 4. Copy changed content from step 2 into the Package-level overview from step 1. 5. Open a pull request for the update file in the docs repo"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"docs#retirement#sdk-deprecation.md","document_title":"Deprecating Azure SDKs","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/retirement/sdk-deprecation","content":"# Deprecating Azure SDKs ## Azure SDK deprecation process # docs#retirement#sdk-deprecation.md # Deprecating Azure SDKs ## Azure SDK deprecation process PowerShell terminal: \`\`\` git clone https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk.git \`\`\` - Create a branch in your local copy of our repo: \`\`\` git checkout -b package_deprecation \`\`\` - Launch VS Code and open the local repo folder: \`\`\` File -> Open Folder -> \`\`\` - Open the relevant CSV file in VS Code, located under the following directory: \`\`\` \azure-sdk\_data\releases\latest\ android-packages.csv c-packages.csv"},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_wiki","document_filename":"Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start-For-Swagger.md","document_title":"Prerequisites","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/wiki/Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start-For-Swagger","content":"# Prerequisites ## Project service name and package name # Dataplane-Codegen-Quick-Start-For-Swagger.md # Prerequisites ## Project service name and package name Two key pieces of information for your project are the `service_name` and `package_name`. The `service_name` is the short name for the Azure service. The `service_name` should match across all the SDK language repos and should be name of the directory in the specification folder of the azure-rest-api-specs repo that contains the REST API definition file. An example is Service Bus, whose API definitions are in the `specifications/servicebus` folder of the azure-rest-api-specs repo, and uses the `service_name` "servicebus". Not every service follows this convention, but it should be the standard unless there are strong reasons to deviate. In Python, a project's `package name` is the name used to publish the package in [PyPI](https://pypi.org/). For data plane libraries (management plane uses a different convention), the `package_name` could be just `azure-{service_name}`. An example is "azure-servicebus". Some services may need several different packages. For these cases a third component, the `module_name`, is added to the `package_name`, as `azure-{service_name}-{module_name}`. The `module_name` usually comes from the name of the REST API file itself or one of the directories toward the end of the file path. An example is the Synapse service, with packages `azure-synapse`, `azure-synapse-accesscontrol`, `azure-synapse-artifacts`, etc."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"deprecation_process.md","document_title":"Step 6: Update API Documentation","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/deprecation_process.md","content":"# Step 6: Update API Documentation ## Update MS Learn docs # deprecation_process.md # Step 6: Update API Documentation ## Update MS Learn docs - Create your own fork of the [azure-sdk](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk) repo and clone it, if you haven't already. - Create a branch in your local copy of the repo: `> git checkout -b python/azure-mypackage_deprecation` - Open the `_data/releases/latest/python-packages.csv` file. - If using Visual Studio Code, the `Edit CSV` extension may be helpful for editing the file. - Find the entry for your package and update the following fields. - `EOLDate`: In MM/DD/YYYY format. If the SDK deprecation is due to a service retirement, this date should match the service final retirement date. If there is a replacement package (or repo), this should match the release date of the deprecated package. - `Support`: Change the value to `deprecated`. - `Replace`: If it exists, set the value to the name of the Azure SDK for Python package meant to replace the package being deprecated. If not, set the value to `NA`. - `ReplaceGuide`: If it exists, link to a migration guide in the following format: `aka.ms/azsdk//migrate/`. If not, set the value to `NA`. - **Note: If you are deprecating multiple packages, please wait until all deprecated packages have been released and update all entries necessary in one PR.** - Create a PR to push these changes. Checks will run to notify the repo owners to review your commit. - Example PR for azure-cognitiveservices-language-spellcheck [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/pull/8012/files). - Ping Xiang Yan (xiangyan) for a review and include a link to your PR. If he is unavailable, ping Ronnie Geraghty (rgeraghty) or Wes Haggard (wesh). - Once the PR has been approved, merge. The Microsoft Learn API reference docs for your package will be updated to Legacy on the following Wednesday. Example of deprecated MS Learn API reference docs for Text Analytics [here](https://learn.microsoft.com/python/api/overview/azure/cognitiveservices-language-textanalytics-readme?view=azure-python-previous). Yan (xiangyan) for a review and include a link to your PR. If he is unavailable, ping Ronnie Geraghty (rgeraghty) or Wes Haggard (wesh). - Once the PR has been approved, merge. The Microsoft Learn API reference docs for your package will be updated to Legacy on the following Wednesday. Example of deprecated MS Learn API reference docs for Text Analytics [here](https://learn.microsoft.com/python/api/overview/azure/cognitiveservices-language-textanalytics-readme?view=azure-python-previous). More detailed instructions on updating the CSV file can be found [here](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-deprecation)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-guidelines","document_filename":"python_design.html","document_title":"Python Guidelines: API Design","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/python_design.html","content":"# Python Guidelines: API Design ## Azure SDK API Design ### Namespaces # python_design.html # Python Guidelines: API Design ## Azure SDK API Design ### Namespaces In the guidelines below, the term "namespace" is used to denote a python package or module (i.e. something that you would `import` in your code). The term "distribution package" is used to describe the artifact you publish to and install from your package manager (i.e. something that you would `pip install`). {% include requirement/MUST id="python-namespaces-prefix" %} implement your library as a sub-package of the `azure` root namespace. > Note: You MUST NOT use `microsoft` as your root namespace. If you need to include `microsoft` in the namespace (e.g. because of policy requirements for extensions to other projects such as `opentelemetry`), you should concatenate it with the package specific namespace with an underscore (e.g. `microsoft_myservice`). You may still use `microsoft-myservice` as the distribution package name in this scenario. {% include requirement/MUST id="python-namespaces-naming" %} pick a package name that allows the consumer to tie the namespace to the service being used. As a default, use the compressed service name at the end of the namespace. The namespace does NOT change when the branding of the product changes. Avoid the use of marketing names that may change. A compressed service name is the service name without spaces. It may further be shortened if the shortened version is well known in the community. For example, â€œAzure Media Analyticsâ€ would have a compressed service name of `mediaanalytics`, and â€œAzure Service Busâ€ would become `servicebus`. Separate words using an underscore if necessary. For example, `mediaanalytics` could be separated into `media_analytics` {% include requirement/MAY id="python-namespaces-grouping" %} include a group name segment in your namespace (for example, `azure..`) if your service or family of services have common behavior (for example, shared authentication types). would have a compressed service name of `mediaanalytics`, and â€œAzure Service Busâ€ would become `servicebus`. Separate words using an underscore if necessary. For example, `mediaanalytics` could be separated into `media_analytics` {% include requirement/MAY id="python-namespaces-grouping" %} include a group name segment in your namespace (for example, `azure..`) if your service or family of services have common behavior (for example, shared authentication types). {% include requirement/MUST id="python-namespaces-grouping-dont-introduce-new-packages" %} avoid introducing new distribution packages that only differ in name. For existing packages, this means that you should not change the name of the package just to introduce a group name. If you want to use a group name segment, use one of the following groups: {% include tables/data_namespaces.md %} {% include requirement/MUST id="python-namespaces-mgmt" %} place management (Azure Resource Manager) APIs in the `mgmt` group. Use the grouping `azure.mgmt.` for the namespace. Since more services require control plane APIs than data plane APIs, other namespaces may be used explicitly for control plane only. {% include requirement/MUST id="python-namespaces-register" %} register the chosen namespace with the [Architecture Board]. Open an [issue] to request the namespace. See [the registered namespace list](registered_namespaces.html) for a list of the currently registered namespaces. {% include requirement/MUST id="python-namespaces-async" %} use an `.aio` suffix added to the namespace of the sync client for async clients. Example: \`\`\`python // Yes: from azure.exampleservice.aio import ExampleServiceClient // No: Wrong namespace, wrong client name... from azure.exampleservice import AsyncExampleServiceClient \`\`\` #### Example Namespaces Here are some examples of namespaces that meet these guidelines: - `azure.storage.blob` currently registered namespaces. {% include requirement/MUST id="python-namespaces-async" %} use an `.aio` suffix added to the namespace of the sync client for async clients. Example: \`\`\`python // Yes: from azure.exampleservice.aio import ExampleServiceClient // No: Wrong namespace, wrong client name... from azure.exampleservice import AsyncExampleServiceClient \`\`\` #### Example Namespaces Here are some examples of namespaces that meet these guidelines: - `azure.storage.blob` - `azure.keyvault.certificates` - `azure.ai.textanalytics` - `azure.mgmt.servicebus`"},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"deprecation_process.md","document_title":"Step 6: Update API Documentation","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/deprecation_process.md","content":"# Step 6: Update API Documentation ## Update MS Learn docs # deprecation_process.md # Step 6: Update API Documentation ## Update MS Learn docs - Create your own fork of the [azure-sdk](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk) repo and clone it, if you haven't already. - Create a branch in your local copy of the repo: `> git checkout -b python/azure-mypackage_deprecation` - Open the `_data/releases/latest/python-packages.csv` file. - If using Visual Studio Code, the `Edit CSV` extension may be helpful for editing the file. - Find the entry for your package and update the following fields. - `EOLDate`: In MM/DD/YYYY format. If the SDK deprecation is due to a service retirement, this date should match the service final retirement date. If there is a replacement package (or repo), this should match the release date of the deprecated package. - `Support`: Change the value to `deprecated`. - `Replace`: If it exists, set the value to the name of the Azure SDK for Python package meant to replace the package being deprecated. If not, set the value to `NA`. - `ReplaceGuide`: If it exists, link to a migration guide in the following format: `aka.ms/azsdk//migrate/`. If not, set the value to `NA`. - **Note: If you are deprecating multiple packages, please wait until all deprecated packages have been released and update all entries necessary in one PR.** - Create a PR to push these changes. Checks will run to notify the repo owners to review your commit. - Example PR for azure-cognitiveservices-language-spellcheck [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/pull/8012/files). - Ping Xiang Yan (xiangyan) for a review and include a link to your PR. If he is unavailable, ping Ronnie Geraghty (rgeraghty) or Wes Haggard (wesh). - Once the PR has been approved, merge. The Microsoft Learn API reference docs for your package will be updated to Legacy on the following Wednesday. Example of deprecated MS Learn API reference docs for Text Analytics [here](https://learn.microsoft.com/python/api/overview/azure/cognitiveservices-language-textanalytics-readme?view=azure-python-previous). Yan (xiangyan) for a review and include a link to your PR. If he is unavailable, ping Ronnie Geraghty (rgeraghty) or Wes Haggard (wesh). - Once the PR has been approved, merge. The Microsoft Learn API reference docs for your package will be updated to Legacy on the following Wednesday. Example of deprecated MS Learn API reference docs for Text Analytics [here](https://learn.microsoft.com/python/api/overview/azure/cognitiveservices-language-textanalytics-readme?view=azure-python-previous). More detailed instructions on updating the CSV file can be found [here](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-deprecation)."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#packaging.md","document_title":"What do I do in my files to achieve that","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/packaging.md","content":"# What do I do in my files to achieve that # dev#packaging.md # What do I do in my files to achieve that The minimal files to have: - azure/\_\_init\_\_.py - MANIFEST.in - setup.py The file "azure/\_\_init\_\_.py" must contain exactly this: \`\`\`python __path__ = __import__('pkgutil').extend_path(__path__, __name__) \`\`\` Your MANIFEST.in must include the following line `include azure/__init__.py`. Example: \`\`\`shell include *.md include LICENSE include azure/__init__.py recursive-include tests *.py recursive-include samples *.py *.md \`\`\` In your setup.py: The "packages" section MUST EXCLUDE the `azure` package. Example: \`\`\`python packages=find_packages(exclude=[ 'tests', # Exclude packages that will be covered by PEP420 or nspkg 'azure', ]), \`\`\` Since the package is Python 3 only, you must notify it in the setup.py as well: \`\`\`python python_requires=">=3.8", \`\`\` Example of a full setup.py \`\`\`python //!/usr/bin/env python //------------------------------------------------------------------------- // Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved. // Licensed under the MIT License. See License.txt in the project root for // license information. //-------------------------------------------------------------------------- import re import os.path from io import open from setuptools import find_packages, setup // Change the PACKAGE_NAME only to change folder and different name PACKAGE_NAME = "azure-keyvault" PACKAGE_PPRINT_NAME = "KeyVault" // a-b-c => a/b/c package_folder_path = PACKAGE_NAME.replace('-', '/') // a-b-c => a.b.c namespace_name = PACKAGE_NAME.replace('-', '.') // Version extraction inspired from 'requests' with open(os.path.join(package_folder_path, 'version.py'), 'r') as fd: version = re.search(r'^VERSION\s*=\s*[\'"]([^\'"]*)[\'"]', fd.read(), re.MULTILINE).group(1) if not version: raise RuntimeError('Cannot find version information') with open('README.rst', encoding='utf-8') as f: => a/b/c package_folder_path = PACKAGE_NAME.replace('-', '/') // a-b-c => a.b.c namespace_name = PACKAGE_NAME.replace('-', '.') // Version extraction inspired from 'requests' with open(os.path.join(package_folder_path, 'version.py'), 'r') as fd: version = re.search(r'^VERSION\s*=\s*[\'"]([^\'"]*)[\'"]', fd.read(), re.MULTILINE).group(1) if not version: raise RuntimeError('Cannot find version information') with open('README.rst', encoding='utf-8') as f: readme = f.read() with open('HISTORY.rst', encoding='utf-8') as f: history = f.read() setup( name=PACKAGE_NAME, version=version, description='Microsoft Azure {} Client Library for Python'.format(PACKAGE_PPRINT_NAME), long_description=readme + '\n\n' + history, license='MIT License', author='Microsoft Corporation', author_email='azpysdkhelp@microsoft.com', url='https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python', classifiers=[ 'Development Status :: 4 - Beta', 'Programming Language :: Python', 'Programming Language :: Python :: 3 :: Only', 'Programming Language :: Python :: 3', 'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.8', 'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.9', 'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.10', 'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.11', 'Programming Language :: Python :: 3.12', 'License :: OSI Approved :: MIT License', ], python_requires=">=3.8", zip_safe=False, packages=find_packages(exclude=[ 'tests', # Exclude packages that will be covered by PEP420 or nspkg 'azure', ]), install_requires=[ 'msrest>=0.5.0', 'msrestazure>=0.4.32,<2.0.0', 'azure-common~=1.1', ], ) \`\`\` This syntax works with setuptools >= 24.2.0 (July 2016) and pip >= 9.0 (Nov 2016), which is considered enough to support in 2021. :: MIT License', ], python_requires=">=3.8", zip_safe=False, packages=find_packages(exclude=[ 'tests', # Exclude packages that will be covered by PEP420 or nspkg 'azure', ]), install_requires=[ 'msrest>=0.5.0', 'msrestazure>=0.4.32,<2.0.0', 'azure-common~=1.1', ], ) \`\`\` This syntax works with setuptools >= 24.2.0 (July 2016) and pip >= 9.0 (Nov 2016), which is considered enough to support in 2021. Since the package is Python 3 only, do NOT make this wheel universal. This usually means you should NOT have `universal=1` in the `setup.cfg`. It may mean you can completely remove the file if `universal` was the only configuration option inside."}]

rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: MS Learning Documentation Categorization as \\\"Unknown\\\"\\n\\nquestion: I've released the preview version of azure-ai-transcription (v1.0.0b1), but the documentation is appearing under the \\\"unknown\\\" folder on Microsoft Learn instead of the cognitive-services category.\\nDuring the documentation build, the warning shows:\\n```\\nThe service of package: cognitiveservices\\n```\\nCan someone help take a look of this issue? Does it require register this package in the metadata CSV with MSDocService: cognitive-services so the documentation appears in the correct location on Microsoft Learn?\\nHere is the release [pipeline link: Pipelines - Run 20251203.2](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build/results?buildId=5633753&view=results)\\nHere is MS learning link: [Azure AI Speech Transcription client library for Python | Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/python/api/overview/azure/ai-transcription-readme?view=azure-python-preview)\", \"response\": \"Yes, to ensure your package documentation appears under the correct 'cognitive-services' category on Microsoft Learn, you must register the package in the metadata CSV with the correct MSDocService value. Specifically, in the metadata CSV (located at _data/releases/latest/python-packages.csv), set the MSDocService field to 'cognitive-services' for your package. This field is used to ensure the correct metadata for the docs site and controls the categorization in the documentation table of contents. If MSDocService is missing or incorrect, your package will appear under 'unknown'.\\n\\nAfter updating the CSV, run the documentation automation again to propagate the changes. If the Notes field for your package says 'Needs Review', update it to something else to prevent automation from overwriting your changes. Once the metadata is correct and the automation job completes, your documentation should appear under the correct category.\\n\\nIn summary: Yes, you need to update the metadata CSV for your package and set MSDocService: cognitive-services.\", \"ground_truth\": \"Yes, to ensure the documentation for azure-ai-transcription appears under the \\\"cognitive-services\\\" category on Microsoft Learn, you need to add or update the metadata for this package in the metadata CSV file located at https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/_data/releases/latest/python-packages.csv.\\nSpecifically, you should:\\n1. Find (or add) the row for azure-ai-transcription in python-packages.csv.\\n2. Set the MSDocService field to \\\"cognitive-services\\\". This value is used to correctly categorize the package in the Learn docs hierarchy.\\n3. Ensure other relevant fields (ServiceName, DisplayName, Type, etc.) are filled in appropriately.\\nAfter updating the CSV, commit and create a PR in the azure-sdk repo. Once merged, the next docs build will pick up the new metadata and your package will be categorized correctly.\\nIf the Notes field for your package is set to \\\"Needs Review\\\", update it to another value to avoid automation overwriting your changes.\\nReferences and field details can be found here:\\n- [CSV field README](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields)\\n- [Relevant CSV file for Python packages](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/_data/releases/latest/python-packages.csv)\\nIn summary: Yes, registering your package in the metadata CSV with MSDocService: cognitive-services is required. This action will resolve the warning and correct the Learn categorization.\\n**References**\\n[Publish SDK reference docs / Onboard a released package | Azure-sdk-docs-eng](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-docs)\\n[Metadata CSV update process for Python | Azure Sdk For Python Docs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/deprecation_process.md)\"}"}]

If the SDK deprecation is due to a service retirement, this date should match the service final retirement date. If there is a replacement package (or repo), this should match the release date of the deprecated package.\\\\r\\\\n  - `Support`: Change the value to `deprecated`.\\\\r\\\\n  - `Replace`: If it exists, set the value to the name of the Azure SDK for Python package meant to replace the package being deprecated. If not, set the value to `NA`.\\\\r\\\\n  - `ReplaceGuide`: If it exists, link to a migration guide in the following format: `aka.ms/azsdk/\\\\u003clanguage\\\\u003e/migrate/\\\\u003clibrary\\\\u003e`. If not, set the value to `NA`.\\\\r\\\\n- **Note: If you are deprecating multiple packages, please wait until all deprecated packages have been released and update all entries necessary in one PR.**\\\\r\\\\n- Create a PR to push these changes. Checks will run to notify the repo owners to review your commit.\\\\r\\\\n  - Example PR for azure-cognitiveservices-language-spellcheck [here](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/pull/8012/files).\\\\r\\\\n- Ping Xiang Yan (xiangyan) for a review and include a link to your PR. name\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAzure services should not be using decorators from the OpenAPIs the correct Azure or trying to match exactly a particular OpenAPI spec which should be a non-goal.\\\\r\\\\nThose decorators are only meant to be read by the openapi emitters which means this might achieve the correct OpenAPI output but other emitters(client SDK, service, etc.) will not be able to understand them and will see a broken representation of the spec.\\\\n\\\\n## Decorators and their alternatives\\\\n\\\\n| OpenAPI Decorator                    | Alternative [`@identifiers`](../../azure-resource-manager/reference/decorators.md#@Azure.ResourceManager.identifiers)                                                   |\\\\r\\\\n| `@operationId` This guide expands on how Azure Services should define Preview versions.\\\\n\\\\n## Preview Versioning Rules\\\\n\\\\n- Always make the last enum the preview and apply `@previewVersion` to it.\\\\r\\\\n- Apply `@added(Versions.PreviewVersion)` to all preview items - these items will not show up in any GA Version\\\\r\\\\n- For a new GA, add a new version enum **BEFORE** the preview enum value. Manually change all **preview** items that are GA'ing so that the `@added` version value matches the new GA enum value\\\\r\\\\n- For any items remaining in **preview**, rename the **old preview** enum value to the **new preview** enum value.\\\\n\\\\n## Usage Examples\\\\n\\\\n### New preview Version\\\\n\\\\nIn the following example we introduce a new preview version called `v3Preview` which See `@errorsDoc` for error documentation.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@returnsDoc(doc: valueof string)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n#### Target\\\\r\\\\n`Operation`\\\\r\\\\n#### Parameters\\\\r\\\\n| Name | Type | Description |\\\\r\\\\n|------|------|-------------|\\\\r\\\\n| doc | [valueof `string`](#string) | Documentation string |\\\\r\\\\n#### Examples\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typespec\\\\r\\\\n@returnsDoc(\\\\\\\"Returns doc\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nop get(): Pet | NotFound;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#develop#supporting-sdk-customers#codeowners.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"PRLabel: %Your Service Label\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/supporting-sdk-customers/codeowners\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# PRLabel: %Your Service Label\\\\n# docs#develop#supporting-sdk-customers#codeowners.md\\\\n\\\\n# PRLabel: %Your Service Label\\\\n\\\\n/sdk/\\\\u003cyour-service-library-directory\\\\u003e/                    @myalias @Azure/myTeam1\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-pipeline.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Run release SDK pipeline\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-pipeline\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Run release SDK pipeline\\\\n## SDK release pipeline\\\\n### Select a release pipeline\\\\n# docs#develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-pipeline.md\\\\n\\\\n# Run release SDK pipeline\\\\n\\\\n## SDK release pipeline\\\\n\\\\n### Select a release pipeline\\\\n\\\\n1. Go to our [pipelines hub](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?view=pipelines\\\\u0026option=recent) contained\\\\r\\\\nwithin the _internal_ team project.\\\\r\\\\n1. Select **All** to see all the pipelines aggregated by language folders.\\\\r\\\\n1. Per language, you will need to locate and select the pipeline that is used to build your package.\\\\r\\\\nPipelines are named after the language and service area that they are responsible for building and releasing.\\\\r\\\\nFor example the _core_ libraries are named **java - core**, and the app configuration libraries are named **java - appconfiguration**.\\\\r\\\\n1. If you don't find a release pipeline, you will need to create one.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e [!NOTE]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e In some cases where there was a pre-existing track 1 library and new track 2 libraries were introduced,\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e we have split the pipelines - so you may see some pipelines in the form **java - [service] - data**.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e This means that the pipeline is the track 1 version of the unified pipeline. This distinction is made to optimize the\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e build and release process for teams doing active development on the track 2 versions of the library.\\\\r\\\\n#### Create a release pipeline\\\\r\\\\nTo generate pipelines for a new service that does not yet exist on _main_, ensure that your PR contains the `ci.yml` and\\\\r\\\\n`tests.yml` files ([modified from the template](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki/117/Setting-up-a-new-Unified-Pipeline))\\\\r\\\\nand then issue the following comment on your github pull request:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n/azp run prepare-pipelines\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThis will trigger a pipeline which analyzes the state of the repo-based on your commit and generates pipelines\\\\r\\\\nnecessary to run PR validation.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#develop#sdk-docs.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Publish SDK reference docs\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-docs\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Publish SDK reference docs\\\\n## Onboard a released package\\\\n### Packages released through the Azure SDK engineering system\\\\n# docs#develop#sdk-docs.md\\\\n\\\\n# Publish SDK reference docs\\\\n\\\\n## Onboard a released package\\\\n\\\\n### Packages released through the Azure SDK engineering system\\\\n\\\\nIf your package is released through the Azure SDK engineering system, almost everything is automated. You'll need to\\\\r\\\\ntake action if this is your first time releasing a package.\\\\r\\\\nWhen releasing a package for the first time:\\\\r\\\\n1. Ensure that your package is tracked in the  \\\\r\\\\n[release work items](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/Release/_queries/query/7d106acd-a1c2-47b9-9676-996422328397/). This can be done by running the [**Prepare-Release.ps1** script](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mark-release-status).\\\\r\\\\nIn each item for your release, you should have a value for **Service Name** and **Package Display Name**. The docs table of contents is generated from this data.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e [!NOTE]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e Do not skip this step. If you skip the service name, your item will appear in the TOC in the **Other** \\\\u003e **Uncategorized** section.\\\\r\\\\n1. Ensure that your package-level overview file (the README.md file for your package in the SDK source repo) is up to date\\\\r\\\\n*before* releasing.\\\\r\\\\nIn general, the automated system will ensure that updated docs are onboarded within a day or two of your release.\\\\r\\\\nTo customize information about your package outside of the engineering system consult documentation for [CSV fields](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields)\\\\r\\\\nand [Service Level Overview](#service-level-overview) and [Package Level Overview](#package-level-overview).\\\\r\\\\n#### Troubleshooting automated documentation updates\\\\r\\\\nAn automation job runs every 2 hours during business hours on weekdays. If your data is\\\\r\\\\nnot updated and you don't want to wait, [run the job manually](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284).\\\\r\\\\nThis will update the metadata PR.\\\\r\\\\nIf you find anything unexpected in the table of contents or service README, check the\\\\r\\\\n[metadata CSV file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/tree/main/_data/releases/latest) to ensure that the metadata is\\\\r\\\\ncorrect. If the metadata is not correct, open a PR with corrections.\\\\n\\\\nduring business hours on weekdays. If your data is\\\\r\\\\nnot updated and you don't want to wait, [run the job manually](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284).\\\\r\\\\nThis will update the metadata PR.\\\\r\\\\nIf you find anything unexpected in the table of contents or service README, check the\\\\r\\\\n[metadata CSV file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/tree/main/_data/releases/latest) to ensure that the metadata is\\\\r\\\\ncorrect. If the metadata is not correct, open a PR with corrections.\\\\r\\\\nOnce merged your changes will be released on the next available documentation release.\\\\r\\\\n##### Update a published Package-level Overview\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e [!NOTE]\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e For packages released using the Azure SDK EngSys, changes need to be synchronized between the source SDK repo and the docs\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e repo. Changes to the docs repo that are not mirrored to the source SDK repo will be overwritten by content from the source\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003e SDK repo on the next package release.\\\\r\\\\n1. Find the Package-level overview using the table from [Package-level overviews](#package-level-overviews).\\\\r\\\\n2. Find the corresponding README.md file for the library in the SDK repo (e.g. [azure-sdk-for-net](https://github.com/azure/azure-sdk-for-net)).\\\\r\\\\n3. Update the \\\\\\\"front matter\\\\\\\" date field at the beginning of the file to today's date. To update other front matter metadata, see [Ensure CSV metadata is correct](#ensure-csv-metadata-is-correct).\\\\r\\\\n4. Copy changed content from step 2 into the Package-level overview from step 1.\\\\r\\\\n5. Open a pull request for the update file in the docs repo\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#retirement#sdk-deprecation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Deprecating Azure SDKs\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/retirement/sdk-deprecation\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Deprecating Azure SDKs\\\\n## Azure SDK deprecation process\\\\n# docs#retirement#sdk-deprecation.md\\\\n\\\\n# Deprecating Azure SDKs\\\\n\\\\n## Azure SDK deprecation process\\\\n\\\\nPowerShell terminal:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\ngit clone https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk.git\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- Create a branch in your local copy of our repo:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\ngit checkout -b package_deprecation\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- Launch VS Code and open the local repo folder:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nFile -\\\\u003e Open Folder -\\\\u003e \\\\u003cSelect your local repo folder\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- Open the relevant CSV file in VS Code, located under the following directory:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003cyour local path\\\\u003e\\\\\\\\azure-sdk\\\\\\\\_data\\\\\\\\releases\\\\\\\\latest\\\\\\\\\\\\r\\\\n   android-packages.csv\\\\r\\\\n   c-packages.csv\\\\r\\\\n   cpp-packages.csv\\\\r\\\\n   dotnet-packages.csv\\\\r\\\\n   go-packages.csv\\\\r\\\\n   ios-packages.csv\\\\r\\\\n   java-packages.csv\\\\r\\\\n   js-packages.csv\\\\r\\\\n   python-packages.csv\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- Right click on the file in the Explorer window and select `Edit csv`. Find your package(s) in the CSV editor.\\\\r\\\\nPackage names are listed in the leftmost column.\\\\r\\\\n- Update the following mandatory fields:\\\\r\\\\n| Field | Description |\\\\r\\\\n| --- | --- |\\\\r\\\\n| `EOLDate` | Date your package will officially be deprecated in `mm/dd/yyyy` format |\\\\r\\\\n| `Support` | Change the value to **deprecated** |\\\\r\\\\n| `Replace` | Name of the package meant to replace the package being deprecated |\\\\r\\\\n| `ReplaceGuide` | Link to a migration guide in the following format: `aka.ms/azsdk/\\\\u003clanguage\\\\u003e/migrate/\\\\u003clibrary\\\\u003e` |\\\\r\\\\nIf an SDK deprecation is due to a service retirement, the end-of-life date (`EOLDate`) should match the service final\\\\r\\\\nretirement date.\\\\r\\\\n- Commit your changes to your local repository:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\ngit add .\\\\r\\\\ngit commit -m \\\\\\\"Update CSV files for package deprecation\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- Push your changes to GitHub:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\ngit push origin package_deprecation\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- Create a pull request. The previous push command output will include a link to your new branch on the console.\\\\r\\\\nOpen the link in your browser and click the green **Create Pull request** button.\\\\r\\\\nOnce the pull request is created, checks will run to verify the change and notify the repo owners to review your commit.\\\\r\\\\nOnce the change has been reviewed and approved, it can be merged.\\\\n\\\\nThe Azure SDK team maintains a publicly-facing [dashboard](https://aka.ms/azsdk) for Azure SDK packages for all languages.\\\\r\\\\nDeprecating a package in this context means:\\\\r\\\\n1. Update the dashboard to move an SDK from the [active release page](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/) to the  \\\\r\\\\n[deprecated release page](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/releases/deprecated/index.html).\\\\r\\\\n2. Update the package manager download page to reflect the deprecated status, along with the name of the replacement\\\\r\\\\npackage (if available) and a link to the migration guide (if available).\\\\r\\\\nThe Azure SDK dashboard is populated using data stored in [CSV files](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/tree/main/_data/releases/latest)\\\\r\\\\nin the Azure SDK GitHub repo. These CSV files are the source of truth for the status of the Azure SDKs.\\\\r\\\\nDeprecate an SDK by updating the language CSV files:\\\\r\\\\n- Install [Git](https://git-scm.com/downloads), [Visual Studio Code](https://code.visualstudio.com/Download), and the  \\\\r\\\\n[Edit CSV](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=janisdd.vscode-edit-csv) extension for VS Code.\\\\r\\\\n- Configure the `Edit CSV` extension. Open the VS Code Settings (File-\\\\u003ePreferences-\\\\u003eSettings) and search for\\\\r\\\\n`csv-edit`. Set the following configuration options:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"csv-edit.quoteAllFields\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"true\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"csv-edit.quoteEmptyOrNullFields\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"true\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"csv-edit.readOption_hasHeader\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"true\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"csv-edit.writeOption_hasHeader\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"true\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n- Clone the repo on your local machine using a Find (or add) the row for azure-ai-transcription in python-packages.csv.\\n2. Set the MSDocService field to \\\"cognitive-services\\\". rows.inputs.query:
title: "black" job in pipeline fails, but when I run locally, the tool does not make any changes

question: I like to run the "black" tool before PRs, and I ask others in my project to do the same. A few hours ago I found out that I can turn on this check in the pipeline. I was happy to see this. So I added the following to pyproject.toml:
```
[tool.azure-sdk-build]
black = true
```
I run "black" before commiting my last change to the PR, and no updates were needed.
But the pipeline called out a "black" failure: https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/public/_build/results?buildId=5606772&view=logs&j=b70e5e73-bbb6-5567-0939-8415943fadb9&t=efe9ac6d-3fdb-50af-24e1-4319f36eecb4
I see the pipeline used black version 24.4.0. I had a newer version when I run locally. I install 24.4.0 and run that, but it also did not do any changes to the code.
Any idea how to fix it? (other than removing it from the pipeline...).
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
The "black" job in the Azure SDK for Python pipeline can fail for reasons beyond just code formatting. Even if running "black" locally with the same version (24.4.0) does not produce changes, there are a few areas to check for a root cause:
1. Run Black with the Same Arguments as the Pipeline:The pipeline runs "black" using tox with specific arguments. Make sure you are running locally in the same way. From the official guidance, run: `tox run -e black -c ../../../eng/tox/tox.ini --root . -- .` This ensures that the same config files, paths, and excludes are used. The pipeline may use a different configuration or target files that you are not formatting locally. Or you can tried the same command used by ci: `python -m azpysdk.main black --isolate sdk/ai/azure-ai-projects`.
2. Check for Hidden Files or Config Differences: The pipeline uses the repositoryâ€™s configuration, including pyproject.toml and any exclude/include patterns. Local runs may inadvertently skip files due to local ignore files, environment differences, or working directory mismatches. Double-check that your local environment matches the CI context.
3. Run `git status` or `git diff` to find out whether there are files already formatted but not pushed to the pr.
4. Line Endings and Whitespace: Sometimes, black fails due to line ending differences (CRLF vs LF) or invisible whitespace issues that are not flagged locally. Make sure your files have consistent line endings (prefer LF in repo).
5. Check the Pipeline Log for Specific Files: Review the pipeline's failure log closely to see which files are reported as needing formatting. Sometimes, itâ€™s a file outside your typical working set (such as generated code or test files).
6. Reproduce in a Clean Environment: To eliminate local state issues, clone your repo in a fresh directory and re-run the pipelineâ€™s black command as above. If you confirm that running "black" via tox in a clean environment with the same version does not report changes, but the pipeline still fails, check for possible pipeline caching or artifact issues. Otherwise, use the pipeline log to identify exactly which file is causing the failure and focus on that file. Removing the check is not recommended; instead, focus on aligning your local runs with the pipeline invocation. If you continue to see unexplained failures, reach out in the Azure SDK language team channel with your findings and the specific pipeline log excerpt.
rows.inputs.response:
The most common cause for the 'black' job failing in the Azure pipeline, even when running the same version locally does not produce changes, is a mismatch in the environment or invocation parameters between your local setup and the pipeline. Here are the recommended steps to resolve this:

1. Ensure you are running 'black' with the exact same arguments as the pipeline. The pipeline may use specific configuration options or target files differently. You can reproduce the pipeline invocation locally by running:

tox run -e black -c ../../../eng/tox/tox.ini --root . -- .

You can also pass additional arguments after the '--' to target specific files or directories, just as the pipeline does.

2. Make sure your local environment is clean and matches the pipeline. Sometimes, local caches or untracked files can affect results. Run 'git clean -xdf' before running 'black' locally to ensure a clean state.

3. Double-check your 'pyproject.toml' for any configuration differences. The pipeline uses the settings in this file to determine how 'black' is run.

4. If you continue to see discrepancies, check the pipeline logs for the exact command and file list being formatted. Compare this to your local run to ensure you are formatting the same files.

By following these steps, you should be able to reproduce and resolve the 'black' formatting issues locally, ensuring your PR passes the pipeline check. Do not remove the check from the pipeline, as it helps maintain code consistency across contributors.

We understand that some services may have historical uniform versioning issues that require significant effort to resolve. We provide one-time suppression options to unblock PRs while working toward resolution. ### One-Time Suppression You can add the `Approved-Avocado` label to your PR to bypass this check, but this is only allowed if: - There is an ongoing discussion about resolving the uniform versioning issue within your service - You have a clear plan and timeline for resolution **If you are unaware of any ongoing discussions about this issue, please reach out to us immediately!**"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Swagger-Avocado.md","document_title":"Known Issues","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado","content":"# Known Issues ## MULTIPLE_API_VERSION # Swagger-Avocado.md # Known Issues ## MULTIPLE_API_VERSION Rule [MULTIPLE_API_VERSION](https://github.com/Azure/avocado?tab=readme-ov-file#multiple_api_version) was changed from a warning to an error on 7/1/2025. As this issue is a blocker to TypeSpec conversion which is an Azure wide effort to drive the API first design pattern among all Azure services. If your PR is blocked due to this error, please check out this [Uniform Versioning Violation Guide](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Uniform-Versioning-Violation-Guide) wiki on how to resolve this. Please check with azversioning@service.microsoft.com to see if your service can have one-time suppression if you are not sure."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"eng_sys_checks.md","document_title":"Azure SDK for Python - Engineering System","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/eng_sys_checks.md","content":"# Azure SDK for Python - Engineering System ## Analyze Checks ### black # eng_sys_checks.md # Azure SDK for Python - Engineering System ## Analyze Checks ### black [black](https://pypi.org/project/black) is an opinionated code formatter for Python source code. #### Opt-in to formatting validation Ensure that `black = true` is present within your `pyproject.toml`: \`\`\`yml [tool.azure-sdk-build] ...other checks enabled/disabled black = true ...other checks enabled/disabled \`\`\` to opt into the black invocation. #### Running locally 1. Go to package root directory. 2. Execute command: `tox run -e black -c ../../../eng/tox/tox.ini --root . -- .` **Tip**: You can provide any arguments that `black` accepts after the `--`. Example: `tox run -e black -c ../../../eng/tox/tox.ini --root . -- path/to/file.py`"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"migrate-swagger#faq#pipeline.md","document_title":"Resolving Pipeline Failures","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/pipeline","content":"# Resolving Pipeline Failures # migrate-swagger#faq#pipeline.md # Resolving Pipeline Failures This document explains how to resolve pipeline failures in TypeSpec migration PRs. ## Swagger BreakingChange ### Multiple OpenAPI Files Before Migration This pipeline will fail if there is more than one OpenAPI file in the latest version. See the detailed explanation in this [issue](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/2194#issue-2844564216). To properly identify real breaking changes, use the "TypeSpec Migration Validation" pipeline instead: 1. Navigate to the TypeSpec Migration Validation pipeline 2. Check the report on the "Summary" page 3. The output should match exactly what you see in [this step](../01-get-started.md#review-and-adjust-the-typespec) on the local machine 4. Review the changes to verify they are expected ### Single OpenAPI File Before Migration If you have only one OpenAPI file in the latest version, use this pipeline to detect breaking changes. If it fails, refer to [Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations](./faq/breakingchange.md). **Known Issues**: The following pipeline failures are false alerts and can be safely ignored: #### 1017 - ReferenceRedirection This typically occurs when an inlined anonymous enum becomes a named enum. **Before:** \`\`\`json "SomeModel": { "enumProperty": { "type": "string", "enum": [ "If", "Else", "None" ], "x-ms-enum": { "name": "EnumType", "modelAsString": true } } } \`\`\` **After:** \`\`\`json "SomeModel": { "enumProperty": { "$ref": "#/definitions/EnumType" } }, "EnumType": { "type": "string", "enum": [ "If", "Else", "None" ], "x-ms-enum": { "name": "EnumType", "modelAsString": true } } \`\`\` #### 1023 - TypeFormatChanged The error message `The new version has a different format 'uri' than the previous one ''.` on the `nextLink` property is expected because the [page template defines the `nextLink` as `uri`](./mustread.md#using-page-model-from-azurecore-library). #### 1047 - XmsEnumChanged After migration, all models (including enums) will have capitalized names. **Before:** \`\`\`json "SomeModel": { "someProperty": { "type": "string", "enum": [ "If" ], "x-ms-enum": { "name": "someName", "modelAsString": true } } } \`\`\` **After:** \`\`\`json "SomeModel": { "someProperty": { "$ref": "#/definitions/SomeName" } }, "SomeName": { "type": "string", "enum": [ "If" ], "x-ms-enum": { "name": "SomeName", "modelAsString": true } } \`\`\` ## Swagger ModelValidation Some validation rules may fail because TypeSpec fixes certain legacy patterns. Review the known issues below and take appropriate action. ### INVALID_FORMAT: Object didn't pass validation for format uri: {nextlink} #### Root Cause The response model of a pageable operation uses the Azure.Core.Page template: \`\`\`typespec model ResponseModel is Azure.Core.Page; \`\`\` This standardized approach changes the `nextLink` type from plain `string` to `uri`. If previous example's `nextLink` value isn't a valid URI, it will cause a validation error. #### Resolution Choose one of the following options: 1. **Update your example** to include a valid URI value, or 2. **Modify your TypeSpec response model** to use a custom definition if the nextLink returned by the service is not a URI: \`\`\`typespec model ResponseModel { @pageItems value: ItemType[]; @nextLink nextLink?: string; } \`\`\` ### INVALID_FORMAT: Object didn't pass validation for format arm-id #### Root Cause This error typically occurs when a custom resource definition is mapped to a resource defined in common-types. See [this section](./breakingchange.md#using-resources-from-common-types) for details. The `id` property for `Resource` in common-types may use the `arm-id` format, depending on the version of common-types used. #### Resolution Update the value in the example file to meet the `arm-id` format requirements."},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"troubleshoot#sdl.md","document_title":"OneBranch SDL","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/troubleshoot/sdl","content":"# OneBranch SDL ## Workaround # troubleshoot#sdl.md # OneBranch SDL ## Workaround Create your own ADO Artifact Feed, and add `https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json` and `azure-feed://azure-sdk/public/azure-sdk-for-net@Local` as upstream feeds. This enables you to only specify your package feed, and then have your feed pull from the upstream feeds."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Deprecating-Preview-APIs.md","document_title":"Process","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Deprecating-Preview-APIs","content":"## Process 1. Open a PR deleting one (or more) previews. All of: 1. TypeSpec sources (`*.tsp`) 2. Example sources (examples closest to `*.tsp` files) 3. Generated swaggers and examples (`preview/YYYY-MM-DD-preview/**`) 4. readme.md (remove tags) 2. PR should fail check `Swagger BreakingChange`, but pass all other checks. 3. Request approval following the normal process for breaking changes - https://aka.ms/brch - azbreakchangereview@microsoft.com"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_migration_docs","document_filename":"typespec-migration-docs-2025-07-17.md","document_title":"lack ofÂ  final-state-vis: azure-async-operation","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange","content":"# lack ofÂ  final-state-vis: azure-async-operation ## answer # typespec-migration-docs-2025-07-17.md # lack ofÂ  final-state-vis: azure-async-operation ## question lack of final-state-vis: azure-async-operation ## answer add this code as below ``` #suppress "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi" "non-standard operations" @operationId("Configurations_CreateOrUpdate") createOrUpdate is Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.ArmCreateOperation< ResourceInstanceParameters< NginxConfigurationResponse, Azure.ResourceManager.Foundations.DefaultBaseParameters >, NginxConfigurationRequest, NginxConfigurationResponse | ArmResourceCreatedResponse< NginxConfigurationResponse, LroHeaders = ArmAsyncOperationHeader >, ErrorResponse > ```"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"howtos#generate-with-tsp-client#local_spec_quickstart.md","document_title":"Quick Start","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-with-tsp-client/local_spec_quickstart","content":"# Quick Start # howtos#generate-with-tsp-client#local_spec_quickstart.md # Quick Start `tsp-client` allows you to develop your TypeSpec project locally before pushing changes upstream. These instructions can be used when you want to generate a client library from a local TypeSpec project that has the changes you wish to use. ### Prerequisites - Install `tsp-client`: \`\`\`bash npm install -g @azure-tools/typespec-client-generator-cli \`\`\` - Have a local Git repository with your TypeSpec project. We'll use the `azure-rest-api-specs` repository in examples. - Have a clone of an `azure-sdk-for-` repository. We'll use `azure-sdk-for-python` in examples. ### Generate a client library from local changes 1. Go to local `azure-rest-api-specs` clone. 2. Create/Modify the TypeSpec project. 3. Switch to the language repository clone you want to generate a client library in. Example: \`\`\`bash cd < path to > /azure-sdk-for-python \`\`\` 4. From the root of the repository run the following command: \`\`\`bash azure-sdk-for-python> tsp-client init -c \`\`\` Example: \`\`\`bash azure-sdk-for-python > tsp-client init -c ../azure-rest-api-specs/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager/ \`\`\` :::info To get familiar with `tsp-client` and supported commands, see [tsp-client usage](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tsp-client). :::"},{"document_source":"static_azure_docs","document_filename":"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md","document_title":"Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2","document_link":"","content":"# Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2 ## 3. Detailed Breaking Change Process # Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2.md # Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy V1.3.2 ## 3. Detailed Breaking Change Process Service owners should start this process before making any breaking changes. Service owners should plan for at least 6-8 weeks (about 2 months) for the process to be completed. Here are the process steps: ### 1. Intake Preparation (Owner: Service PM) **Estimated time:** 1-3 days - Create a new intake using the template for breaking changes: - Save Intake Request as New. - Please assign the intake to the service owner PM. - Add the "Breaking Change" tag. - Please ensure your request shows up in the dashboard () - Send email to @azbreakchangereview. - Attend weekly Office Hours to talk through the breaking change and seek approval. The office hours are on Mondays, 10 AM to 11 AM Pacific Time. Meeting details can be found here. ### 2. Intake Evaluation (Owner: Service PM/Breaking Change review board) **Estimated time:** 1-2 weeks - Validate high-level business justification. - What is the proposal that is being reviewed? - Why do you need this breaking change? - What will your team do if the breaking change is not approved? There is a high chance the breaking change will NOT be approved. - Customer experience impact. - Number of customers affected. - How can you reduce the impact on customers? ### 3. Intake decision (Owner: Breaking change Review Board) **Estimated time:** 1-3 days - Reviewing all the information, the Breaking Change Review Board will decide whether to approve the proposal, change it, or disapprove it. ### 4. Intake approval from Azure REST API board (Owner: Service PM) **Estimated time:** 1 week - Once approved by the Breaking Change Review Board, status of the intake will be marked as approved by the Breaking Change Review Board. - If there is an SDK impact- then the proposal should be reviewed by API board to seek approval. Reference the API Breaking change documentation: - Engage the SDK team and the SDK Review board to minimize the impact on client libraries. - Service teams should not implement the change until all approvals have been received. ### 5. Communication Readiness (Owner: Service PM/Azure Marketing/CSS) **Estimated time:** 2-6 weeks - Service team owners will need to work with Azure PMM/ Service PM/ Sharon Loh (Breaking change Team - Marketing) - to lock on communication template. If breaking change impacts more than 20,000 subscription IDs, the customer email will be reviewed by assigned editorial team and needs marketing GM and at least one marketing CVP approval. This process will take 2 to 4 weeks. - Engage MS DOC team to update content. - Engage Business planning team to update price, if appropriate - Engage assigned Azure PMM to update marketing assets and ACOM. - Engage Comms Team for avoiding negative press. (If needed) - Engage Azure portal team to update content or add banner. - Engage CSS for awareness into this breaking change being shared with customers. - Engage with CXP (Doug Miller) to schedule communication to customers. ### 6. Signoff/Approval (Owner: Service PM/ APEX Retirements team) **Estimated time:** 2-3 weeks (in parallel with communication readiness) - A signoff sheet for the breaking change request will be created. - Service teams will need to get all signoffs including their service CVP. - APEX Retirements team will help with Office of CTO sign offs. ### 7. Communication update (Owner: Service PM/ CXP) **Estimated time:** Quarterly on preset schedule (Feb, June, Aug, Nov) - Azure updates - Email comms to customers. - Communication rhythm: 3 years, 2 years, 1 year, 6 months, 90 days (about 3 months), 30 days (about 4 and a half weeks), then weekly until T-O. - Service health notification in-product messaging. ### 3.1 Signoff Criteria This section describes the sign offs required for a breaking change that has been approved but not yet communicated. | Sequence | Criteria | Owner | Guidance | |----------|----------|-------|----------| | 1 | Breaking change Request completed | Service Owner PM | â€¢ Azure Dev Ops Intake for breaking changes () filed with business justification, details of the breaking change.
â€¢ Timing of the breaking change implementation. Adherence to the policy.
â€¢ Customer impact identified (Total customers, S500 Customer impact)
â€¢ Migration plan documented. | | 2 | Breaking Change Approval | Azbreakchange review (Jeffrey Richter/Srikanth Mantha) | â€¢ Sign off from the Breaking change review board for approval. API and SDK impacts also reviewed and signed off. | | 3 | Review draft for external communications | Laurel Martinez | â€¢ Program Manager and assigned Azure PMM to create draft customer email based on MS DOC.
â€¢ Works with PM and Azure PMM to review draft email communication.
â€¢ If breaking change impacts over 20,000 subscription IDs and above. PM to create an email intake form (). Send approved draft email to editorial team for review, follow by GM and two CVPs review. Please allow 2 to 4 weeks for this process to be completed. Once approved, send approved draft to Azure CXP email tool to schedule publication.
â€¢ If breaking change impacts fewer than 20,000 subscription IDs, PM to send approved draft to Azure CXP email tool ().
â€¢ PM to share approved email on Azure updates on ACOM | | 4 | Customer communication planned | Doug Miller | â€¢ Customer communications planned and ready to send on pre described date. | | 5 | CVP Of the Group requesting the retirement/Breaking change | Service Owner PM | draft to Azure CXP email tool to schedule publication.
â€¢ If breaking change impacts fewer than 20,000 subscription IDs, PM to send approved draft to Azure CXP email tool ().
â€¢ PM to share approved email on Azure updates on ACOM | | 4 | Customer communication planned | Doug Miller | â€¢ Customer communications planned and ready to send on pre described date. | | 5 | CVP Of the Group requesting the retirement/Breaking change | Service Owner PM | â€¢ PM to drive the sign-off with the CVP to the group requesting the change.
â€¢ Send CVP Link to the sign-off sheet for recording their Sign Off.
â€¢ PM can also attach Email confirmation from CVP to the Sign off sheet. | | 6 | CSS Support readiness | Alex Lagerkrans-Pandey | â€¢ CSS readiness with documentation and training for the breaking change | | 6 | CTO Office approval | John Sheehan/ Mark Russinovich | â€¢ Driven by APEX Retirements team as batch update.
â€¢ All prior steps must be completed.
â€¢ Only after this approval can communication be started. |"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_migration_docs","document_filename":"typespec-migration-docs-2025-07-17.md","document_title":"Error with invalid-argument Argument of type xxx is not assignable to parameter of type 'Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Resource'","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange","content":"# Error with invalid-argument Argument of type xxx is not assignable to parameter of type 'Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Resource' ## answer # typespec-migration-docs-2025-07-17.md # Error with invalid-argument Argument of type xxx is not assignable to parameter of type 'Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Resource' ## question Error with invalid-argument Argument of type xxx is not assignable to parameter of type 'Azure.ResourceManager.CommonTypes.Resource' ##
