## Controlling the Generation Directory
# emitters#clients#http-client-python#reference#package-structure.mdx

# Namespaces

## Controlling the Generation Directory

When migrating existing SDKs or working with brownfield services, you might need to place generated code in a specific subdirectory, like `_generated`. For these scenarios, you can use the [`namespace` configuration option](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/typespec-client-generator-core/reference/emitter/#namespace) in your `tspconfig.yaml` file.
If you want the published SDK to follow closely with the package structure and namespaces in your TypeSpec file, you should also pass in the `package-name` flag with the desired value.

### Using the `namespace` Flag

The `namespace` option allows you to specify where the generated code should be placed within your package structure. This is particularly useful for cases where you want to:
1. Keep generated code isolated in a dedicated subdirectory
2. Maintain backward compatibility with existing SDK structures
3. Separate generated code from hand-written code
#### Example Configuration
In this example, we will take you through emitting generated code into a specific subdirectory (like `_generated`), with the idea that you will be fully-wrapping the generated code. Add the following to your `tspconfig.yaml`:
<Tabs>
<TabItem label="tspconfig.yaml" default>
\`\`\`yaml
emitters:
  "@typespec/http-client-python":
    namespace: "azure.keyvault.certificates._generated"
    package-name: "azure-keyvault-certificates"
\`\`\`
</TabItem>
<TabItem label="TypeSpec File">
\`\`\`typespec
namespace Azure.KeyVault.Certificates;
@service({
  title: "Azure Key Vault Certificate Client",
})
namespace Azure.Keyvault.Certificates {
  model Certificate {
    id: string;
    name: string;
    properties: CertificateProperties;
  }
  model CertificateProperties {
    created: utcDateTime;
    updated: utcDateTime;
    enabled: boolean;
  }
  @route("/certificates")
  interface CertificateOperations {
    @get list(): Certificate[];
    @get get(@path id: string): Certificate;
  }
}
\`\`\`
</TabItem>
<TabItem label="Generated Python SDK">
\`\`\`
azure-keyvault-certificates/
â”œâ”€â”€ azure/
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ keyvault/
â”‚       â””â”€â”€ certificates/
â”‚           â”œâ”€â”€ __init__.py
â”‚           â””â”€â”€ _generated/
â”‚               â”œâ”€â”€ __init__.py
â”‚               â”œâ”€â”€ _models.py
â”‚               â”œâ”€â”€ _client.py
â”‚               â””â”€â”€ ...
â”œâ”€â”€ setup.py
â””â”€â”€ ...
\`\`\`
</TabItem>
</Tabs>"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"emitters#clients#typespec-ts#reference#emitter.md","document_title":"Emitter usage","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/emitters/clients/typespec-ts/reference/emitter","content":"# Emitter usage
## Usage
# emitters#clients#typespec-ts#reference#emitter.md

# Emitter usage

## Usage

1. Via the command line
\`\`\`bash
tsp compile . --emit=@azure-tools/typespec-ts
\`\`\`
2. Via the config
\`\`\`yaml
emit:
  - "@azure-tools/typespec-ts"
\`\`\`
The config can be extended with options as follows:
\`\`\`yaml
emit:
  - "@azure-tools/typespec-ts"
options:
  "@azure-tools/typespec-ts":
    option: value
\`\`\`"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"howtos#generate-client-libraries#04method.mdx","document_title":"Basic methods","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/04method","content":"# Basic methods
## One path for multiple input/output
### Default behaviors
# howtos#generate-client-libraries#04method.mdx

# Basic methods

## One path for multiple input/output

### Default behaviors

The simplest way to express a combination of input in TypeSpec is to use the union operator `|`.
At a glance, JS and Python supports natively union, while Java and C# will use overloads.
<ClientTabs>
\`\`\`typespec title=client.tsp
@service(#{ title: "Analyze", version: "v1" })
namespace Analyze;
@route("/analyze")
@post
op analyze(@query mode: "strict" | "lenient", @body image: bytes): AnalyzeResult;
model CompletionInput {
  input: string | string[];
}
@route("/completions")
@post
op completions(@body input: CompletionInput): CompletionResult;
\`\`\`
\`\`\`python
def analyze(image: bytes, *, mode: Literal["strict", "lenient"]) -> AnalyzeResult:
  ...
class CompletionInput:
  input: Union[str, List[str]] = rest_field(readonly=True)
def completions(input: CompletionInput) -> CompletionResult:
  ...
\`\`\`
\`\`\`csharp
// Union "strict" | "lenient" will be generate as extensible enum
namespace Analyze.Models
{
  public readonly partial struct Mode : IEquatable<Mode>
  {
    public static Mode Strict { get; } = new Mode(StrictValue);
    public static Mode Lenient { get; } = new Mode(LenientValue);
  }
}
// other union which cannot be convert to enum will generate as BinaryData
namespace Analyze.Models
{
  public partial class CompletionInput
  {
    public CompletionInput(BinaryData input)
    public BinaryData Input { get; }
  }
}
namespace Analyze
{
  public partial class AnalyzeClient
  {
    //protocol method
    public virtual async Task<Response> AnalyzeAsync(string mode, RequestContent content, RequestContext context = null) {}
    public virtual Response Analyze(string mode, RequestContent content, RequestContext context = null) {}
    //convenience method
    public virtual async Task<Response<AnalyzeResult>> AnalyzeAsync(Mode mode, BinaryData image, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) {}

image: Uint8Array,
  options: AnalyzeOptionalParams = { requestOptions: {} },
): Promise<AnalyzeResult>;
// JS CodeGen classical client layer
export class AnalyzeClient {
  completions(
    input: CompletionInput,
    options: CompletionsOptionalParams = { requestOptions: {} },
  ): Promise<CompletionResult>;
  analyze(
    mode: "strict" | "lenient",
    image: Uint8Array,
    options: AnalyzeOptionalParams = { requestOptions: {} },
  ): Promise<AnalyzeResult>;
}
\`\`\`
\`\`\`java
public enum Mode {
    STRICT("strict"),
    LENIENT("lenient");
}
public final class CompletionInput {
    public CompletionInput(BinaryData input)
    public BinaryData getInput()
}
public final class AnalyzeClient {
    public Response<BinaryData> analyzeWithResponse(String mode, BinaryData image, RequestOptions requestOptions)
    public Response<BinaryData> completionsWithResponse(BinaryData input, RequestOptions requestOptions)
    public AnalyzeResult analyze(Mode mode, byte[] image)
    public CompletionResult completions(CompletionInput input)
}
\`\`\`
\`\`\`go
type AnalyzeResult struct {
	Confidence *float32
	Result     *string
}
type CompletionInput struct {
	Input []*string
}
type CompletionResult struct {
	Text   *string
	Tokens *int32
}
type AnalyzeClientAnalyzeOptions struct {}
type AnalyzeClientCompletionsOptions struct {}
type AnalyzeClientAnalyzeResponse struct {
	AnalyzeResult
}
type AnalyzeClientCompletionsResponse struct {
	CompletionResult
}
type AnalyzeRequestMode string
const (
	AnalyzeRequestModeLenient AnalyzeRequestMode = "lenient"
	AnalyzeRequestModeStrict AnalyzeRequestMode = "strict"
)
func (client *AnalyzeClient) Analyze(ctx context.Context, mode AnalyzeRequestMode, imageParam io.ReadSeekCloser, options *AnalyzeClientAnalyzeOptions) (AnalyzeClientAnalyzeResponse, error)
func (client *AnalyzeClient) Completions(ctx context.

{
	AnalyzeResult
}
type AnalyzeClientCompletionsResponse struct {
	CompletionResult
}
type AnalyzeRequestMode string
const (
	AnalyzeRequestModeLenient AnalyzeRequestMode = "lenient"
	AnalyzeRequestModeStrict AnalyzeRequestMode = "strict"
)
func (client *AnalyzeClient) Analyze(ctx context.Context, mode AnalyzeRequestMode, imageParam io.ReadSeekCloser, options *AnalyzeClientAnalyzeOptions) (AnalyzeClientAnalyzeResponse, error)
func (client *AnalyzeClient) Completions(ctx context.Context, input CompletionInput, options *AnalyzeClientCompletionsOptions) (AnalyzeClientCompletionsResponse, error)
\`\`\`
</ClientTabs>
Using union implies that the entire combination of possible input is valid. If you have a specific set of combination, or connection between input and output,
you must use `@sharedRoute`. By default, codegen will generate one method per operation name.
<ClientTabs>
\`\`\`typespec title=client.tsp
@sharedRoute
@route("/foo")
op a(x: int32): float;
@sharedRoute
@route("/foo")
op b(x: string): int64;
\`\`\`
\`\`\`python
def a(x: int) -> float:

}
namespace Analyze
{
  public partial class AnalyzeClient
  {
    //protocol method
    public virtual async Task<Response> AnalyzeAsync(string mode, RequestContent content, RequestContext context = null) {}
    public virtual Response Analyze(string mode, RequestContent content, RequestContext context = null) {}
    //convenience method
    public virtual async Task<Response<AnalyzeResult>> AnalyzeAsync(Mode mode, BinaryData image, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) {}
    public virtual Response<AnalyzeResult> Analyze(Mode mode, BinaryData image, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) {}
    //protocol method
    public virtual async Task<Response> CompletionsAsync(RequestContent content, RequestContext context = null) {}
    public virtual Response Completions(RequestContent content, RequestContext context = null) {}
    //convenience method
    public virtual async Task<Response<CompletionResult>> CompletionsAsync(CompletionInput input, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) {}
    public virtual Response<CompletionResult> Completions(CompletionInput input, CancellationToken cancellationToken = default) {}
  }
}
\`\`\`
\`\`\`typescript
// JS CodeGen api layer
export async function completions(
  context: Client,
  input: CompletionInput,
  options: CompletionsOptionalParams = { requestOptions: {} },
): Promise<CompletionResult>;
export async function analyze(
  context: Client,
  mode: "strict" | "lenient",
  image: Uint8Array,
  options: AnalyzeOptionalParams = { requestOptions: {} },
): Promise<AnalyzeResult>;
// JS CodeGen classical client layer
export class AnalyzeClient {
  completions(
    input: CompletionInput,
    options: CompletionsOptionalParams = { requestOptions: {} },
  ): Promise<CompletionResult>;
  analyze(
    mode: "strict" | "lenient",
    image: Uint8Array,
    options: AnalyzeOptionalParams = { requestOptions: {} },
  ): Promise<AnalyzeResult>;
}
\`\`\`"},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"libraries#http#operations.md","document_title":"Operations","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/libraries/http/operations","content":"# Operations
## Metadata
### Nested metadata
# libraries#http#operations.md

# Operations

## Metadata

### Nested metadata

Metadata properties are not required to be top-level. They can also be nested deeper in a parameter or response model type. For example:
\`\`\`typespec
model Thing {
  headers: {
    @header example: string;
  };
  name: string;
}
\`\`\`
Note that nesting in this sense does not require the use of anonymous models. This is equivalent:
\`\`\`typespec
model Thing {
  headers: Headers;
  name: string;
}
model Headers {
  @header example: string;
}
\`\`\`
In the event that this nesting introduces duplication, then the least nested property with a given name is preferred and the duplicate metadata properties are ignored.
\`\`\`typespec
model Thing {
  headers: {
    @header example: string; // preferred
    more: {
      @header example: string; // ignored
    };
  };
}
\`\`\`"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"howtos#generate-client-libraries#08types.mdx","document_title":"Generated Types","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/08types","content":"# Generated Types
## Unions
### Inline union of basic type and literals of that type
# howtos#generate-client-libraries#08types.mdx

# Generated Types

## Unions

### Inline union of basic type and literals of that type

This is union defined inline at point of usage which include the base type as an option.
<ClientTabs>
<ClientTabItem lang="typespec" >
\`\`\`typespec
model Widget {
  color: "red" | "blue" | string;
}
\`\`\`
</ClientTabItem>
<ClientTabItem lang="python">
Python generates a union of literals again.
\`\`\`python
from typing import Literal, Union
model Widget:
  color: Union[Literal["red"] | Literal["blue"] | str]
\`\`\`
</ClientTabItem>
<ClientTabItem lang="csharp" >
\`\`\`csharp
public partial class Widget
{
  public WidgetColor Color;
}
public readonly partial struct WidgetColor : IEquatable<WidgetColor>
{
  private const string RedValue = "red";
  private const string BlueValue = "blue";
  public static WidgetColor Red { get; } = new WidgetColor(RedValue);
  public static WidgetColor Blue { get; } = new WidgetColor(BlueValue);
}
\`\`\`
</ClientTabItem>
<ClientTabItem lang="typescript" >
\`\`\`typescript
export interface Widget {
  color: "red" | "blue" | string;
}
\`\`\`
</ClientTabItem>
<ClientTabItem lang="java" >
\`\`\`java
public final class WidgetColor extends ExpandableStringEnum<Colors> {
    public static final Color RED = fromString("red");
    public static final Color BLUE = fromString("blue");
}
\`\`\`
</ClientTabItem>
<ClientTabItem lang="go" >
\`\`\`go
type Colors string
const (
  ColorsRed Colors = "red"
  ColorsBlue Colors = "blue"
)
\`\`\`
</ClientTabItem>
</ClientTabs>"},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"language-basics#values.md","document_title":"Values","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/values","content":"# Values
## Value kinds
### Object values
# language-basics#values.md

# Values

## Value kinds

### Object values

Object values use the syntax `#{}` and can define any number of properties. For example:
\`\`\`typespec
const point = #{ x: 0, y: 0 };
\`\`\`
The object value's properties must refer to other values. It is an error to reference a type.
\`\`\`typespec
const example = #{
  prop1: #{ nested: true }, // ok
  prop2: {
    nested: true,
  }, // error: values can't reference a type
  prop3: string, // error: values can't reference a type
};
\`\`\`"},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#docstring.md","document_title":"Docstrings","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/docstring.md","content":"# Docstrings
## Docstrings
### Method Docstrings
# dev#docstring.md

# Docstrings

## Docstrings

### Method Docstrings

by calling :func:`~delete_model()`
        .. versionadded:: v2.1
            The *model_name* keyword argument
        .. admonition:: Example:
            .. literalinclude:: ../samples/sample_train_model_without_labels.py
                :start-after: [START training]
                :end-before: [END training]
                :language: python
                :dedent: 8
                :caption: Training a model (without labels) with your custom forms.
        """
        ...
\`\`\`
The first portion of this docstring is a general description of what the method does. It contains a clickable link to MS documentation (note the special format and double-underscore necessary to make this work). Following the general description of the method is a **required new line** and then documentation for each of the parameters, optional keyword arguments, returned objects, and potentially raised errors.
Positional parameters can be documented in one-line or two-lines. Both options can be used in a single docstring for documenting different parameters without issue.
1. This option works best for parameters that are one of the basic types (`str`, `int`, `bool`, `bytes`, `float`, etc.)
\`\`\`python
:param <type> <param_name>: <Description of the parameter>
\`\`\`
2. This option works best for parameters that use custom models or have many different options
\`\`\`python
:param <param_name>: <Description of the parameter>
:type <param_name>: <param_type>
\`\`\`
Optional keyword arguments can be documented in one-line or two-lines. Both options can be used in a single docstring for documenting different keywords without issue. Keywords includes kwargs and in Python 3 code only, parameters after `*` character.
1. This option works best for keyword args that are one of the basic types (`str`, `int`, `bool`, `bytes`, `float`, etc.)
\`\`\`python
:keyword <type> <keyword_name>: <Description of the keyword>
\`\`\`

A method docstring is annotated by the Python long-string `"""<docstring>"""` right after the method definition. The convention is a short line ending with a period, two new lines, followed by a longer description. Below is an example of a full docstring from `azure-ai-formrecognizer`:
\`\`\`python
    @distributed_trace
    def begin_training(self, training_files_url, use_training_labels, **kwargs):
        # type: (str, bool, Any) -> LROPoller[CustomFormModel]
        """Create and train a custom model.
        The request must include a `training_files_url` parameter that is an
        externally accessible Azure storage blob container URI (preferably a Shared Access Signature URI). Note that
        a container URI (without SAS) is accepted only when the container is public. 
        See `SAS container details
        <https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/cognitive-services/form-recognizer/build-training-data-set>`__
        for more details.
        Models are trained using documents that are of the following content type - 'application/pdf',
        'image/jpeg', 'image/png', 'image/tiff', or 'image/bmp'. Other types of content in the container is ignored.
        :param str training_files_url: An Azure Storage blob container's SAS URI. A container URI (without SAS)
            can be used if the container is public. For more information on setting up a training data set, see:
            https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/cognitive-services/form-recognizer/build-training-data-set
        :param bool use_training_labels: Whether to train with labels or not. Corresponding labeled files must
            exist in the blob container if set to `True`.
        :keyword str prefix: A case-sensitive prefix string to filter documents in the source path for
            training. For example, when using a Azure storage blob URI, use the prefix to restrict sub
            folders for training.

<param_name>: <param_type>
\`\`\`
Optional keyword arguments can be documented in one-line or two-lines. Both options can be used in a single docstring for documenting different keywords without issue. Keywords includes kwargs and in Python 3 code only, parameters after `*` character.
1. This option works best for keyword args that are one of the basic types (`str`, `int`, `bool`, `bytes`, `float`, etc.)
\`\`\`python
:keyword <type> <keyword_name>: <Description of the keyword>
\`\`\`
2. This option works best for keyword that use custom models or have many different options
\`\`\`python
:keyword <keyword_name>: <Description of the keyword>
:paramtype <keyword_name>: <keyword_type>
\`\`\`
The returned object is documented on two lines, the first describing what the returned object is and the second describing what the returned type is.
\`\`\`python
"""
:return: <Description of the returned object>
:rtype: <Type of the returned object>
"""
\`\`\`
Finally, describe the possible errors raised by a method:
\`\`\`python
:raises <error1>, <error2>, or <error3>: <description>
\`\`\`
All of the above information needs to be added for each public method and there **needs to be a newline after the above docstrings**. There are additional options for including examples and version specific additions.
For adding a version specific change use the `versionadded` docstring:
\`\`\`
.. versionadded:: <version_number>
\`\`\`
Additional sphinx directives are documented [here](https://review.learn.microsoft.com/help/onboard/admin/reference/python/documenting-api#supported-sphinx-directives)

:param bool use_training_labels: Whether to train with labels or not. Corresponding labeled files must
            exist in the blob container if set to `True`.
        :keyword str prefix: A case-sensitive prefix string to filter documents in the source path for
            training. For example, when using a Azure storage blob URI, use the prefix to restrict sub
            folders for training.
        :keyword include_subfolders: A flag to indicate if subfolders within the set of prefix folders
            will also need to be included when searching for content to be preprocessed. Not supported if
            training with labels.
        :paramtype include_subfolders: bool
        :keyword str model_name: An optional, user-defined name to associate with your model.
        :keyword continuation_token: A continuation token to restart a poller from a saved state.
        :paramtype continuation_token: str
        :return: An instance of an LROPoller. Call `result()` on the poller
            object to return a :class:`~azure.ai.formrecognizer.CustomFormModel`.
        :rtype: ~azure.core.polling.LROPoller[~azure.ai.formrecognizer.CustomFormModel]
        :raises ~azure.core.exceptions.HttpResponseError:
            Note that if the training fails, the exception is raised, but a model with an
            "invalid" status is still created. You can delete this model by calling :func:`~delete_model()`

## Analyze Checks
### Sphinx and docstring checker
# eng_sys_checks.md

# Azure SDK for Python - Engineering System

## Analyze Checks

### Sphinx and docstring checker

[`Sphinx`](https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/) is the preferred documentation builder for Python libraries. The documentation is always built and attached to each PR builds. Sphinx is configured to
fail if docstring are invalid, helping to ensure the resulting documentation will be of high quality. Following are the steps to run `sphinx` locally for a specific package with strict docstring checking:
1. Go to root of the package.
2. Execute following command: `tox run -e sphinx -c ../../../eng/tox/tox.ini --root .`"},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"handbook#style-guide.md","document_title":"Style guide","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/style-guide","content":"# Style guide
## Layout convention
# handbook#style-guide.md

# Style guide

## Layout convention

TypeSpec has a built-in formatter. See [formatter section](./formatter.md) for more information on how to use it.
- Use 2 space indenting
<!-- prettier-ignore -->
\`\`\`typespec
// bad
model Pet {
    name: string;
}
// good
model Pet {
  name: string;
}
\`\`\`
- Place a space before an opening curly brace
<!-- prettier-ignore -->
\`\`\`typespec
// bad
model Pet{
  name: string;
}
// good
model Pet {
  name: string;
}
\`\`\`
- Block opening curly brace `{` should be on the same line
<!-- prettier-ignore -->
\`\`\`typespec
// bad
model Pet 
{
  name: string;
}
// good
model Pet {
  name: string;
}
\`\`\`
- Add a newline after blocks
<!-- prettier-ignore -->
\`\`\`typespec
// bad
model Pet {
  name: string;
}
model Cat extends Pet {}
// good
model Pet {
  name: string;
}
model Cat extends Pet {}
\`\`\`
- Place no space between an operation/decorator/function name and the parameter list
<!-- prettier-ignore -->
\`\`\`typespec
// bad
op list (filter: string): Pet[];
// bad
@doc ("This is a pet")
// good
op list(filter: string): Pet[];
// good
@doc("This is a pet")
\`\`\`
- Do not add spaces inside parentheses
<!-- prettier-ignore -->
\`\`\`typespec
// bad
op list( filter: string ): Pet[];
// good
op list(filter: string): Pet[];
\`\`\`
- Add spaces inside curly braces.
<!-- prettier-ignore -->
\`\`\`typespec
// bad
alias foo = {type: "cat"};
// good
alias foo = { type: "cat" };
\`\`\`
- Do not add space inside square brackets
<!-- prettier-ignore -->
\`\`\`typespec
// bad
alias foo = [ 1, 2, 3 ];
// good
alias foo = [1, 2, 3];
\`\`\`
- Start all comments with a space
<!-- prettier-ignore -->
\`\`\`typespec
//bad
// good
\`\`\`
- Avoid trailing spaces at the end of lines.

### Model layout

- Properties should hug each other unless they have decorators or comments
<!-- prettier-ignore -->
\`\`\`tsp
// bad
model Foo {
  one: string;
  two: string;
  three: string;
}
// good
model Foo {
  one: string;
  two: string;
  three: string;
}
\`\`\`
- Wrap properties in new lines if they have leading comments or decorators
<!-- prettier-ignore -->
\`\`\`tsp
// bad
model Foo {
  one: string;
  @doc("Foo")
  two: string;
  // line comment
  three: string;
  /**
   *  Block comment
   */
  four: string;
  five: string;
}
// good
model Foo {
  one: string;
  @doc("Foo")
  two: string;
  // line comment
  three: string;
  /**
   *  Block comment
   */
  four: string;  
  five: string;
}
\`\`\`"}]

[docutils]\\n```\\nIt comes from two TypeSpec models, direct link here:\\nResponse model - https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/blob/feature/ai-foundry/agents-v2/specification/ai/Azure.AI.Projects/.external-readonly/openai.external.typespec/responses/custom.tsp#L38\\n```\\nmodel Response {\\n...Response_Pre_Update;\\nconversation: {\\nid: string;\\n} | null;\\n}\\n```\\nServiceTier union - https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/blob/feature/ai-foundry/agents-v2/specification/ai/Azure.AI.Projects/.external-readonly/openai.external.typespec/common/models.tsp#L475\\n```\\nunion ServiceTier {\\n\\\"auto\\\",\\n\\\"default\\\",\\n\\\"flex\\\",\\n\\\"scale\\\",\\n\\\"priority\\\",\\n}\\n```\", \"response\": \"To resolve the Python doc generation errors (unexpected indentation, block quote issues, duplicate explicit target names, and bullet list formatting) when emitting from TypeSpec to Python using tsp-client, you need to update your TypeSpec documentation comments and model definitions to be compatible with Sphinx and Python docstring formatting rules.\\n\\n**Key actions:**\\n\\n1. **Bulleted Lists and Block Quotes:**\\n   - In TypeSpec, documentation comments support CommonMark markdown, but Sphinx (used for Python docs) is sensitive to indentation and blank lines, especially for lists and block quotes.\\n   - Ensure that any bulleted lists in your `@doc` or block comments have a blank line before and after the list, and that list items are properly indented. For example:\\n     ```typespec\\n     /**\\n      * This is a summary.\\n      *\\n      * - Item one\\n      * - Item two\\n      *\\n      * More text after the list.\\n      */\\n     ```\\n   - Avoid mixing block quotes and lists without blank lines between them.\\n\\n2. **Duplicate Explicit Target Names:**\\n   - This error is usually caused by repeated markdown links with the same text (e.g., `[learn more](...)`) in the same docstring. Ensure that each link text is unique or only appears once per docstring.\\n   - If you need multiple links, use different link texts or combine them into a single sentence.\\n\\n3. **Unexpected Indentation and Unindent Errors:**\\n   - These are typically caused by inconsistent indentation in doc comments or by starting/ending lists or block quotes without blank lines.\\n   - Always start block comments and lists with a blank line, and end them with a blank line.\\n   - Avoid mixing markdown constructs (lists, quotes, code blocks) without clear separation.\\n\\n4. **ServiceTier Union Formatting:**\\n   - For unions like `ServiceTier`, if you have a doc comment with a bullet list, ensure it is formatted as described above. For example:\\n     ```typespec\\n     /**\\n      * Service tier options:\\n      *\\n      * - auto\\n      * - default\\n      * - flex\\n      * - scale\\n      * - priority\\n      */\\n     union ServiceTier {\\n       \\\"auto\\\",\\n       \\\"default\\\",\\n       \\\"flex\\\",\\n       \\\"scale\\\",\\n       \\\"priority\\\",\\n     }\\n     ```\\n\\n5. **Response Model Documentation:**\\n   - For the `Response` model, review all doc comments for properties and the model itself. Ensure that any lists, code blocks, or block quotes are separated by blank lines and properly indented.\\n   - If you have nested documentation, keep indentation consistent and avoid starting a new markdown construct immediately after another without a blank line.\\n\\n6. **General TypeSpec Docstring Best Practices:**\\n   - Use the TypeSpec formatter to ensure consistent indentation and layout ([see style guide](https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/style-guide)).\\n   - Use block comments (`/** ... */`) for multi-line documentation and ensure markdown constructs are separated by blank lines.\\n   - Avoid duplicate link texts and ensure all markdown is valid CommonMark.\\n\\n**Next steps:**\\n- Update your TypeSpec files to follow these documentation formatting rules.\\n- Re-run `tsp-client update` and rebuild your Python docs (`tox run -e sphinx ...`).\\n- If errors persist, check the generated Python docstrings for problematic markdown and adjust your TypeSpec comments accordingly.\\n\\nThis approach will resolve the Sphinx docstring errors and ensure your Python SDK documentation builds cleanly.\", \"ground_truth\": \"The Sphinx docstring errors you're seeing in the generated Python SDK (unexpected indentation, block quote ends without a blank line, duplicate explicit target names, bullet/definition list issues) are caused by how TypeSpec documentation comments are emitted into Python docstrings, especially when those comments use Markdown or formatting that doesn't map cleanly to reStructuredText (reST), which Sphinx expects.\\nTo resolve these errors, there are two possible solutions:\\n1. You need to ensure that the TypeSpec doc comments for the Response model and ServiceTier union are written in a way that avoids problematic Markdown constructs and closely follows what Sphinx/reST expects.\\nHere are practical steps:\\n- **Bullet/Definition List Formatting:** - Avoid using Markdown bullet lists (`*`, `-`, or `+`) or definition lists in your TypeSpec doc comments. Instead, use plain sentences, or, if you need a list, format it as numbered items with clear line breaks between each item. - If you must use a list, add a blank line before and after the list, and ensure each item starts on a new line. Do not nest lists or use complex indentation.\\n- **Inline Strong/Emphasis Markup:** - If you use `**bold**` or `*italic*` in TypeSpec comments, Sphinx may misinterpret these if not balanced. Prefer using plain text or ensure that every start marker has a matching end marker.\\n- **Explicit Targets (Links):** - If you use `[Learn more](url)` in doc comments, emitting these into Python docstrings can result in duplicate explicit target names. Use plain URLs or avoid repeating the same anchor text multiple times.\\n- **Block Quotes:** - Avoid using Markdown block quotes (`>`) in TypeSpec doc comments. If you need to highlight something, use plain sentences.\\n- **Unexpected Indentation:** - Ensure all TypeSpec doc comments are left-aligned, with no leading spaces or tabs before the text, unless you are deliberately creating a code block. For code blocks, use triple backticks and add blank lines before and after the block.\\n- **General Style:** - Write documentation in simple paragraphs. Do not mix Markdown with reST, and avoid complex formatting. - Example of a safe docstring for a model property: ```tsp /** * The list of available service tiers. Possible values include: * 1. Basic - Entry-level tier. * 2. Standard - Recommended for most workloads. * 3. Premium - Advanced tier for high throughput. */ ``` - Avoid: ```tsp /** * - Basic * - Standard * - Premium */ ``` **Actionable Steps:** - Go to your TypeSpec definitions for Response and ServiceTier, and revise any doc comments containing bullet lists, definition lists, block quotes, repeated anchor text, or excessive indentation. Replace with simple sentences or numbered lists as above. - After making these changes, regenerate the Python SDK and run the Sphinx build again. The warnings/errors should be resolved. - For reference on Python docstring formatting and Sphinx compatibility, see the Azure Python SDK [docstring guidelines](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/docstring.md). If you need a specific example for ServiceTier: ```tsp /** * Service tier for deployment. Possible values: * 1. Basic: Entry-level tier. * 2. Standard: Recommended tier. * 3. Premium: Advanced tier for large workloads. */ union ServiceTier { ... } ``` And for Response model, ensure any lists or references are in plain sentences and do not use block quotes or repeated links.\\n2. Or you can disable the sphinx environment within the pyproject.toml for the problematic package. By that way you won't hit these sphinx failures.\\n```\\n[tool.azure-sdk-build]\\nsphinx = false\\n```\"}"}]

\"[{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_migration_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec-migration-docs-2025-08-07.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Same response model is used both in pageable operation and non-pageable operation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Same response model is used both in pageable operation and non-pageable operation\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec-migration-docs-2025-08-07.md\\\\n\\\\n# Same response model is used both in pageable operation and non-pageable operation\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nSame response model is used both in pageable operation and non-pageable operation\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nUltimately, the solution agreed upon is to add nextLink and use the core paging schema in TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\\r\\\\n#suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/documentation-required\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"For backward compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n- model ListAppIdResponse is Azure.Core.Page\\\\u003cAppId\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n+ model ListAppIdResponse {\\\\r\\\\n+    /*\\\\r\\\\n+    * List of AppIds\\\\r\\\\n+    */\\\\r\\\\n+    @TypeSpec.pageItems\\\\r\\\\n+    value: string[];\\\\r\\\\n+\\\\r\\\\n+    /*\\\\r\\\\n+    * next Link\\\\r\\\\n+    */\\\\r\\\\n+    @TypeSpec.nextLink\\\\r\\\\n+    nextLink?: string;\\\\r\\\\n+ }\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\\r\\\\n  #suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"non-standard operations\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n  @operationId(\\\\\\\"LocalRulestacks_listAppIds\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n+ @TypeSpec.list\\\\r\\\\n  listAppIds is ArmResourceActionSync\\\\u003c\\\\r\\\\n      LocalRulestackResource,\\\\r\\\\n      void,\\\\r\\\\n      ArmResponse\\\\u003cListAppIdResponse\\\\u003e,\\\\r\\\\n      Parameters = {\\\\r\\\\n          #suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/documentation-required\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"For backward compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n          @query(\\\\\\\"appIdVersion\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n          appIdVersion?: string;\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n          #suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/documentation-required\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"For backward compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n          @query(\\\\\\\"appPrefix\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n          appPrefix?: string;\\\\r\\\\n      }\\\\r\\\\n  };\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nif it's pageable, then add decorator @TypeSpec.List to the operation\\\\n\\\\n[ref link](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/2932):\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nissue title: Same response model is used both in pageable operation and non-pageable operation\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\ncontent: \\\\r\\\\nThis is an example,\\\\r\\\\npageable operation[https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/03a6598cdc38924f9eaaeb03f8ef151f5aeff449/specification/guestconfiguration/resource-manager/Microsoft.GuestConfiguration/stable/2024-04-05/guestconfiguration.json#L1046]\\\\r\\\\nnon-pageable operation[https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/03a6598cdc38924f9eaaeb03f8ef151f5aeff449/specification/guestconfiguration/resource-manager/Microsoft.GuestConfiguration/stable/2024-04-05/guestconfiguration.json#L358]\\\\r\\\\nThey share the same response model GuestConfigurationAssignmentReportList.\\\\r\\\\nIn swagger, pageable is marked at operation level, while in TypeSpec pageable is marked at model level. We need to figure out a way for this case.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nsolution:\\\\r\\\\nAs discussed, TypeSpec\\u2019s core paging system supports both client-driven and server-driven paging, but it requires explicit specification\\u2014there is no default assumption like nextLink. If a response model lacks nextLink, it\\u2019s not considered pageable in the traditional sense, and setting x-ms-pageable would be a misinterpretation.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nThe recommendation is to use the standard ARM paging mechanism. Since nextLink is optional, adding it is not a breaking change. This ensures that if paging is implemented later, it follows the standard. Ultimately, the solution agreed upon is to add nextLink and use the core paging schema in TypeSpec.\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\\r\\\\n#suppress \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/documentation-required\\\\\\\" \\\\\\\"For backward compatibility\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n- model ListAppIdResponse is Azure.Core.Page\\\\u003cAppId\\\\u003e;\\\\r\\\\n+ model ListAppIdResponse {\\\\r\\\\n+    /*\\\\r\\\\n+    * List of AppIds\\\\r\\\\n+    */\\\\r\\\\n+    @TypeSpec.pageItems\\\\r\\\\n+    value: string[];\\\\r\\\\n+\\\\r\\\\n+    /*\\\\r\\\\n+    * next Link\\\\r\\\\n+    */\\\\r\\\\n+    @TypeSpec.nextLink\\\\r\\\\n+    nextLink?: string;\\\\r\\\\n+ }\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n```diff\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"language-basics#documentation.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Documentation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/language-basics/documentation\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Documentation\\\\n## Markdown\\\\n# language-basics#documentation.md\\\\n\\\\n# Documentation\\\\n\\\\n## Markdown\\\\n\\\\nTypeSpec Documentation support CommonMark markdown formatting. The tooling(IDE extensions, doc generation, etc.) will process the documentation as markdown.\\\\r\\\\nEmitters can choose to render the description as it is, convert it to their preferred format or just strip any markdown information.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``tsp\\\\r\\\\n@doc(\\\\\\\"This is a **bold** text\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\nmodel Dog {\\\\r\\\\n  @doc(\\\\\\\"This is a _italic_ text\\\\\\\")\\\\r\\\\n  name: string;\\\\r\\\\n  /**\\\\r\\\\n   * This contains a bullet list\\\\r\\\\n   * - one\\\\r\\\\n   * - two\\\\r\\\\n   * and code blocks\\\\r\\\\n   *\\\\r\\\\n   * \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`typescript\\\\r\\\\n   * dog.age = 5;\\\\r\\\\n   * \\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n   */\\\\r\\\\n  age: int32;\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\``\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Output folder 'ContentUnderstanding' appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Output folder 'ContentUnderstanding' appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\\n## question\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Output folder 'ContentUnderstanding' appears to contain TypeSpec-generated swagger files, not generated from the current TypeSpec sources. Perhaps you deleted a version from your TypeSpec, but didn't delete the associated swaggers?\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\n[Pull Request #21772](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/21772) is currently failing TypeSpec validation because data-plane contains the Swagger for an older preview not specified in main.tsp.  The guidance I got from API board a month ago is that main.tsp should only list the latest preview. API version  But doing so triggered this error. \\\\r\\\\nShould this be an error?  Or can we make this into a warning instead?\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\nYou should only track the latest preview version in your TypeSpec files.\\\\r\\\\nIf there are older preview Swagger files still in the repo, they can remain there for the required 90-day deprecation window, even if they're no longer listed in your .tsp files.\\\\r\\\\nWhile TypeSpec validation currently throws an error if Swagger files exist without a matching version in TypeSpec, you can suppress this error by adding an entry to suppressions.yaml in your service's spec folder (not the global one).\\\\r\\\\nLonger-term, the goal is to eliminate swagger files entirely, but for now, swagger and TypeSpec coexist. So:\\\\r\\\\nKeep only the latest preview in .tsp\\\\r\\\\nKeep older generated swagger for 90 days\\\\r\\\\nAdd suppressions if needed to prevent TypeSpec validation from failing\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_sdk_for_python_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"dev#mgmt#operation_migration.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure SDK Migration Guide: New Operation Design Generation Breaking Changes\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/operation_migration.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure SDK Migration Guide: New Operation Design Generation Breaking Changes\\\\n## Why These Changes?\\\\n# dev#mgmt#operation_migration.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure SDK Migration Guide: New Operation Design Generation Breaking Changes\\\\n\\\\n## Why These Changes?\\\\n\\\\nOur operations prioritize consistency with the underlying REST API:\\\\r\\\\n- **Better API Alignment**: Keyword-only parameters improve traceability between code and request body.\\\\r\\\\n- **Improved Developer Experience**: Keyword-only parameters enable IDEs to provide rich type hints with parameter names.\\\\r\\\\n- **Maintainability**: Enum-based conditions makes the SDK easier to maintain and understand.\\\\r\\\\nIf you encounter issues not covered here, please file an issue on [GitHub](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues) with tag `emitter:client:python`.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"emitters#clients#introduction.mdx\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Client Emitters\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/clients/introduction\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Client Emitters\\\\n## Disclaimer\\\\n# emitters#clients#introduction.mdx\\\\n\\\\n# Client Emitters\\\\n\\\\n## Disclaimer\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003cAside\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n**All client emitters are in preview**. These emitters are actively being developed and may experience changes or updates that could affect their functionality. Please follow the official documentation for the latest updates.\\\\r\\\\n- [TypeSpec C# emitter library](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/blob/main/packages/http-client-csharp/readme.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [TypeSpec Python emitter library](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/blob/main/packages/http-client-python/README.md)\\\\r\\\\n- [TypeSpec Java emitter library](https://github.com/Azure/autorest.typescript/blob/main/packages/typespec-ts/README.md)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\u003c/Aside\\\\u003e\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure_sdk_for_python_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"dev#mgmt#hybrid_model_migration.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Azure Changes\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/hybrid_model_migration.md\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Azure SDK Migration Guide: New Hybrid Model Design Generation Breaking Changes\\\\n## Why These Changes?\\\\n# dev#mgmt#hybrid_model_migration.md\\\\n\\\\n# Azure SDK Migration Guide: New Hybrid Model Design Generation Breaking Changes\\\\n\\\\n## Why These Changes?\\\\n\\\\nOur hybrid models prioritize consistency with the underlying REST API:\\\\r\\\\n- **Better API Alignment**: Model hierarchy and property names now match your REST API documentation exactly\\\\r\\\\n- **Improved Developer Experience**: Direct dictionary access eliminates extra method calls\\\\r\\\\n- **Consistency**: `camelCase` output matches what you see in REST API responses\\\\r\\\\n- **Maintainability**: Reduced artificial flattening makes the SDK easier to maintain and understand\\\\r\\\\nIf you encounter issues not covered here, please file an issue on [GitHub](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/issues) with tag `emitter:client:python`.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"typespec_azure_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"emitters#clients#typespec-python#reference#emitter.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Emitter Via the command line\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`bash\\\\r\\\\ntsp compile . --emit=@azure-tools/typespec-python\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n2. Via the config\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-python\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe config can be extended with options as follows:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`yaml\\\\r\\\\nemit:\\\\r\\\\n  - \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-python\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\noptions:\\\\r\\\\n  \\\\\\\"@azure-tools/typespec-python\\\\\\\":\\\\r\\\\n    option: value\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_qa\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Exclude property from list that is in create/update/get\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Exclude property from list that is in create/update/get\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec_2025_05_22.md\\\\n\\\\n# Exclude property from list that is in create/update/get\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\nWe have an ARM resource that has a property , e.g.  properties.blob that will contain a very large amount of text not appropriate for list responses.  \\\\r\\\\nI see we can override the properties for ArmResourceCreateOrReplaceAsync and ArmResourcePatchAsync, but I don't see a way to do this for ArmResourceRead or ArmResourceListByParent. \\\\r\\\\nIs there a way to exclude a property from properties when listing other than defining a new resource type that lacks the specific property? \\\\r\\\\nThe property is required. The only way I can see to do this would be to make it appear optional but return an error is the user tried to set it to empty or null.\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n},\\\\r\\\\n          {\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"notificationHubName\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"in\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"path\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The name of the NotificationHubResource\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\": true,\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"pattern\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"^[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9-./_]*$\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n          },\\\\r\\\\n          {\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"authorizationRuleName\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"in\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"path\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"description\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"The name of the SharedAccessAuthorizationRuleResource\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"required\\\\\\\": true,\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"type\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"string\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"pattern\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"^[a-zA-Z0-9!()*-._]+$\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nExpected: [This](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/5351ac8e1e6fdf48933bae2cd879434b93b36ac0/specification/notificationhubs/resource-manager/Microsoft.NotificationHubs/preview/2023-10-01-preview/notificationhubs.json#L417-L425) \\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/parameters/NamespaceName\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n          },\\\\r\\\\n          {\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/parameters/HubName\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n          },\\\\r\\\\n          {\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/parameters/AuthorizationRuleName\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n          },\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nis the original swagger. There is limitations on minLength and maxLength.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nYes, because the actual path parameters do not come from the resource, you would need to decorate the parameters in the LegacyOperations instantiation.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nWhen you construct the LegacyOperations interface, you pass in the parameters - those passed-in parameters would need to be decorated.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nI wonder if we shouldn't have a legacy resource template that omits the name parameter, just to avoid confusion, it is literally unused in this context.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf you need to decorate the name parameter, you will need to define them directly, or name the resulting model, so they can be decoratred.  You can decorate a model statement, but not a model expression.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n# First experience of TSP ApiVersion introduction - passed all CI checks, what's next?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi TypeSpec friends!\\\\n\\\\n`TypeSpec.Http.OkResponse` which causes problems in downstream. Can we remove this model? (omit-unreachable-types: true does not work)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## answer\\\\r\\\\nIf the `OkResponse` model is being emitted but not actually referenced, that does sound like a bug \\u2014 we shouldn't be generating unused models. Especially in cases like this where you're doing a long-running POST action and the 200 response is effectively empty, it\\u2019s more accurate to model the operation with just a `202` and an error response.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nFor your case, you can avoid using `OkResponse` entirely by switching to `ArmResourceActionNoResponseContentAsync` or passing `never` as the third argument. That will prevent the generation of the unnecessary `OkResponse` model.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nAlso, keep in mind that for LROs, the POST operation typically doesn't return 200 anyway. That response is just a placeholder in the old pattern to signal \\\\\\\"void\\\\\\\". If you're converting from existing Swagger, and it doesn\\u2019t actually return 200, you should be able to safely drop that response from the Swagger and avoid the breaking change.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nAlternatively, if you do need to customize the final response for the LRO, `getLroResponse` can be used to override the response returned at the end of the operation \\u2014 no need to rely on `OkResponse` at all.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n# TSP Install fails with below error\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nI am trying to install TSP and its dependencies and it fails with below error. I have latest node.js Can you please help?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nError: spawn EINVAL\\\\r\\\\n    at ChildProcess.spawn (node:internal/child_process:420:11)\\\\r\\\\n    at spawn (node:child_process:753:9)\\\\r\\\\n    at installTypeSpecDependencies (file:///C:/Users/anponnet/AppData/Roaming/npm/node_modules/@typespec/compiler/dist/src/core/install.js:4:19)\\\\r\\\\n    at file:///C:/Users/anponnet/AppData/Roaming/npm/node_modules/@typespec/compiler/dist/src/core/cli/cli.js:152:95\\\\r\\\\n    at Object.handler (file:///C:/Users/anponnet/AppData/Roaming/npm/node_modules/@typespec/compiler/dist/src/core/cli/utils.js:16:16)\\\\n\\\\nI wonder if we shouldn't have a legacy resource template that omits the name parameter, just to avoid confusion, it is literally unused in this context.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\nIf you need to decorate the name parameter, you will need to define them directly, or name the resulting model, so they can be decoratred.  You can decorate a model statement, but not a model expression.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\n# First experience of TSP ApiVersion introduction - passed all CI checks, what's next?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\r\\\\n## question \\\\r\\\\nHi TypeSpec friends! \\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nWe are bringing 2nd \\\\\\\"private-preview\\\\\\\" API version to exercise TSP-based wirings and learn the ecosystem:\\\\r\\\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22321\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nFirst round was back in the swagger days.\\\\r\\\\nNow that we are bringing TSP, it comes with a lot of learning.\\\\r\\\\nWe made lots of adjustments to satisfy the checks, that were not really changing the protocol, and we had to apply several suppressions otherwise since development of this version has completed - and it is heading to PowerShell CLI partners.\\\\r\\\\n \\\\r\\\\nIt is clear that specification work of the next API version need to be exercised through Azure REST repository By using TypeSpec, you can ensure a consistent, high-quality developer experience across Azure services.\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"azure-sdk-docs-eng\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"What is TypeSpec?\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n## Get help\\\\n### Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot\\\\n# docs#design#api-specs#api-typespec.md\\\\n\\\\n# What is TypeSpec?\\\\n\\\\n## Get help\\\\n\\\\n### Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot\\\\n\\\\nThe TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel includes an Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot that is designed to help you with questions  \\\\r\\\\nrelated to TypeSpec, Azure TypeSpec, and the related emitters. Simply mention `@Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot` directly in your  \\\\r\\\\nmessage with a clear description of the problem you're facing.\\\\r\\\\n**Example usage:**\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n@Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot: How can I describe HTTP status codes for responses in TypeSpec?\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n**Best practices for using the bot:**\\\\r\\\\n- Start a conversation by mentioning `@Azure SDK Q\\\\u0026A Bot` in the TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel - note that  \\\\r\\\\n  modifying existing posts won't trigger a response\\\\r\\\\n- The bot only has context from messages that directly mention it and cannot access or see messages outside of that  \\\\r\\\\n  context\\\\r\\\\n- It supports images and GitHub pull request links for better context\\\\r\\\\n- All replies are generated by AI, so please double-check to ensure the information is correct\\\"},{\\\"document_source\\\":\\\"static_typespec_migration_docs\\\",\\\"document_filename\\\":\\\"typespec-migration-docs-2025-08-07.md\\\",\\\"document_title\\\":\\\"Additional \\\\\\\"consumes\\\\\\\": [  \\\\\\\"text/plain\\\\\\\"  ], in operation\\\",\\\"document_link\\\":\\\"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange\\\",\\\"content\\\":\\\"# Additional \\\\\\\"consumes\\\\\\\": [  \\\\\\\"text/plain\\\\\\\"  ], in operation\\\\n## answer\\\\n# typespec-migration-docs-2025-08-07.md\\\\n\\\\n# Additional \\\\\\\"consumes\\\\\\\": [  \\\\\\\"text/plain\\\\\\\"  ], in operation\\\\n\\\\n## question\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"consumes\\\\\\\": [\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"text/plain\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n],\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\n\\\\n## answer\\\\n\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\n{\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"name\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"body\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"in\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"body\\\\\\\",\\\\r\\\\n    \\\\\\\"schema\\\\\\\": {\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"$ref\\\\\\\": \\\\\\\"#/definitions/email\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n    }\\\\r\\\\n}\\\\r\\\\n```\\\\r\\\\nBecause TypeSpec wants to reproduce this part of the content from the original swagger, but once the parameter in body is a basic type (string, int32, scalar, etc.), it will cause this extra part to appear. name\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAzure services should not be using decorators from the OpenAPIs libraries(`@azure-tools/openapi`, `@azure-tools/typespec-autorest` or `@azure-tools/openapi3`) in their spec.\\\\r\\\\nUsing those decorators is usually a sign that the spec is either not following the correct Azure or trying to match exactly a particular OpenAPI spec which should be a non-goal.\\\\r\\\\nThose decorators are only meant to be read by the openapi emitters which means this might achieve the correct OpenAPI output but other emitters(client SDK, service, etc.) will not be able to understand them and will see a broken representation of the spec.\\\\n\\\\n## Decorators and their alternatives\\\\n\\\\n| OpenAPI Decorator                    | Alternative             |\\\\r\\\\n| `@extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-client-flatten\\\\\\\", ` | Use [`@flattenProperty`](../../typespec-client-generator-core/reference/decorators.md#@Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy.flattenProperty)                       |\\\\r\\\\n| `@extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-mutability\\\\\\\", `     | Use [`@visibility` decorator](https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-decorators#@visibility)                                                        |\\\\r\\\\n| `@extension(\\\\\\\"x-ms-enum\\\\\\\", `           | [Enum extensibility doc](../../../troubleshoot/enum-not-extensible.md) [`@identifiers`](../../azure-resource-manager/reference/decorators.md#@Azure.ResourceManager.identifiers)                                                   |\\\\r\\\\n| `@operationId` It contains a clickable link to MS documentation (note the special format and double-underscore necessary to make this work). Following the general description of the method is a **required new line** and then documentation for each of the parameters, optional keyword arguments, returned objects, and potentially raised errors.\\\\r\\\\nPositional parameters can be documented in one-line or two-lines. Both options can be used in a single docstring for documenting different parameters without issue.\\\\r\\\\n1. This option works best for parameters that are one of the basic types (`str`, `int`, `bool`, `bytes`, `float`, etc.)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n:param \\\\u003ctype\\\\u003e \\\\u003cparam_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cDescription of the parameter\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n2. This option works best for parameters that use custom models or have many different options\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n:param \\\\u003cparam_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cDescription of the parameter\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n:type \\\\u003cparam_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cparam_type\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOptional keyword arguments can be documented in one-line or two-lines. Both options can be used in a single docstring for documenting different keywords without issue. Keywords includes kwargs and in Python 3 code only, parameters after `*` character.\\\\r\\\\n1. This option works best for keyword args that are one of the basic types (`str`, `int`, `bool`, `bytes`, `float`, etc.)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n:keyword \\\\u003ctype\\\\u003e \\\\u003ckeyword_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cDescription of the keyword\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\n\\\\nA method docstring is annotated by the Python long-string `\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\u003cdocstring\\\\u003e\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"` right after the method definition. The convention is a short line ending with a period, two new lines, followed by a longer description. Below is an example of a full docstring from `azure-ai-formrecognizer`:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n    @distributed_trace\\\\r\\\\n    def begin_training(self, training_files_url, use_training_labels, **kwargs):\\\\r\\\\n        # type: (str, bool, Any) -\\\\u003e LROPoller[CustomFormModel]\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"Create and train a custom model.\\\\r\\\\n        The request must include a `training_files_url` parameter that is an\\\\r\\\\n        externally accessible Azure storage blob container URI (preferably a Shared Access Signature URI). Note that\\\\r\\\\n        a container URI (without SAS) is accepted only when the container is public. \\\\r\\\\n        See `SAS container details\\\\r\\\\n        \\\\u003chttps://docs.microsoft.com/azure/cognitive-services/form-recognizer/build-training-data-set\\\\u003e`__\\\\r\\\\n        for more details.\\\\r\\\\n        Models are trained using documents that are of the following content type - 'application/pdf',\\\\r\\\\n        'image/jpeg', 'image/png', 'image/tiff', or 'image/bmp'. Other types of content in the container is ignored.\\\\r\\\\n        :param str training_files_url: An Azure Storage blob container's SAS URI. A container URI (without SAS)\\\\r\\\\n            can be used if the container is public. For more information on setting up a training data set, see:\\\\r\\\\n            https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/cognitive-services/form-recognizer/build-training-data-set\\\\r\\\\n        :param bool use_training_labels: Whether to train with labels or not. Corresponding labeled files must\\\\r\\\\n            exist in the blob container if set to `True`.\\\\r\\\\n        :keyword str prefix: A case-sensitive prefix string to filter documents in the source path for\\\\r\\\\n            training. For example, when using a Azure storage blob URI, use the prefix to restrict sub\\\\r\\\\n            folders for training.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\u003cparam_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cparam_type\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nOptional keyword arguments can be documented in one-line or two-lines. Both options can be used in a single docstring for documenting different keywords without issue. Keywords includes kwargs and in Python 3 code only, parameters after `*` character.\\\\r\\\\n1. This option works best for keyword args that are one of the basic types (`str`, `int`, `bool`, `bytes`, `float`, etc.)\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n:keyword \\\\u003ctype\\\\u003e \\\\u003ckeyword_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cDescription of the keyword\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\n2. This option works best for keyword that use custom models or have many different options\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n:keyword \\\\u003ckeyword_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cDescription of the keyword\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n:paramtype \\\\u003ckeyword_name\\\\u003e: \\\\u003ckeyword_type\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nThe returned object is documented on two lines, the first describing what the returned object is and the second describing what the returned type is.\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n:return: \\\\u003cDescription of the returned object\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n:rtype: \\\\u003cType of the returned object\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\\\\"\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nFinally, describe the possible errors raised by a method:\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`python\\\\r\\\\n:raises \\\\u003cerror1\\\\u003e, \\\\u003cerror2\\\\u003e, or \\\\u003cerror3\\\\u003e: \\\\u003cdescription\\\\u003e\\\\r\\\\n\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\\\\\`\\\\r\\\\nAll of the above information needs to be added for each public method and there **needs to be a newline after the above docstrings**. Corresponding labeled files must\\\\r\\\\n            exist in the blob container if set to `True`.\\\\r\\\\n        :keyword str prefix: A case-sensitive prefix string to filter documents in the source path for\\\\r\\\\n            training. For example, when using a Azure storage blob URI, use the prefix to restrict sub\\\\r\\\\n            folders for training.\\\\r\\\\n        :keyword include_subfolders: A flag to indicate if subfolders within the set of prefix folders\\\\r\\\\n            will also need to be included when searching for content to be preprocessed. Not supported if\\\\r\\\\n            training with labels.\\\\r\\\\n        :paramtype include_subfolders: bool\\\\r\\\\n        :keyword str model_name: An optional, user-defined name to associate with your model.\\\\r\\\\n        :keyword continuation_token: A continuation token to restart a poller from a saved state.\\\\r\\\\n        :paramtype continuation_token: str\\\\r\\\\n        :return: An instance of an LROPoller. Call `result()` on the poller\\\\r\\\\n            object to return a :class:`~azure.ai.formrecognizer.CustomFormModel`.\\\\r\\\\n        :rtype: ~azure.core.polling.LROPoller[~azure.ai.formrecognizer.CustomFormModel]\\\\r\\\\n        :raises ~azure.core.exceptions.HttpResponseError:\\\\r\\\\n            Note that if the training fails, the exception is raised, but a model with an\\\\r\\\\n            \\\\\\\"invalid\\\\\\\" status is still created. [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"response\": \"To resolve the Python doc generation errors (unexpected indentation, block quote issues, duplicate explicit target names, and bullet list formatting) when emitting from TypeSpec to Python using tsp-client, you need to update your TypeSpec documentation comments and model definitions to be compatible with Sphinx and Python docstring formatting rules.\\n\\n**Key actions:**\\n\\n1. **Bulleted Lists and Block Quotes:**\\n   - In TypeSpec, documentation comments support CommonMark markdown, but Sphinx (used for Python docs) is sensitive to indentation and blank lines, especially for lists and block quotes.\\n   - Ensure that any bulleted lists in your `@doc` or block comments have a blank line before and after the list, and that list items are properly indented. For example:\\n     ```typespec\\n     /**\\n      * This is a summary.\\n      *\\n      * - Item one\\n      * - Item two\\n      *\\n      * More text after the list.\\n      */\\n     ```\\n   - Avoid mixing block quotes and lists without blank lines between them.\\n\\n2. **Duplicate Explicit Target Names:**\\n   - This error is usually caused by repeated markdown links with the same text (e.g., `[learn more](...)`) in the same docstring. Ensure that each link text is unique or only appears once per docstring.\\n   - If you need multiple links, use different link texts or combine them into a single sentence.\\n\\n3. **Unexpected Indentation and Unindent Errors:**\\n   - These are typically caused by inconsistent indentation in doc comments or by starting/ending lists or block quotes without blank lines.\\n   - Always start block comments and lists with a blank line, and end them with a blank line.\\n   - Avoid mixing markdown constructs (lists, quotes, code blocks) without clear separation.\\n\\n4. **ServiceTier Union Formatting:**\\n   - For unions like `ServiceTier`, if you have a doc comment with a bullet list, ensure it is formatted as described above. For example:\\n     ```typespec\\n     /**\\n      * Service tier options:\\n      *\\n      * - auto\\n      * - default\\n      * - flex\\n      * - scale\\n      * - priority\\n      */\\n     union ServiceTier {\\n       \\\"auto\\\",\\n       \\\"default\\\",\\n       \\\"flex\\\",\\n       \\\"scale\\\",\\n       \\\"priority\\\",\\n     }\\n     ```\\n\\n5. **Response Model Documentation:**\\n   - For the `Response` model, review all doc comments for properties and the model itself. Ensure that any lists, code blocks, or block quotes are separated by blank lines and properly indented.\\n   - If you have nested documentation, keep indentation consistent and avoid starting a new markdown construct immediately after another without a blank line.\\n\\n6. **General TypeSpec Docstring Best Practices:**\\n   - Use the TypeSpec formatter to ensure consistent indentation and layout ([see style guide](https://typespec.io/docs/handbook/style-guide)).\\n   - Use block comments (`/** ... */`) for multi-line documentation and ensure markdown constructs are separated by blank lines.\\n   - Avoid duplicate link texts and ensure all markdown is valid CommonMark.\\n\\n**Next steps:**\\n- Update your TypeSpec files to follow these documentation formatting rules.\\n- Re-run `tsp-client update` and rebuild your Python docs (`tox run -e sphinx ...`).\\n- If errors persist, check the generated Python docstrings for problematic markdown and adjust your TypeSpec comments accordingly.\\n\\nThis approach will resolve the Sphinx docstring errors and ensure your Python SDK documentation builds cleanly.\", \"ground_truth\": \"The Sphinx docstring errors you're seeing in the generated Python SDK (unexpected indentation, block quote ends without a blank line, duplicate explicit target names, bullet/definition list issues) are caused by how TypeSpec documentation comments are emitted into Python docstrings, especially when those comments use Markdown or formatting that doesn't map cleanly to reStructuredText (reST), which Sphinx expects.\\nTo resolve these errors, there are two possible solutions:\\n1. You need to ensure that the TypeSpec doc comments for the Response model and ServiceTier union are written in a way that avoids problematic Markdown constructs and closely follows what Sphinx/reST expects.\\nHere are practical steps:\\n- **Bullet/Definition List Formatting:** - Avoid using Markdown bullet lists (`*`, `-`, or `+`) or definition lists in your TypeSpec doc comments. Instead, use plain sentences, or, if you need a list, format it as numbered items with clear line breaks between each item. - If you must use a list, add a blank line before and after the list, and ensure each item starts on a new line. Do not nest lists or use complex indentation.\\n- **Inline Strong/Emphasis Markup:** - If you use `**bold**` or `*italic*` in TypeSpec comments, Sphinx may misinterpret these if not balanced. Prefer using plain text or ensure that every start marker has a matching end marker.\\n- **Explicit Targets (Links):** - If you use `[Learn more](url)` in doc comments, emitting these into Python docstrings can result in duplicate explicit target names. Use plain URLs or avoid repeating the same anchor text multiple times.\\n- **Block Quotes:** - Avoid using Markdown block quotes (`>`) in TypeSpec doc comments. If you need to highlight something, use plain sentences.\\n- **Unexpected Indentation:** - Ensure all TypeSpec doc comments are left-aligned, with no leading spaces or tabs before the text, unless you are deliberately creating a code block. For code blocks, use triple backticks and add blank lines before and after the block.\\n- **General Style:** - Write documentation in simple paragraphs. Do not mix Markdown with reST, and avoid complex formatting. - Example of a safe docstring for a model property: ```tsp /** * The list of available service tiers. Possible values include: * 1. Basic - Entry-level tier. * 2. Standard - Recommended for most workloads. * 3. Premium - Advanced tier for high throughput. */ ``` - Avoid: ```tsp /** * - Basic * - Standard * - Premium */ ``` **Actionable Steps:** - Go to your TypeSpec definitions for Response and ServiceTier, and revise any doc comments containing bullet lists, definition lists, block quotes, repeated anchor text, or excessive indentation. Replace with simple sentences or numbered lists as above. - After making these changes, regenerate the Python SDK and run the Sphinx build again. The warnings/errors should be resolved. - For reference on Python docstring formatting and Sphinx compatibility, see the Azure Python SDK [docstring guidelines](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/docstring.md). Or you can disable the sphinx environment within the pyproject.toml for the problematic package.
